output: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I apologise once again for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of everyone and the perception that education, knowledge, and the intertwining of different cultures with one another is crucial is already an accepted fact.
For this reason, multiple initiatives associated with this year have been carried out by the different areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus programme also plays its part, and from this new perspective, a new regulation is already in place.

The Erasmus Mundus programme constitutes an important contribution to the creation of centres of excellence in the EU, which will in some way help to stem the brain drain from the European Union, and also plays a significant role in the

in promoting European values among nationals from third countries who come here to study and who find in the old continent a cultural and linguistic diversity that acts as an attractive and distinct pole from models existing in the rest of the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have suffered greatly in order to survive.

The problem of visas for Erasmus Mundus students and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them often lead to a situation of semi-condemnation within the European Union, as they attend master's programs but with tourist visas, and sometimes even altered ones.
The search for a solution that ensures solidity, transparency, and efficiency in the issuance of pre-student visas is considered of utmost relevance and urgency.
Knowledge of the language that allows for cultural appreciation and mutual coexistence, beyond the strictly academic domain, is also crucial, so we can absolutely guarantee this premise.
Finally, a word of thanks to Mrs de Sarnez for the way she has conducted this whole process and for the balanced report she has produced.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, authorisation for the granting of State aid for the modernisation and renewal of the fishing fleets in the outermost regions should only be possible until the end of 2009 or should be valid indefinitely.
The specific nature of fishing activity in these regions justifies that these aids can be granted beyond 2009, without the marine environment being minimally harmed.
Aid for the modernisation and renewal of fleets in the outermost regions is not intended to be permanent and internal.
would be immediately discontinued if studies and evaluation by the Scientific Council and Regional Advisory Councils demonstrated such a need.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fishing in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that justify an exclusive fishing reserve up to the seed for fishermen in each of the outermost regions also justify a differentiated treatment with regard to aid for the modernisation and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, in the Committee on Fisheries, the best solutions were found that can meet the particularities of fishing in the outermost regions.

Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner Almunia, President of the Eurogroup, I want to congratulate not only the rapporteurs, but also the Commission for taking the initiative to produce this text, the assessment of the ten years of Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text and this analysis was fundamental.
The euro, as has been said here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the Euro has proven its resilience and solidity even during the severe turbulence we have witnessed, and it is clear that the borders of this club need to be expanded.
But the current times are putting the solidity of the European project to the test on many other dimensions on a daily basis.
The euro, as I said, is a central instrument of the financial system's operation.

However, the Commission's own text clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor convergence, in social or spatial terms, has kept pace with this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that the disparities have worsened violently during the decade of the single currency's operation.
This divergence affects regions of my country, in particular, northern Portugal, but also other regions of member countries.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, particularly due to the very high exchange rate in practice, have affected more those regions that are most exposed to international competition and the most export-oriented regions.
Today, the crisis that resulted from the deregulation of financial markets is violently affecting the real economy and further exacerbating the situation for many citizens and regions.

These regions, those exposed to international competition, those dependent on small and medium-sized enterprises, those where access to credit is most important, are today falling victim to this process and are even threatening depression.
Mr President, Commissioner, President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the confidence that European citizens have in it.
The most powerful European countries have already begun the process of relaunching their national economies.
We have the case, in particular, of initiatives that concern the automotive industry.
But in Europe, it is more than that.
It must be much more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.

The time has come to transform the euro into a central tool of Europe, supporting a robust currency, but also a robust real economy, and to ensure that the euro's operation is accompanied by these developments.
of mechanisms that ensure the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it is at the heart, at the core of the European project.
Debates on the coordination of economic policies in the euro area now have an enhanced and unquestionable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is needed.

Having a Lisbon Strategy, which is a sum of national initiatives, and a Stability and Growth Pact, which differentially tightens the belt on the different countries that use it and which they have to submit to, are limitations to which we add the limited budget at our disposal.
Crises generate opportunities.
The monetary union can only be sustained by a convergence of well-being of the member countries that integrate it, regardless of their citizens, regardless of the place where they were born.
What other way would we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?
The Commission must live up to its own diagnosis, which is why we eagerly await the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this plenary on November 26 and present to European citizens.

It is essential that, from this crisis, a new phase of the Union be launched, in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by effective prosperity made of cohesion and also economic citizenship.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this oral question submitted to the European Commission by Gerardo Gagliotti, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development of this Parliament, is fully justified and relevant.

In fact, the reasons why the Council is blocking the reform of the Solidarity Fund need to be made clear, as it is unable to agree on a common position that would allow the legislative process to continue.
The reasons that may be underlying the Council's position are hardly discernible, except perhaps for petty financial reasons.
Does the Council not want a more agile and immediate response to the natural disasters that occur?
I do not want the Council to give this kind of quick response to other types of catastrophes, such as serious industrial accidents, terrorist attacks or serious public health situations.

It is important that these questions have a clear answer, just as it is also important to clarify what the European Commission thinks about this situation and whether it intends to take any measures aimed at unblocking the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this area.
Citizens would not understand at all if we were not to do so.
I mean, I wanted to protest against the statement made by Mrs. Lulling, which seeks to condition the vote of the Members of this House, and that conditioning does not make sense.

The interpretation you are making is an interpretation that we do not share and it is only in this sense that I would like to ask my colleagues who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests, which are the interests of public health and the interest of citizens and the interest of countries that in fact vote in favor of the report.
Mr President, Commissioner, for the past two months, the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic over the Lisbon Treaty barely have any coverage in the media.

Don't you think that now the Commission's information and communication strategy should be reinforced with the need and urgency of the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, also as a political response to face and overcome the crisis we are living through?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, the powers of the world have at that time the international financial system at their disposal.
they were looking for a handmade detail and it was about time.
And so, perhaps it is time for us to solve another problem that we have been hearing about for decades.
For decades we have been hearing this song of the ignoble plundering of resources, how often, as now again in the Congo, over the blood of the populations.

I believe that it is also time to pursue these companies, to pursue this ignoble trade, to freeze the accounts through which the shameful profits of this mineral exploitation, at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations, circulate and are deposited.
I don't understand why these companies aren't listed in the same way that we've already blacklisted terrorist organizations.
And I don't understand why the international community is not able to pursue these businessmen who, in fact, are not businessmen, but authentic bandits who jeopardize regional and world security.
I encourage the French Presidency and the Commission to develop an international initiative in this direction.
We have heard it said here several times today that a crisis usually creates an opportunity, and that is indeed the case.
And if we want to seize the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to understand.
First of all, we are aware, at the level of the European Union, of the need to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation, and supervision in financial markets.
And it is not necessary for his commissioner Macri to launch more consultations, nor is it necessary for the Presidency to analyze and invoke more studies.
There are more proposals; you just need to look at the proposals that were made in a timely manner by the socialists and many of which were eventually taken up by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot be in an international space in a passive manner.

It must be an active agent in the construction of the new international order, it must be the defender of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, such as the tax havens are at the moment.
Thirdly, we heard you say here today, Mr President of the Commission, that there is reluctance in coordinating strategies at the level of the different states.
It is true that, if we had not heard from many members of the Commission for so long that the markets were self-regulating and that the state should stay out of it.
if financial markets had no impact on growth or employment, perhaps there would be a more active and effective spirit of solidarity at the level of different countries.
But today the proposal we have in hand is a proposal that is nothing more than a first step. If we compare it with the program of China and the United States, on the other hand, it
it does not define clearly enough what the objective is and the objective has to be employment and, thirdly, because a European programme cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the time for us to show the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of economic rights that protect them in times of crisis, in terms of
solidarity, a growth program, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that, at this time, are not receiving the results of the interventions that were made at the banking level.
The real economy is what it is, and we are here as Europeans to show citizens that Europe is here too, and above all, because of them. Thank you very much.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is with particular satisfaction that I stand before you to present the work that has been done, which was done together with everyone on this own-initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the unfolding of this process, we can say that we did our job.

to everyone, in particular to the shadow rapporteurs from the different political groups who have made great efforts to reach compromises with the future, to the always available regional development staff, especially to Miguel Tel Cremades and Elisa da Fara,

to the PSE staff, Lilla and Petros, the European Commission, who, always represented by the many different directorates-general that such a brilliant report requires, have constantly and closely followed the work and have made great efforts to ensure that it is successfully completed.
To my office and, in particular, to Joana Benziño, my heartfelt thanks on behalf of a more harmonious and structured development for coastal regions and tourism in the European Union.
The 27 member states of the European Union together have more than 89 kilometers of coastal areas.

It presents a variety of very particular characteristics that, according to their location, are demarcated either by cosmopolitanism, if we were to speak of cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen, Stockholm, or

the difficulties of being in peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions, with problems of connections to major cities or with accelerated desertification contexts, such as the Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands or Madeira.
One way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coast and coastal zone and experiences the advantages and disadvantages associated with them on a daily basis.
According to data available up to 2010, about 75% of humanity will live in coastal areas. These areas
According to the circuits and relationships between them, we define the 50 kilometers in a straight line that go from the coastline to the inland areas.
Yes, regions rather than maritime zones detached from the integrated vision that these matters so desperately need and that our ancestors would also subscribe to.
Here, the entire population will concentrate in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, their only expectation is that these will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated view of the impact of tourism on coastal areas took hold of our minds and led us to get to work.

In the current context of financial crisis, where the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly insurmountable, tourism emerges as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal manner.

The regions, which are overwhelmingly or totally dependent on it for their development, see their activity threatened and look to the future with distrust, especially because tourism is not currently a competence of the European Union.
However, coordinated measures can and should be taken, and the spirit in which the Lisbon Treaty was framed reflects this very trend.
However, waiting until the Treaty comes into force to start acting is waiting for the phase when we will cry over spilled milk.
The current political and tourist activity and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it require urgent and effective action from us.

The fact that these are areas structurally dependent on tourism as a source of employment, even if it is often seasonal, means that this labor-intensive activity cannot be overlooked in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

That is why this report that we are presenting to you here and now, which was already of the utmost importance and urgency when the Committee on Regional Development of this House decided to promote it, now assumes that it should be seen as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council from now on.

Priority should indeed be given to the numerous initiatives that it incorporates, as well as to those that assume its express support and that have already been promoted by other institutions, in addition to the measures adopted in the emergency plan.

of the Commission, of which I highlight the review of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector and the shock it is currently experiencing must obviously be covered.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy in these coastal areas, ensuring their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of different sectoral policies, such as the maritime sector, transport,

energy, cohesion instruments already in place, the new quality product policy that the CAP reform incorporates with the announcement of the EFSC report and the new tourist products in these coastal areas, taking into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an appropriate and holistic vision for this policy should be a reality in the near future in the European Union.

And, to conclude, Mr President, only with the clear articulation of these instruments and a rapid and effective action involving all the partners already on the ground can we ensure that we will have a sustainable and future-oriented coastal tourism sector in the European Union.
Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, e-Justice is an important step towards access to law, justice and courts.
I want to congratulate the initiative, commend the rapporteur and the French Presidency.

The EJSTIS was one of the projects under discussion and called on Portugal, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of a pilot project that will allow all citizens to access the services of other member states in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable way and in their own language.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and businesses seeking legal support and basic legal advice on legal and cross-border issues.

The e-Justice system must be coordinated and overseen by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various member states and their articulation with this responsible unit.
Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I welcome the launch of the portal in December 2009.
Mr President, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, Mrs Martin Rühi and the other Members.
In December 2004, the Council adopted a regulation establishing standards for security features and biometric data in passports and travel documents issued by member states.
Now, we have needed to take new steps towards combating the kidnapping and trafficking of children.
The use of passports by children, in accordance with the principle of one person one passport, may be the key means of winning this difficult and important battle.
In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children as young as six years old is already a long-standing practice that, perhaps for that reason, does not cause me any objection.
As a defender of the European cause, I believe that, on this matter, it is important to have harmonization.
It is reassuring to know that member states, such as Portugal, which have long set the minimum age at six years for collecting fingerprints, will not have to amend their national legislation.
It should be emphasized that the security of passports, which is being strengthened today, is not limited to the existence of the passport itself.

The passport, in itself, corresponds to an increase in the level of security, which ranges from the presentation of the necessary documents for the issuance of passports, followed by the collection of biometric data, to the verification and matching at border control posts.
This report is another step towards affirming the rights of the individual and ensuring their safety.
Mr President, first of all, I would like to greet the rapporteur Alexander Lambsdorff and the shadow rapporteurs, with particular emphasis on Barbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I believe it is essential that we move towards the integration of national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must proceed effectively with the necessary specifics and precautions in order to apply the essential rules of the internal market to the defense industries, increasing transparency in the tenders that are organized and in the contracts that are signed involving the member states of the European Union.
But at the same time, we must help develop the conditions that allow European equipment and products to be more competitive in global markets.

It seems important to me that this directive can ensure progress in the legal framework relating to public contracts in the fields of defence and security, moving forward in the construction of the internal market.

within and, of course, respecting the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the field of security, and particularly those that manufacture weapons, ammunition and security equipment, such as, for example, my own country.

I would also emphasize the provisions that allow small and medium-sized enterprises easier access to this market, particularly through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of thus advancing with greater impact and depth in the

industrial for the creation of a true European market in the defense industries, which could also contribute to strengthening research and development, not only in the defense industries, but also in a range of European industries that benefit from the development of the defense industries.
Finally, I think it is worth noting the obvious link between the defense industries and the Union's foreign policies.
But I would like to quote, regarding the DETA, a recent intervention, translating a classic Romanian saying: if you want peace, prepare for war.
The European Union, as it is almost a peaceful superpower, calls these defense industries and not war industries, because we want peace and not war, and that is why we also need defense industries.
Mr. Vice President Barrot, I agree with you, I agree with you with dissatisfaction.
In fact, we have to be dissatisfied with the set of measures that are vast.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are areas where there is a lot of
Regarding immigration, particularly in the Mediterranean towards Italy, France has initiated a series of important bilateral cooperations, but other member states have not followed suit.
The Commission must continue without losing enthusiasm in this policy of cooperation and aid to the United States.
Mr President, Commissioner, I shall try to put the questions in a very concise way.
First point, the issue of the European Union's special monitoring mechanism for the tests, which ended, as mentioned here, on December 31, 2008.
What is lacking, Commissioner, is the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports, and prices, similar to what happens in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against any unfair practices, and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I asked him to pay attention to this, just as other colleagues have already done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety standards, social standards, and environmental standards.
RITES, for example, is a recent initiative that creates even more constraints for us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy that is noticeable and monitorable so that imported products have identical requirements.
In what way are these aspects being properly safeguarded in the ongoing free trade agreements?
And as for Meidine, can Meidine actually help resolve this issue?
Thirdly, the European Union has launched an economic recovery plan to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At this point, what is the Commission preparing to do when a number of other countries, such as China, are beginning to proliferate the imposition of non-tariff barriers, increasingly so, to prevent our European imports from accessing Chinese markets?

What does it propose in terms of updating or adjusting the Globalisation Fund, as well as the support available in the structural funds frameworks, to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Last question, finally, will the crisis we are going through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner, to conclude, persuade her colleagues and the entities dealing with European monetary policy to rebalance their monetary system?
It is clear to us that we should applaud Obama's decision to close Guantánamo, to ban torture, illegal interrogations, and the suspension of military trials.
However, dear colleague, who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese socialist government have no feelings of guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, quite the contrary.

It was precisely now, with the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese Government, with the initiative of Minister Luiz Amado, that the possibility and the duty of the European Union and democratic countries to welcome and receive the detainees without a proven guilt in Guantánamo were triggered.

This is what is truly important, this is what should be highlighted as an example to be followed by the remaining member states of the European Union, as it is important that tomorrow the resolution is approved by all the parties that make up this Chamber so that, in unity, the decision may have more strength.
Mr President, I am very grateful to my colleague Mrs Napolitano for her excellent report.

14 years after Barcelona and 5 years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean with economic power, with parliamentary power, with civil society, with heads of government deciding together.
All with a desire to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent a potential for development and peace for the world.
To follow them only in terms of the economic and business aspects is a clear mistake.

Addressing growth crises naturally requires a political response, but addressing humanitarian crises, emergency situations, and military crises, such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens have to provide answers to the world's problems.
The world demanded answers, and months later, we, citizens and politicians alike, on a platform like the Union for the Mediterranean, are still slow to react.

I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served to learn and move forward, because only those who make mistakes learn, but moving forward in the acceleration of the reaction is absolutely crucial.
The interest in approving this proposal for a directive lies essentially in how it can contribute to stimulating economic activity at the local level and supporting social initiatives.

The application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the field of housing, both in construction and renovation, allowing member states that adopt it to reduce the respective cost for the end user.

Local service provision, particularly by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in the cost of living, ensuring and generating more and better employment by encouraging the consumption of goods and services, thereby stimulating the economy itself.

The restoration activity, which is fundamental for the proper functioning of local economies and the growth of tourism itself, can thus benefit greatly at the local level with this reduction in VAT taxation.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate within the European internal market, which will help to reduce the reservations of some member states already verified at the Council level.
Therefore, I cannot agree to the extension of this reduced rate to equipment, whatever the pretext.

The prudent manner in which this proposal should be handled in the European Parliament should not provide an excuse for governments that have some reservations about the European Commission's proposal to actually use the right of veto that European legislation still provides in fiscal matters.
Thus, here it is prudent to reject large-scale amendments, which only make the acceptance of the text more difficult.
As already mentioned here, not only is the perfect the enemy of the good, but those who want everything end up losing everything.
This proposal for a directive is important not only for strengthening local economies, but it also corresponds to the ambitions repeatedly expressed by several member states.
Let us therefore support the Commission's proposal as it was presented; this, incidentally, was the sense of the vote, as I recall, of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.

I commend the work of the rapporteurs and call for the approval of this proposal in the exact terms in which it was made by the Commission and voted on in the Parliamentary Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.
I gave the floor to my colleague Edith Estrella to disagree with me, and that, incidentally, was what motivated me to speak. It was when she caricatured the intentions of the Czech Presidency.
No one wants to send women home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
There are even associations that seek to defend them, women who are ignored, scorned, discriminated against because they want to dedicate themselves to their families, and we don't listen to them.
And this is a matter of freedom, it is a matter of freedom of choice that the left so loves to invoke, but which they forget about here.
It is about respecting or not the freedom of organization of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who want to do so with a better quality of life, better fatherhood, and better motherhood.
This is what our society also needs to do.
We are not going there, we will not solve the problems of birth rates and people's happiness with prejudices.
We resolve with policies that are adjusted to reality and to the spontaneous desires of the people.
We are not going there as an opposition to the state and the market.
Let's start with a fair look at the family.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the difficult situation at Qimonda has been exacerbated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese government has done everything it deems appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
We would like the Bavarian government to also demonstrate a strong sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving the Munich facilities will have a decisive impact on the Vila do Conde and Dresden units.

The Portuguese minister himself, Manuel Pinho, stated the great interest in making this enterprise viable, which is so important for Portugal and for Europe, mentioning that Aquimonda can be a globally competitive company.
Mr President, the efforts of the Portuguese Government towards a solution that ensures the viability of the company will be maintained.
We hope that the German governments, at both the federal and state levels, will make a genuine effort to resolve this problem.
As for me, I would like to reiterate the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry within European territory.
may no national or state executive make the mistake of allowing this company to close facilities and eliminate jobs within the territory of the Union.

Dear colleagues, we understand the need to help restructure the major groups in the automotive industry, but the Union's funds and the European Commission's energies cannot be exhausted in these aids.

Mr President, dear Commissioner, we appeal to Commissioner Vladimir Spidla, with whom we share bonds of work and political security, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and of a significant part of Quimonda's workers, to commit the Commission to supporting Quimonda, overcoming possible communication failures.

We should point out, before concluding, that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, recently stated in Germany that there was new hope regarding Quimonda and also mentioned the importance, as already highlighted by colleagues, of the very economic sector in which Quimonda operates.
We take into account that the Portuguese Government has expressed its willingness to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, given the country's economic size.
Ladies and gentlemen, let's help save Quimonda, time is of the essence.

Madam President, Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon Strategy for years, and the times we are living in are perhaps not the most suitable for discussing the Lisbon Strategy, but we undoubtedly need a strategy.
in a strategy that addresses the difficulties and challenges that the current crisis presents us with.
And that is what we expect from the Commission too.

It is essential that the Commission does not stray from this issue and, instead, has the capacity to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal and the governments of Germany and the leaders of Germany.

It is essential to keep in mind that this is an industry, as has already been mentioned here, that is of interest to Europe because of its quality and value, the research it develops, and the environmental quality associated with it, and it is essential that the Commission does not turn away.
I endorse the invitation made by my colleague Pineda for his Commissioner and the Commission to visit Portugal.

It is essential that the Commission bear in mind that, at this time, Europeans are looking to Europe and expect answers from the European authorities. They need to feel that the European authorities are close by.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands, rather they want a Europe that has the courage to roll up its sleeves and get to work, helping to overcome difficulties. Thank you very much.
Mr President, I also add my voice to the tributes to Mr Jammeh, but I asked to speak to welcome your President's statement on the European Day in Memory of the Victims of Terrorism.
It was my proposal that led to the adoption of this approach five years ago, which the Council enshrined in a meeting on March 25, following the tragic attacks in Madrid.
But my intervention was an appeal.
Parliament has always been faithful to the celebration of this date, but unfortunately, this date has not yet had the impact it should have among the European institutions and member states.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important tools we have to honor the victims, as your President did, but also to raise the level of public awareness.
I know there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but not much else.
Therefore, I appeal to the Commission and the Czech Presidency to ensure that all member states commemorate this date appropriately in the future.
(FEL) Ladies and gentlemen, my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we expected and unemployment will be higher than we predicted.
There are good reasons to assume that the planned European stimulus is not enough, but it is already clear at this point that it is taking too long to reach the citizens.
The Parliament's position is strong and clear, it has been and I hope it will continue to be.
Our goal is to maintain employment and create new jobs, with cohesion and solidarity, both territorial and social.
And at this time of crisis, citizens cannot be satisfied with a Europe that does not respond to them, with a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems they are experiencing.
What is Parliament going to ask the Commission?

It naturally asks, through these reports, for the coordination of national interventions, asks it to use all the means currently at its disposal to intervene, and provides it with all the conditions, as a budgetary entity, for this to happen.

He asks him to launch a clear European initiative for employment and tells him that it is important to have a calendar-based agenda to implement measures for regulating the financial market, as well as to channel credit into the real economy.
But what is being asked of the council?
The Council is asked, above all, to rediscover the political will that is at the heart of the construction of the European project.
The European Union is competition, but it is also cohesion and solidarity.
And there can be no single market without this guarantee of solidarity and cohesion.
This is what we all delegated at the European level, the national autonomies we had before joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, anyone who visits sub-Saharan Africa easily recognises the enormous weakness of their health systems in most countries and the extremely negative impact that this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations that these services are supposed to serve.
The indicators continuously disseminated at international level do not cease to confirm it.
And, in this regard, it is absolutely disturbing the notion that simple gestures and practices that are not very elaborate, not even particularly expensive, could be enough to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard, and we must always keep in mind how cooperation in the health sector is truly strategic and directly affects not only one of the millennium goals, but many of them.

The Court of Auditors found that Community funding for the health sector has not increased since 2000 in proportion to its total development aid, despite the Commission's commitments to the Millennium Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa.
Be quiet.

And it acknowledged, I quote again, the Commission has made a significant contribution, through its funding, to establish the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but it did not give the same attention to strengthening health systems, which was supposed to be one of its priorities.
(FEL) Fine quote.

According to the Court, this happened again because the Commission lacked sufficient experience in health matters to ensure that the funding for aid granted to this sector was used in the best possible way.
Finish this one.
This is therefore a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors is launching directly at the European Commission, and one that I support.
For our part, I want to reiterate that same challenge, now sustained by the objectivity of these data and this evaluation.
Health services are already part of, but should increasingly be part of, our development aid priorities, and are deserving of increased funding.

Optimizing the way aid is provided, bearing in mind the seemingly antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to the beneficiary populations, is providing a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this request, and it is in this sense that I urge it.
A moment ago, our colleague Mr Bowis made a moving speech here and was able to put faces, human faces, to the dry coldness of these figures from the Court of Auditors.
The challenge for us, Commissioner, is that our cooperation should be able to put a look of joy and hope on those same faces.
And for that, Commissioner, it is essential that the figures in the health sector in our cooperation be different.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing the situation in Guinea Bissau, which is truly distressing.
It is a country that has been living with chronic instability for many years, which attempted a path towards democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing has gone well; there has been a coup d'état, a small internal war, and it is living in great political and military instability, with deep tensions and rivalries, and now, recently, there is also the very worrying presence, increasingly evident to all observers interested in drug trafficking.
We strongly condemn these attacks, the bombing death of Chief of Staff Tagme Naouye, and also the particularly barbaric, not to say savage, murder of President Nino Vieira.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity to their families, to the people of Guinea Bissau, and we deeply regret and condemn these attacks.
We wish for a return to normalcy, and the lesson I have learned and would like to emphasize in the resolution is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, regarding the murder of Assumane Mané and General Alvares M. Ciabra, how is it that a blind eye was turned so that the guilty parties were not found and brought to justice?
It is evident that this is not possible.
Therefore, we must make it clear to the State of Guinea Bissau that those responsible must be found, the guilty must be brought to justice, and we must provide all the necessary help.

I would also like to draw attention, in conclusion, to the concern we have seen regarding the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk it already poses to the European Union, and the shocking presence of it in Guinea Bissau.
I would also like to appeal for closer relations with Cape Verde in this context.

We have established a special partnership with Cape Verde. Cape Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a great deal of knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable, and this is essential for our own European security as well.
Therefore, the intensification of the special partnership with Cape Verde is also very important in this context, thank you very much.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I would first of all like to thank everyone for the work that has been celebrated.

The three lines defined in the Green Paper, concentration, interconnection, and cooperation, can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, particularly the negative effects associated with

concentration of economic activity, inequalities in access to markets and services resulting from distance, and divisions imposed by borders between Member States, particularly the most disadvantaged ones, but also between regions.
We must therefore promote the improvement of synergies between these policies with effective methods of evaluating their territorial impact.

That is why I have always advocated for the definition of additional qualitative indicators, with the aim of improving the allocation and implementation of corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For now, GDP remains the only eligibility criterion for receiving support from the Structural Funds.

However, this definition of additional indicators and the conduct of territorial assessments should not lead to more bureaucracy or further delays, but rather to simplification, the implementation of new policies, and support actions for territorial cohesion.
The fifth interim report, and to conclude, Mr President, makes a specific reference to the transition regions located between the convergence regions and the competitiveness and employment regions.
It is important to note that these regions need to have a clearer status, with more security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the context of this major debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific problems of the outermost regions.

Regions that, due to the combination and persistence of a certain amount of geographical factors, reveal a great economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt in the context of a serious international crisis like the one we are currently experiencing.

It would therefore be worth appealing to the European Commission and, in particular, to Commissioner Hübner, to pay very particular attention to the effects of the current crisis on the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, particularly in tourism, construction, and the rise in unemployment, would be important to enable a specific European response for these regions.

I therefore challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions, which goes beyond the measures already announced under the economic and social cohesion policy for all European regions.
a specific European response to the crisis for the outermost regions.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in response to the global financial crisis, the European economy's relationship plan states that cohesion policy contributes significantly to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a means of recovery from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All the instruments deployed aim to achieve this purpose and accelerate the attainment of results.

In this sense, the broadening of the scope of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund and the acceleration of the European Social Fund have, in particular, the responsibility to respond to the multiple situations of social and economic emergency that require support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that their action will be all the more effective the more complementary their actions and spheres of activity are.

However, as there is no provision for the mobilisation of new funds or new lines of action on the ground, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund is used to its full potential in the fight against unemployment and the rapid increase in competitive pressure in the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic slowdown.

I would like to emphasize that the Committee on the Rules of Procedure has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for improving the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission is now proposing.

We were asked to act urgently, however, on this matter, and when adopting this regulation package, we took this into account, and this cause has never shied away from assuming its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite the many views that the particularity of the moment raises, in addition to the guarantees of the process's swiftness and the real benefit to citizens that the proposal aims for, we refrain from presenting new proposals and amendments at this time.
However, we caution that it is necessary to initiate an evaluation process of this fund immediately, with a view to carrying out a supplementary review as soon as possible.
The crisis, among other aspects, highlighted the strong imbalances between the countries of the eurozone, perhaps the main cause of tension.
conclusion of the report on the Economic and Monetary Union, but above all the extreme vulnerability of countries that, while belonging to the European Union, do not belong to the eurozone.

This is why the reinforcement of the means available at European level to support balance of payments crisis situations is absolutely essential, and this is why we welcome the increase from 12 to 25 million euros and then to 50 million euros in necessary funds.
However, the most important thing is to address the root causes of the problems and not just their most obvious manifestations.
Today, the enlarged Europe and the eurozone must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to see in this light what the capacity of European horizontal policies is, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments, such as Eurobonds.
Financial assistance for the balance of payments is necessary, but it is far from sufficient to ensure the sustainability of the European project and the European single currency.
Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was not, in fact, the time for us to discuss internally how to organize ourselves. Therefore, my wish is that the Lisbon Treaty be quickly ratified so that we can face the world stage united and in solidarity, as Europeans.

As for the economic crisis, in the report I authored and which this Parliament approved by a majority, we acknowledged that the recovery plan, which had since been presented by the Commission, was not sufficient.
Today we are certain that it is not enough.
A crisis that began in the financial sector extends to the real economy, then to employment, and then to the social sphere.
It is not sufficient and it is out of focus.
This is the Commission's opportunity to respond to the real problems of Europeans, through serious financial regulation and not the lightest and most fragmented one that the European Parliament has.
possible, as it is currently underway, not of individualistic national plans, but of a genuine European initiative, not through scattered means, but by focusing on the real challenge that I employ.

In every crisis there is an opportunity, this is the opportunity for the Commission and for Europe to respond to the real problems of European citizens, and I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the relaunch plan.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would just like to express, not only on behalf of the EPP, as has already been done by many Members, but in particular on behalf of the Portuguese EPP Members, our great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly reinforces the prospects for development and evolution of the European Union, which creates conditions for a new stage.

We naturally wanted to pay tribute to all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President present here, and also, of course, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union, which

You have a very important role here, and that is why we also wanted to say with pleasure that we have noticed that despite all these vicissitudes and while we are still eagerly awaiting the position of the Czech Republic, the Portuguese will be very happy to see the name of their capital linked to it.

It is a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union, and I would like to say that we can also count on another flag in this perspective, which will always be a flag of the Portuguese MEPs of the EPP, which is the flag of the national parliaments.
We argue that the Lisbon Treaty takes a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of national parliaments into European democracy.

And that is why we believe that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, is the representative dimension and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendum dimension.

If the fundamental and essential aspect of democracy is representation and not direct voting, then the Lisbon Treaty is a major step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
That is why we are very pleased with this decision by the Irish people.

Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a brief intervention to welcome the historic and broad result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role that Fine Gael and its leader and future Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, played in leading this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became very apparent.
They are, we are all, the main recipients of all the Union's actions.
It is essential that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has on our lives on a daily basis.
Europe is our living space.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, it is good for its citizens.
This is certainly the case with the Lisbon Treaty.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can simultaneously be a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, having concluded a debate that has lasted too long about its organisation and functioning, will be able to focus much more and with new, much more effective instruments on the real problems facing Europeans: competitiveness, growth and employment.
I conclude, Mr. President, Madam Minister, with a proposal for future generations.

Given the information deficit regarding the values, competences, objectives, and functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory education in each Member State, a new mandatory European studies course.
In an objective, truthful and concrete way, young Europeans will effectively learn about our principles, who we are, what we do and where we want to go.

It is through knowledge, from a young age, that they will understand throughout their lives the potential and enormous usefulness of the European identity of this unique project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, I begin by congratulating you on this first debate on what this new instrument of political control means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is European citizens, through their representatives, who stand to gain.

In view of the latest developments, the Irish referendum, the ratification by Poland and the recent statements by the President of the Czech Republic, I would like to know your assessment of the process of bringing the Lisbon Treaty into force.
Efforts have been made by the President of the Commission.
and what is your prediction for a possible entry into force date of the treaty and, on the other hand, to know if at this moment and based on this prediction, the Commission
Some steps have already been taken to transition from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, or is it still in a phase of, shall we say, expectation, therefore, in a phase of waiting to see.
Mr President of the Commission, having heard that, I would like to know the following at this stage when everyone is waiting for the formation of the Commission: what is the President's perspective?

It remains to be seen whether we will now have a Commission in office until that final ratification by the Czech Republic, or whether the procedures for appointing the new Commissioners will move forward.

Mr President, it is essential that the primary objective of the creation of the European External Action Service materialises the efforts of the European institutions to ensure the creation of an effective service, capable of articulating, formulating and implementing a European response to the international challenges of the present.
It must also represent more than the parts that constitute it; it must be added value in relation to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential to me that what makes the specificity of the Union is at the center of this new reality, and that specificity is the Community method.
That is why I give my full support to the Brok report, which advocates for and safeguards a close partnership between the Commission and the future Service.

In this context, I would like to highlight two aspects: the importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, who is also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure effectiveness and smooth functioning.
Finally, there is a need for an alliance between Parliament and the Commission to combat the impending intergovernmental drift that could compromise the effective functioning of the service.
Parliament must therefore be vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will be a centre of excellence representing the best skills in terms of foreign policy.
Mr President, Commissioner, I, first and foremost, want to emphasize the importance of this issue that was raised by Mr Gloriano, because it is a matter of the most basic justice.

We all know perfectly well that, in a situation of an A flu pandemic, it will be the countries of the South that will suffer the most from this problem and from the consequences of the virus's proliferation, not the countries of the North.

And every year we passively witness the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or have treatments available in the Northern countries. An immense list of malaria, dengue, yellow fever, tuberculosis,
We have no limits to this list and we passively watch this problem unfold.

We effectively use the countries of the South as providers of free samples of the new strains of the virus so that we can improve treatment in the countries of the North, but, despite this, we remain without an effective response to these problems and, therefore, to the questions that have been raised, I would just like to add a few more.
We want to effectively treat this problem as a public health issue or as a business.
Because, if it is a public health problem, we must ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and for that, efforts must be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope it is not the case, if we are waiting for the vaccine stocks in Europe to become so overburdened.

that the secondary FPI are proving to be so negative in this regard, and that it is only then that we have an act of generosity and suddenly start sending the necessary vaccines to the countries of the South.

Finally, I just wanted to ask if the European Union, we Europeans and the Commission, are comfortable with a system or a model in which northern countries deal with pandemics through a prevention model and in the southern countries it is treated as palliatives or only with leftovers.

Mr President, first of all, I want to express my full support for the issue raised by Mr Reul and, above all, highlight the underlying issue, the fundamental political issue at stake here, which is precisely related to the joint programming of research.

What happened in terms of joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases and, in particular, on Alzheimer's, was that, in the middle of the process, the rules were changed, we stopped having a report, we started having a resolution, so our capacity for co-decision on this matter was eliminated, we stopped being deputies, we became consultants.
And, therefore, I would like to know if, at least, what we recommend will be taken into consideration or not.
The programming of research activities, in whatever field, is a political choice, not a technical one, and in this sense, the role of Parliament should be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that setting priorities that are political means that they must be accountable, that they must be transparent, and that they must be democratic.
What happened with the process regarding the joint decision and joint programming of Alzheimer's research is a process that should not be repeated again.

Could you please repeat that they should notify us in advance? I therefore hope that the last thing that could happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations that Parliament has presented on this matter are not taken into account.
Mr. President, last month, the regions of Europe were particularly in evidence.
The European Week dedicated to regions and cities focused on the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in the European response to global challenges.
This was concluded, leaving no room for doubt, by President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Samezky, and the hundreds of debates that took place.

Moreover, at a more specific level, the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the Outermost Regions of Europe, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constitutes a milestone in regional policy in favor of European construction.
Global challenges and European responses constitute a great opportunity for a new strategy for the ORs.

These regions, such as the Azores, in addition to the permanent constraints that everyone is accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that offer clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give Europe a clear advantage in new areas essential to responding to global challenges.

It is therefore imperative that the President of the Commission puts a clear end to the palace coup that the Commission's No Paper indicates was being prepared, while we, Members of Parliament and European citizens, were advocating for the ratification of the Lisbon Treaty and its importance in defending the cohesion of the territory.

I would first of all like to commend the rapporteurs, particularly Mr Martin and also Mr Corbet, and say that, as a member of the EPP, I basically recognise myself in the amendments proposed to the Rules of Procedure.
It was essentially important to highlight the point that seems important to me here and that has not yet been brought up this evening, which is the point of the national parliaments.
The democratic strengthening of the European Parliament undoubtedly results from this system and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also results from the connection to national parliaments.
And what this Regulation or this proposal is now doing is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacies, to strengthen democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the European Parliament's own instruments, its instruments for monitoring its legislative capacity, and on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of national parliaments through different instruments.
And that is why I am, let's say, totally in tune with the proposals made.
I do not agree with my colleague Mr Duff when he says that we should postpone the interruption of mechanisms for relations with national parliaments.
I think we can do this right now, in the light of the Lisbon Treaty, and that this is very important.
I would also like to say that I support the proposal of my colleagues Sayer and Brock regarding representation in COSAC and, finally, that I am
I fully agree with the comments made here by my colleague Mr Brok and other colleagues about the primacy of Parliament and Members of Parliament over Parliament's services.
Mr President, Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I congratulate my fellow rapporteur on the work done on this report and on her speech just now.
This new microfinance instrument will allow for the granting of microcredit to small businesses and to people who have lost their jobs and want to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important at a time when the economic crisis is expected to result in the loss of three and a half million jobs in the European Union alone.

As a consequence of the economic slowdown, banks have stopped granting loans for job creation and business development, and access to credit is more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new microfinance medium will counteract the current trend of restricting access to credit, making it easier to obtain the necessary funds for launching new businesses and creating new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate 100 million euros from the PROGRESS programme budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Thus, the reallocation of PROGRESS resources, which targets the most vulnerable groups, is not at all the most appropriate solution.
For this reason, it supports the creation of a separate budget line to finance this instrument, as well as an increase in the allocation to 150 million euros.

We also agree with the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group is vulnerable groups who have difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and who face the threat of social exclusion.
Therefore, the reference to specific groups should be suppressed.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential that people who have financial support also have adequate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the EPP and on behalf of the Portuguese EPP delegation.
Our assessment of the Swedish Presidency is one of almost complete success, essentially in four key areas.
Firstly, in the institutional area, the Swedish Presidency's contribution to the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, and to the very successful election of the Commission President.
for, in particular, all the ratification issues associated with the ratification, was extremely professional and was at the level of what is expected from the best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Lisbon Treaty, this contribution from the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, of course, the Commission's work has also been extremely important.
We must say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many EPP deputies, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has been most successful.
It is leading the real global fight and this is due to the efforts of both the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, the Commission Presidency.
We also consider this balance to be very positive.

A third point is the issue of financial regulation, which, especially with this last Council, has taken a step that we consider decisive and that could have a very significant impact on the exit from the crisis.
And therefore, I would also like to congratulate you on the fact that an agreement was reached in this area.
And finally, I would like to say a word about an area that personally means a lot to me, which is the Stockholm Programme and, consequently, the area of security, justice, and freedom.

I believe that I, who have followed both the tempering process and especially the AIA process afterwards, consider this Stockholm Programme absolutely essential and I would like to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt for this.

Mr President, the recognition of professional qualifications was consolidated into a single legislative act, as is known, comprising 15 directives, which has led to various practical problems in implementation across the different Member States.

The difficulties are known and the Commission should identify the critical points and carry out an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market provision.
Protectionism, which manifests itself at various levels, constitutes an obstacle not only to the free movement of people, but also to the internal market.
We must try to identify the grey areas so that the effectiveness of the directive is not undermined by mistrust.
The Union is not being asked to do what the member states should do, but there is an effort to facilitate that helps to dismantle professional corporatism.
An improvement in the application of this directive should involve promoting the recognition of qualifications in the SOLVIT network and the EURES network by encouraging
common platforms, implementation of effective contact points and, not least, it should provide an articulation of this directive with the services directive.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is urgent that we promote a debate on the Community budget and how we can contribute to its sustainability and transparency in the future.

The post-2013 financial framework must be built on the basis of solidarity and territorial cohesion, values that are crucial for regions like Madeira, which face permanent difficulties and therefore require ongoing support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking about and building cohesion policy.

The Commission has been referring, on several occasions, to some aspects that I consider essential, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency and a more results-oriented approach in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are issues that give me some concern, especially considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this matter, allow me three brief notes. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as, for example, value-added sectors.

A reorientation like this could undermine Objective 2, which currently benefits about two-thirds of European regions, and could potentially be counterproductive in regions with very specific economic profiles and competitive advantages. Secondly, I believe that maintaining the proximity criterion in cohesion policy is vital.

it must continue to prioritize the allocation and management of structural funds from a regional perspective, rather than a national or even centralized European perspective. Thirdly, and last but not least, it would be worth remembering and emphasizing Article 349.
Article 349 of the Lisbon Treaty provides for special treatment of the outermost regions with regard to access to structural funds, precisely because of their economic and social situation.

The situation is exacerbated by perennial constraints and unique characteristics, which manifest themselves in the aforementioned constant difficulties and therefore require the requested permanent assistance.
Mr President, in the face of urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen was several steps backwards.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than Kyoto, but it also created more divisions and, as a result, what happened was that we ended up with a situation of every man for himself, where each state can define its own objectives and, on top of that, in a voluntary regime.
it should be noted that if we have a two-degree Celsius target or funding goals without any clarification, that cannot be of any comfort to us either.
And so, what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future, and acting in terms of the future is about moving from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always stated so.
But when we got to Copenhagen, he ended up hesitating, failing to define or defend the goals he stated here as his own and which he wouldn't trade.

And so, what I ask is whether, for the future, we will not be more just, whether we will continue to allow, at the cost of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest to continue to pay the heaviest bill.
Mr President, I wanted to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at the moment, where it is clear that the media is one of the main problems in the world.
It brought to light a government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, which jeopardizes freedom of expression.
This week, a well-known journalist, Mario Crespo, had one of his columns censored, also at the suggestion or apparent suggestion of the prime minister.

In light of this, Prime Minister José Sócrates must provide substantial explanations to the country, he must explain that he is not suppressing, censoring, or controlling freedom of expression in Portugal.

At this rate, Portugal is no longer a state governed by the rule of law, but a formal state governed by the rule of law, where the prime minister confines himself to formalities, procedures, and formalism, and does not want to provide substantial explanations.
For Portugal, we want a material State of Law.

Mr President, the Green Paper on the reform of the common fisheries policy, for which my colleague on the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Maria do Celso Patrão Neves, is the rapporteur, is a unique opportunity for a debate on a sector that is of great importance in balancing the local development of the outermost regions.

Madara is following the ongoing discussion with particular interest and believes it is imperative to propose a differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is essential to defend a principle of positive discrimination, in terms of limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone only to local artisanal fleets.
In forestry, priority is given to supporting the modernization of vessels, as well as management that ensures the conservation of a comprehensive group of species in the long term.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid situations that are unsustainable for economic, environmental, and social balance.
Finally, we will strive to ensure that fisheries in the outermost regions receive permanent, not time-limited, support.
This report on EAFRD aims to extend the eligibility of housing interventions in favor of marginalized communities in our member states.
Until now, this support was only applicable to marginalized communities living in urban areas of the new member states.
That is, since the vast majority of these types of communities live in rural areas and in shelters, these communities could not benefit from support to replace poor-quality housing.
It is, in essence, about how to kill a vaccine and give member states and their regions greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
I also advocate for equal treatment for all member states, as marginalized communities with support and integration needs deserve our concern, regardless of the member state they belong to.

By concluding at first reading this important report on the fight against poverty and for human dignity, we are also ensuring its rapid implementation within the framework of the economic recovery plan, responding swiftly to the crisis that affects us.

Mr President, Commissioner, allow me to begin by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr Van Nistelrooy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the willingness he has always shown to incorporate other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will vote on amendments to the ERDF regulation that are of particular importance to the so-called old member states and also to Portugal.

These changes will allow the use of the ERDF in the housing sector to be extended in favor of marginalized communities, since currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The amendments that he proposed, together with other colleagues and which were approved by a large majority in the Committee on Regional Development, will allow the old Member States, and not just the new ones, as the original proposal provided, to also benefit from this possibility of funding.

With this, I tried to prevent the opening of a precedent that I consider dangerous and that would exclude all the former Member States from this and, probably, from other additional uses of Community aid.
This would not make any sense, since housing problems, especially among marginalized communities, exist in both new and old member states.
I take this opportunity to reiterate that the seniority of EU membership should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds and that this criterion should be definitively abandoned.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy must be based on solidarity, aiming at territorial cohesion, and should be oriented towards rewarding, rather than punishing, regions that have shown exemplary use of community aid.

Mr President, I would like at this point to essentially underline to the Commission and to the President of the Commission the way in which they have worked with this Parliament over these months of investiture.
There is no executive body in the world with legislative initiative capacity that is subject to its president presenting a program before Parliament, and holding a hearing with all the groups.

Members of Parliament to a vote by an absolute and significant majority, bringing here all the commissioners to be heard one by one with their own agenda, with three to four hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.
someone who agreed to negotiate a framework agreement with Parliament, in which they agreed, first and foremost, to justify and expand Parliament's powers in the area of legislative initiative.

which accepted the principle of full access to information, both in legislative and political action and in international negotiations, which accepted taking into account Parliament's opinion on the commissioners, on the reshuffling of the commissioners.
This means, once and for all and from my point of view, that the Commission has proven, from July until now, that it is willing to have a close relationship with Parliament and that it is

The President did so, demonstrating in a clear, vivid, and unequivocal manner that the strategic alliance of the Lisbon Treaty for the Community method that colleague Sarkozy Zwolowski spoke of is the alliance between Parliament and the Commission.
And for that reason, the Commission and the framework agreement deserve the full support of the EPP.
Mr President, five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians seem to look back on this period as a missed opportunity.
And it's not just the fault of their political elites.
It is certain that they consumed themselves too much in wars of power and influence.
many reforms were not implemented, many did not go beyond the paper.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy electoral laws should be changed between the two rounds of an election.
It does not dignify those who proposed them, those who voted for them, or those who promulgated them.
and translates the intentions that are not praiseworthy or recommendable in its genesis.
And much needs to change in the absence of independence of the judiciary, which is subject to too much influence, not only from the political power, but also from economic agents.
Without a free and independent judiciary, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, there is no progress.
But the blame for this disenchantment also lies very much with this Parliament and, essentially, with many Member States.
I would like us to, for a few seconds, put ourselves in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to the vicissitudes of history, is not yet a member of the European Union.
What kind of spiritualism is it not?
solidarity.
