But many chancelleries, with the sole concern of not annoying and displeasing Moscow, have used and abused the permanent internal struggles in Kiev to avoid stating unequivocally that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if this is the majority will freely expressed by its people and provided they meet the established criteria, Ukraine may aspire to become a member of the European Union in the future.
I would like to emphasize that in island regions, air transport offers the only possibility of access and that the operating conditions are conditioned by the size of their passenger and cargo flows.

There are island regions where the abundance of these flows is appealing to many air operators, attracting competition and low transport prices, thus improving accessibility. Other regions, such as the Azores, have reduced flows that are not attractive to operators' interests.

As a result, airfares are higher, constituting an obstacle to population mobility and a limiting factor in attracting tourists who allow that enormous potential for development and diversification of its economic base to flourish and be built.
This framework is particularly penalizing in times of crisis like the one we are going through.

Temporary support is therefore essential to encourage an increase in flows so that the market can start to function, and to share the objectives of the trans-European networks in bringing the peripheries of Europe closer together, including these regions with high tourist potential.
Mr President, I have taken the floor in this House today with a voice choked by the dismay of someone who personally lived through and witnessed the tragedy that struck Madeira last Saturday.
My words are, of course, to join in the feeling of grief and mourning that has affected the families of the 42 fatalities, to whom I pay my respects in recognition of their losses.

The true extent of this catastrophe is yet to be revealed, as search and rescue teams, who have been working tirelessly since Saturday in a Herculean effort, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
and we fear that the number of victims may increase.
The scene is one of large-scale destruction, with extensive damage to access roads, completely destroyed highways and bridges, and to essential services such as water and electricity supply.
There are about 600 displaced people who have lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal course of life.
You need to look forward now.
I also need to convey a message of solidarity, hope, and trust to people.
Help is needed, and this is where the European Union and Parliament, in particular, have a say. They are crucial in the process of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called upon to intervene, we have to do so quickly, because we cannot ask these people to wait, especially when they need us the most.
I appeal to the Commission and its President, Mr Barroso, especially to the Commissioner for Regional Development, João H. Ahn, and welcome their initiative to visit Madeira as soon as possible.
Asking him to also be the bearer of this message of hope, of help and support for reconstruction, because now is the time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately and once again, has forgotten me.
But I am sure we will do it, because as the Madeiran anthem hinted to me, the Madeiran people are humble, stoic and brave.
It is the people who worked the land among the rocks, heroes of labor in the barren mountain.
Through wood he will honor his history and at the end of work he will struggle and achieve his well-being and glory.
We begin today's plenary session with a minute of silence.

And it was a minute of silence with two meanings: one of solidarity with the victims of this absolute catastrophe in Madeira and their families, and a sense of tribute to all the workers who have been providing assistance to these victims tirelessly.
But the minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead to a reflection that goes beyond what we are doing here.
What we heard in the wood is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself more and more.
Climate change causes extreme phenomena to recur, and we must have responses to them.
We cannot prevent natural disasters, but we should not be condemned to always have to suffer their dramatic effects on people's lives.
That is why we must fight for planning and zoning policies that are oriented towards the public good.

But I want to conclude, Mr President, with what is most important and what brought us here, which is that the European Commission, the European Parliament and the European institutions must have the capacity to respond urgently to an emergency situation, and for that, the necessary financial resources and the necessary speed are required.
a tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of the tragic events that occurred on Saturday on the island of Madeira.
As a Syrian, as a Portuguese and as a European, I cannot help but appeal to Parliament and the Union to show their active solidarity with the autonomous region of Madeira and its people.
It is in the regions that the Union's presence needs to be felt, and it is precisely in these moments when its solidarity is most needed that it is also most important for it to be felt.

Mr President, I too wish to express my solidarity with the suffering of the people of Madeira and to urge the European institutions, and the Commission in particular, to mobilise all the resources available to them to provide this aid.
I would also like to emphasize that when there is a disaster of this kind, it is much more difficult to address its consequences when it occurs in poor countries and poor regions.

But, in the case of wood, we must also take into account that the economic base of wood is directly affected by the fact that, depending on tourism, it has a double consequence when its natural beauty, its access, its quality of life, is all destroyed.

Therefore, there is indeed a different situation when we have problems of this severity in poor countries and poor regions, and in particular in mountainous and tourist regions, as is the case with timber.
Therefore, it is absolutely essential that all the adaptations that were planned and requested, and that were mentioned here regarding the Solidarity Fund, do not wait any longer.

they come into effect immediately, because, due to climate change, these processes will unfortunately be repeated, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those that experience torrential rainfall in terms of water and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you very much once again, Mr. President.
Mr President, Commissioner and Council, we are here to talk about the reinvention of the energy system on a European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I think it is one of the very important challenges, as is mentioned, in fact, in the communication that is made.
It is one of the challenges we must address centrally, but there is no clarification here, hence the importance of raising these questions and asking for clarification.
It seems that not only the clarification of funding is lacking, but also the political clarification is missing.
There is talk of energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear, biofuels, solar energy, and even of energy efficiency as the cheapest way to reduce emissions.
It surprises me that there are other, much cheaper ways to reduce carbon emissions that don't even involve this communication, such as, for example, reducing consumption in the first place.
energy, microgeneration, distribution and different forms of distribution and different projects that do not have to go through large structures and access to energy.
Hopefully, we were certainly contributing to more financial clarification to make the plan cheaper.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, there is still a need to talk about what seems to me to be an absolutely important point, which is the emphasis that is permanently placed on public or private partnerships, as if they were the solution to everything.
When asked where the money comes from, the Commission tells us it comes from where it is.
I confess that I am not any more enlightened by being told that the money will come from where it is, without being told exactly where it is.

And therefore, this reliance on public or private partnerships, which is systematically made when we talk about low-carbon technologies, is certainly based on the certainty that, not knowing where the money comes from and knowing that they are public or private partnerships, we know who will pay.
Taxpayers will pay for it at the beginning, and consumers, who also happen to be taxpayers in the end, will pay for it too.

And we know that from now on, the institutions and private organizations are the ones who pay less, and those that make investments are remunerated for it, but in the end they end up monopolizing the profits.
Without this clarification, it seems to me that, once again, we are systematically passing on the bill for the change in the European energy model to future generations.

Mr President, the European Union recently concluded an agreement with Latin American countries within the framework of the World Trade Organization, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on banana imports from those countries.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement has directly negative effects on European banana producers, particularly on the Madeira banana producers in Portugal, but also, even more intensely, on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I would like to remind you that the situation of producers in these regions is already seriously hampered by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the size of their farms, which leads them to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures in defense of banana producers, wood producers, and the Canary Islands, taking into account the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva Agreement has on the European import market and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas from these outermost regions.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as the rapporteur for partnership of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to start with a point.
I would like to congratulate Mr Kirilov, even in his enforced absence, and highlight the way in which he has managed to produce this important report, facilitating the main objective.
I would also like to congratulate Ms Creol for the presentation she gave us.
This main objective is, quite simply, to simplify procedures and accelerate the implementation of programmes financed by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds and the Regional Development Fund.
In the context of the current financial, economic and social crisis, pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will decrease with better use of community funding, with these resources arriving more quickly to the beneficiaries most affected by the economic downturn.
More than 20 million Europeans are unemployed, which is 4 million more than a year ago, and unfortunately, the trend is to increase.

This situation requires ensuring the proper execution of cohesion programs, as they represent a more powerful and relevant lever for helping the real economy, particularly in small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the driving force of the European economy and the key players in sustainable growth and job creation in terms of both quantity and quality.

The continuation of simplification and clarification of the rules governing cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of programme implementation, particularly because it will be

national, regional and local authorities the possibility of using clearer and less bureaucratic rules, which will allow for more flexibility in adapting programmes to new challenges. Thank you very much.
Mr President, of course this crisis was an unforeseen crisis and of course the precautionary principle had to take priority.
But there are lessons to be learned, and the first is that, for five days, no sufficiently strong and politically irresponsible European voice was heard.
And that voice was missed when it came to defending passengers' interests, clarifying their rights, seeking transport alternatives, and coordinating solutions.

A second conclusion is that the way out of the crisis cannot appear, in the eyes of the average citizen, to be a power struggle between those who want to avoid losses and those who want to defend the precautionary principle.
There must be clear transparency and clear objectivity about the conditions under which one exits a situation of full coverage of the European space.
And that is why improving scientific tests and coordination at the same level is important.

Mr President, I also want to start by congratulating my colleague Mrs Thyssen Kohl on her work and persistence on this very important dossier, and on her work to improve the energy performance of buildings and to make Europe more sustainable.
Energy consumption in the European Union, as we know, is far above what is acceptable, which is why moving forward with proposals of this nature is so important.
It is high time we had an ambitious policy in European terms and that we added to this ambitious policy complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation in which we live.
The construction sector is said to be one of the sectors, one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of economy and energy, but it is not just that.
And that is not all, and that is why it is an excellent sector for the implementation of public policies, and it is in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr. President.
We must therefore seize this opportunity that is given to invest in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and their potential for creating millions of jobs in the coming years.
And it's not just about new buildings, but also about the rehabilitation and recovery of existing buildings that are degraded or inadequate.

Let us therefore use this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revival of the European economy and we cannot continue to neglect the investment that can and should be strategic for recovery from the crisis. Let us hope that there will be investment from the Commission and that the Member States will know how to take advantage of this investment.

Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Mr Manders on the work he has done on this report, and also by thanking the Members who have collaborated with him on this dossier.

In fact, the mere fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the current regulatory framework, bringing together all existing legislation, three basic guidelines on the naming and labeling of textile products, in a single regulation, is an important achievement in itself.

But, beyond that, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities and will also allow for a framework for new developed fibers, thus encouraging innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This revision will also enhance the transparency of the process of adding new fibers to the list of harmonized fiber names.
There seems to be no doubt that the agents involved will benefit from this regulation.
Let's see the textile industry will benefit from a saving in administrative costs and the possibility of marketing new fibers earlier.
For their part, the authorities of the member states will not need to transpose the amendments into national legislation, which will enable a significant cost saving for these member states.
And consumers will have the assurance that the fibers designated meet specific characteristics, while also benefiting from the fact that the new fibers reach the market sooner.
For the European industry, the introduction of these new fibers is important as a way to promote innovation, while also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
In the current context of a globalized world, with emerging economies and increasingly expanded markets, in which millions of products produced by millions of companies circulate,
The focus on innovation and the speed at which this innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
that the application of this regulation may increase its competitiveness.
These small and medium-sized enterprises will certainly gain market share with this new regulation and, in this way, will contribute to increased employment in Europe.
Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, the shortage of organs for transplantation is a major problem.

It has been mentioned here several times and it is a major problem that raises issues related to public health, as well as issues associated with the strengthening of the parallel market and organ trafficking, which does not enhance our health systems or our citizens in any way.

And so we must combat this crime, and to combat it through legislation of proposals, such as those we are discussing here, is a way, it seems to me, more than important and more than relevant, and that is why I want to focus on the dimensions and the most important issues raised by these two proposals.
Because the system we have so far, and not having these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
Inequalities between member states, inequalities between existing systems, inequalities in access to organs, inequalities between citizens, which I believe we cannot tolerate.
Therefore, it is important to emphasize that these inequalities are reduced and these proposals aim to combat precisely that.

I think that a European system that maintains, where appropriate, some specific features of certain countries so that they are not forced to have more restrictive systems is the answer to this problem.

And the work that has been developed by the rapporteurs, by Mr. Deputy Miroslav László Jároly and by Mr. Deputy Perello Rodrigues, are works of extreme importance and contribution to this problem that we face.
We are talking about proposals that are based on and supported by issues such as donation, volunteering, I apologize, free services, confidentiality, and data protection.

Traceability, responsibility - and here I think it is important from Parliament's side that we look at patient recovery and not just donation and cooperation between member states - I think we are on the right track.
I must just point out, however, and in relation to donations between living individuals, I am pleased with the inclusion and the expansion, this expansion made with rights.

Obviously, it guaranteed all rights and all conditions, but it was very important that it went beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise it would be just another way of having other forms of equality.

Promoting the DAD as the main source of transparency and protecting patient data and safety seem to me to be more than sufficient reasons for us all to come together tomorrow and vote in favor of these two proposals of utmost importance to health.

Mr President, Minister and Commissioner, the ability to replace deteriorated human organs with organs from another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

European benchmarking reveals that medium-sized countries, such as Portugal, perform very well in such comparisons, and larger countries, such as Spain, are now recognized as organizational leaders and promoters of best practices.
some principles and practices to safeguard.

Firstly, the strengthening of scientific knowledge and information, which will lead more donors to donate while still alive and to generalize post-mortem donation. Secondly, the prohibition of the commercialization of the

This donation system not only applies to member states, but also to those outside of them, preventing transplant tourism and combating organ trafficking. Thirdly, proactive promotion of donation in hospitals as a way to overcome the shortage.

Finally, Madam President, ensuring equal access to transplantation for all those who need it and qualify under harmonized clinical criteria, adhering to the principle of universal access to health, the paradigm of the social Europe of which we are proud.
I congratulate the rapporteurs on the work they have done.
I would like to emphasize that it is with great, shall we say, satisfaction that the European People's Party and the Portuguese Members of the Party
On the European side, the process of accession, of the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights, is beginning.

We, after all, a country like Portugal, which has always been at the forefront of human rights, with the abolition of slavery in Portugal as early as 1761, with its pioneering role in the abolition of the death penalty, can obviously only be interested and supportive of this accession process.

However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that we consider it very important that the European Parliament follows every step of the negotiation for the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider this aspect, from a technical, legal and political point of view, to be fundamental, because Parliament is also a home of human rights and a place where human rights are of great importance, and I would just like to make a point that we consider to be very important.

For us, Members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many states outside the European Union, it is very important, it is a very good signal that we give to the members of the Council of Europe, to the entry of the European Union, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
For these members of the Council of Europe, this is a sign of the European Union's increased commitment to their situation and to the levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.

Madam President, Commissioner, social housing is an economic service of general interest, with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities for the benefit of the whole of society.
According to Protocol 26, annexed to the Lisbon Treaty, it is the responsibility of national, regional and local authorities to implement and organise these types of services.
Hence, the restriction of the target audience to families with incomes below 30 euros is hardly understandable.

This is a measurement of poverty that is made in absolute and purely financial terms, which does not take into account the diversity of the twenty-seven member states, and is reduced to a simple argument of solvency.
Now, social housing addresses cultural and social issues, proximity to the workplace, the important redefinition of women's role in the market, and the mobility of workers in the European space.
The struggle that the European Union is waging to emerge from the current crisis involves economic growth, which entails an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.
economic and cultural factors and the need for their integration, even with the associated risks of ghettoization that we must combat with a fair balance.
Is the Commission not encroaching on the area of competence of the Member States?

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, allow me, Madam President, to note that we are debating the first report of the Committee on Agriculture, subject to the new ordinary legislative procedure provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon.

This is a historic moment that, if this House confirms the proposed voting direction, will begin this new period of shared competence in agricultural matters in the European Union in the best possible way.
I speak precisely with the Icelanders about their outermost regions, in a practical demonstration of the will to build a Union that is strengthened by cohesion.
in the spirit of active solidarity, with respect for the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path for building our common European project.

I also speak about introducing fundamental regulations to make the already century-old sugar industry viable in the Azores, the region where I come from, which is why I am particularly pleased, thereby contributing to a
healthy agricultural diversification in a region where the dairy sector occupies, as we know, a unique dimension on a national scale, irreplaceable, which we must sustain and consolidate.
Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Cioloş and the senior officials of the Commission, with whom we have worked and negotiated, for the openness and flexibility they have shown.
The Spanish Presidency of the Council also made every effort to ensure that our party's desire to reach an agreement at first reading became a reality.

This thanks is, of course, extendable to the Members of the other political groups, as well as to the excellent staff of the Secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture of this Parliament, whose collaboration allowed us to reach a result that I consider very positive.

I would also like to emphasize the decisive contribution played by the Agricultural Federation of the Azores and the regional and national governments in their involvement and commitment to finding a solution for Azores sugar.

The presentation of the proposed Council regulation on October 2 in the Committee on Agriculture came at a time when there were no prospects for the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, which was still awaiting ratification by all member states.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal would be approved in a simplified process, without any changes, to take effect from January 1, 2010.

with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and, despite, at that time, the opinion being dominated by other political groups, as well as the Council and the Commission, for the proposal to remain in a simplified process, because they believed that

The proposal did not need any changes and should have come into force quickly, but despite this prevailing opinion, I and the Socialist and Democrat Group understood that Parliament should have already voiced its opinion under the Lisbon Treaty, assuming its role as co-legislator.

We did so at the right time, because from then on new possibilities opened up, first with the contribution of the Committee on Regional Development and the partnership of my colleague Nunta Sheira, whom I would also like to thank for his help.

I would like to congratulate and thank you for the cooperation always provided throughout this process and, later, with my report, introducing the new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as for the contribution and support of the colleagues from the Committee on Agriculture.

I would like to say finally, in this first speech, that regarding the amendments proposed by the REGI Committee and voted on in the AGRI Committee and which I supported, we were unable to secure their acceptance of the compromise reached in the triangle.

It was essential to obtain a commitment at first reading, thus safeguarding the improvements already achieved and the need for entry into force, in order not to compromise its retroactivity since January of this year.
However, since the Commission is already preparing a document to review POSEI, we will certainly have the opportunity to debate it again soon.

Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, we are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political and social systems, and therefore for all our citizens.
Today we have witnessed an unprecedented weakening of the response capacity of states.
The European Union must therefore identify common and allied causes and act clearly and united on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations require lucidity in joint action.

If we do not take the necessary measures of rigor and collective accountability, Europe will be doomed to marginalization and impoverishment, and only a strong Europe, respectful of its common rules, will be able to adequately respond to the new times.
Weak and indebted states do not have the capacity to protect their citizens.
Therefore, we need to be able to restore citizens' confidence, to win the battles of stability, budgetary discipline, job creation, monetary union stability, globalization, and strategic choices.
This is at the risk of our future being compromised.
And we win the future by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, building a new model based on values of freedom, social justice, and responsibility.
Thus, the 2020 Strategy and the Integrated Guidelines Europe 2020 are essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For proper implementation and achievement, it is necessary to define quantifiable and clear objectives in employment, education, and poverty reduction.

It is also crucial for the success of the strategy that everything is done to facilitate the transposition by the Member States of their national objectives and to ensure the correct implementation of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the economic and monetary union completed ten years, the Commission considered the euro the most successful project of the Union.
Today we would find it difficult to affirm this without limitations, because the crisis has shown the evidence that economic and monetary union is an unfinished project.
Minimal rescue measures were taken in an emergency climate, but let us not be mistaken: the conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the main players
The member countries, the painful nature of the decisions, and their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union in the eyes of citizens and the world.
We must face the facts.
The European Union and the euro are a process of integration, not mere cooperation between countries.
It is an unfinished project that, at this moment, either strengthens itself or runs a very serious risk of disappearing.
There are three issues that need to be addressed first: it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this emergency climate, and a monetary fund must be created.
The European euro requires progress with Eurobonds, progress with the European supervisory and regulatory architecture, and progress with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
It is important to realize that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak; the 1% growth predicted for the European Union is unsustainable in terms of income.
either in terms of its demographic composition or in terms of combating unemployment. The 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a set of good ideas that lack the means to be implemented.

Third dimension, Commissioner Lehne, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences between the member states that make up the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revisited. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr President. Several colleagues here from the EPP have already painted a very complete picture of the situation.
I believe that it is now necessary to demand and make a reference to the role of nation states.
In fact, national governments also have a role to play here in imposing requirements on their states.
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and for this project of monetary and economic integration to be carried forward.
And here I would like to say that our party, the party linked to the EPP, which is the PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government in the austerity measures, because we believe

The mistakes that the socialist government has made in Portugal over these 15 years, which are unfortunately visible to everyone today, need to be corrected and will have the support of the PSD to be corrected.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government and it is a good example for other analogous cases, because it is not reducing spending and what is crucial is not just

It is not about raising taxes to reduce the deficit, but about reducing spending, it is about demanding that the government has the courage to take measures that reduce spending, that alleviate the deficit, that alleviate the public debt.
This applies to Portugal and to other states that are today in a difficult situation, and we, as European parliamentarians, have the responsibility to also do so in our own countries.
An apology for the measures necessary for the euro to emerge strengthened and for this space of integration and this dream, which is a dream of the EPP and a dream of all of us, to become a reality.
That is why we criticize those governments that do not have the courage to take the necessary measures in their states.

I would like to begin by saying that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2006 roadmap for equality between men and women, which aims to influence future strategies on this matter, could, in our opinion, have been more decisive and less controversial.

In fact, the way to approach various ethically sensitive issues, particularly the issue of women's sexual and reproductive health, should have been different if the goal was truly to achieve the greatest possible consensus.

That being said, I would like to emphasize that, in times of normal economic growth, concern for women's rights, particularly regarding the disparity between the situation of men and women in the workplace, in society, and in the family, is great, but these problems are profoundly exacerbated by economic and social crises like the one we are experiencing.
Hence the need for a reinforced strategic commitment from the member states, at the level of local and regional authorities and Community institutions, with regard to the protection of human rights.

We must say that, in line with what President Daul and colleague Werner Langen said, it is essential that there is an economic government of the Union, but that this economic government is centered in the Commission.
This is the first point I wanted to emphasize, and having said that, I would like to say that we should not only, as we do every morning, focus our debate on immediate issues, but
Also in those that are in the 2020 Strategy and I would emphasize, in particular, the issue of education and training of the young, the issue of innovation, research and development.

Because these are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, unfortunately, the European educational model has failed, and failed when compared to the model of emerging countries.

Like India, like China, like Brazil, it is now a less demanding and less rigorous model, and therefore it is also requested that in the boldness of this idea of innovation, development, research and education, there be rigor and demand within the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and demand will we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot just think about the crisis of this year or the next two or three years, we have to think about the strategy for Europe in the next ten to twenty years and it depends on a rigorous and demanding educational system.
Mr President, Commissioner, never before has the European project, built with so much effort over the last 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is enormous: the financial system that was supposed to serve them destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, in short, their future.
As for the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market, including banks, insurance, and securities, the path forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing today.
We do indeed need a strong European supervisory architecture, covering all products and actors, equipped with methodologies and instruments.
effective interventions and capable of responding to the reality of a market that, especially in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and spreads to the real economy.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms in place to limit contagion, especially with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the deposit of citizens' savings.

It is precisely in the powers and competences of the banking authority that the capacity to implement a new strategy for managing cross-border crises in the banking sector lies, a topic to which my report refers.
It is not in our hands to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is carried out in a
in an orderly manner, limiting the side effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from having to pay for the costs of the crises they generate.

A set of new devices is needed for this. It is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments and terminology common to all parties involved in restructuring, reorganization or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, particularly bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to assign supervisors with extended powers of intervention.
It is necessary to establish clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow for the initiation of interventions in an institution in difficulty.
Contingency plans need to be prepared.
This whole process, for 27 member states, takes time.
And yet, about 50 banks out of the 12 that operate in Europe account for 70 percent of the assets.
Now, this means a huge concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene on them as a priority.

There are therefore conditions in place to propose a special and urgent process for banks to meet, which, being cross-border due to their size, have relationships with other banks that could have a systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European banking authority, although operating within the College of National Supervisors.
It is possible and urgent that they, due to the risk they generate, start making contributions to a fund that finances potential interventions.
that are necessary and it is important that the banking authority creates a specialized unit that coordinates interventions in case of difficulties in these banks.
Overall, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational banks of a systemic nature are consistent and coordinated among the
different countries and, above all, that a principle so dear to Europe is upheld, that the costs of pollution caused by these banks are borne by the polluter themselves.
This proposal fits perfectly with what we are discussing, especially regarding the powers of the banking authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Committee, there was a very large majority in support of this proposal, 87 of the votes.
We also have here in the plenary a massive vote from this institution to the effect that, by massively supporting this proposal, which is visionary, which is realistic, but which is pragmatic, we
Let us take action that is urgent and necessary to rekindle the hope of Europeans in Europe, in its financial system and, in particular, in the banking system. Thank you very much.
-Thank you very much. - Breton, to underline only four points,
The first one is that it was an extraordinary experience to work in such a supportive way with my colleagues from other political parties.
Thank you very much for including me in the supervision package and, in particular, thank you Mr. Garcia Margalho for all the collaboration that was possible to obtain.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems on the planet and, each year, we lose 13 million hectares of forest, thus contributing to 20% of the globe's carbon emissions and posing a huge threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable and, as such, it is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events, floods, and even the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Forest loss puts all of humanity at risk, but this risk and impact is not shared equally among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those that depend most on the forest and nature to survive are the most affected.
Deforestation concerns our coactive existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and indigenous communities, and social justice.
The main cause of deforestation is illegal logging, which accounts for 20 to 40 percent of the world's industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also talking about the transfer of wealth from the producing countries to the consuming countries in the same way.
This illegal practice endangers the sustainable exploitation of timber and the companies that do it.
Pretty words are not enough.
This Parliament must adopt strong and consistent measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in that direction by defining the prohibition of the timber trade.
Good intentions are not enough either.
Effective means are necessary, particularly sanctions, which in this case could be of three types.

First, fines that actually remove the economic benefit of the illegal practice, increased for repeat offenders; second, the confiscation of the wood and the products in question; and third, the immediate suspension of the authorization to carry out a commercial activity.

And this is because those who exploit or market a natural resource must be socially responsible, and this is also because those who place wood or wood products in the European Union for the first time must be required to take due diligence to ensure that the wood is legally exploited.
That is why all subsequent operators must provide basic information about this wood, including its origin and destination.
The population must also have the right - and this is where I conclude, Mr President - to have access to information about who complies and who does not. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Europe needs to renew trust and hope.

Cutting structural funds today, as the Commission proposes, the funds that were created to stimulate convergence in diverging economies, seems to be putting firefighters to the task of fanning a fire that has not yet been extinguished.
We clearly need architects.
One final question: I would like to know the external dimension of the European Union's action, in particular, to learn a bit more about what the Belgian Presidency proposes for Cancún and Doha.

Agricultural policies are increasingly market-oriented, farmers in Europe are facing very low income levels, and millions of consumers, as a result of the crisis that affects everyone, are in the primary need of keeping food at affordable prices.

That is why, if farmers' incomes are to become increasingly dependent on the values generated in the markets and the price of food on their proper functioning, then improving the functioning of the food supply chain is essential.
it becomes absolutely necessary for a more equitable sharing of the value generated, from agricultural producers to final consumers, ensuring fair incomes for some and appropriate prices for others.

To achieve this, it is necessary to rebalance the relationships established throughout the food supply chain, make them transparent, and ensure the existence of a framework of fair and competitive best practices.
In this sense, we support the Commission in taking into account the widely supported proposals in the Committee on Agriculture.
A few days ago, in Aroca, Portugal, all the female workers at a footwear company were fired with a simple text message, without further explanation.

It goes against all European norms and violates any sense of common sense, respect, and dignity.
Since the crisis began, Europe has 8 million new unemployed people, bringing the total to 25 million. How many have been fired in such a disgraceful way?
I would say more and more, unfortunately.
The European Union says it has a long tradition of safeguarding workers' rights.
However, the current de-icing has not been effective.
So what additional measures will the Commission take?
That is why this issue is so relevant.
There is no justification for dismissals like that of Arroca.

The environmental catastrophe under discussion today, although occurring outside the geographical space of the Union, concerns all of us, European citizens.

The notion of sustainable development that we believe in is a concept that knows no administrative boundaries, no religious beliefs, and that looks at the planet as a whole and not as the sum of its parts.
The Jordan River is therefore a problem for all of humanity, not just the populations or communities directly affected by the scarcity or poor quality of its water.
"Think globally, act locally" is a common-sense approach.
That is what we are here to do today, to think globally.
As the European Union, we must help to act locally in order to minimize and reverse this ongoing degradation of the flow and quality of the Jordan River's waters.
And in order to act or help to act, the Union already has the legislative framework, institutional structure and instruments at its disposal.
I refer to the Union for the Mediterranean, its secretariat and the FEIMIP, managed by the European Investment Bank.
This is, of course, a topic that the delegation of this Parliament, which I chair, and its relationship with the Mashreq countries, will follow closely.

It is obvious that the action leading to the resolution of this environmental tragedy should, first and foremost, be undertaken by the states and local authorities whose populations benefit directly from it.
In this context, I would like to highlight two ideas present in the resolution.
First, the creation of a commission for the management of the entire Jordan River basin, composed of representatives of the states or authorities that use those waters.
And here Europe can help, sharing, for example, the experience of the International Commission for the Protection of the Rhine River.
Secondly, support and dissemination of good practices with regard to joint community projects involving Jordanian, Israeli and Palestinian citizens.

In particular, those promoted by Friends of the Earth Middle East, which Rossi's colleague has now invoked, regarding the efficient and proper management of water resources in the Jordan Valley Basin.
Finally, Mr. President, and on an even broader scale, it is important to highlight the example of cooperation and peaceful coexistence that this endeavor represents.

Madam President, we have discussed here today yet another situation of human rights violation, that of the imprisonment of Syrian activist Aytan al Maleh, an 80-year-old lawyer, accused of allegedly spreading false and exaggerated news that weakens the national feelings of his country.

In addition to the violation of numerous international treaties and conventions, the imprisonment of this human rights defender is also contrary to the country's own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction to try civilians.

The decision that was made regarding this man and regarding other Syrian prisoners detained for similar reasons, the various detentions, the restrictions on freedom of movement and the arbitrary measures taken

The measures taken by the Syrian authorities are practices that contradict Syria's important role throughout the region and do not reflect the efforts that have been made in this country to improve the social situation.
I repeat, today we are discussing yet another situation of human rights violation.
It is impossible to separate it from the various discussions we have had here this week.
I highlight two: first, the rejection of the death sentence by stoning imposed on Sakineh Hashtani
Many voices have come together and there have already been some results.

It is not yet time to sing of victories, but it is even less time to remain silent. Secondly, today we have approved an important resolution against the abuses imposed by the Sarkozy government on Romanian and Bulgarian citizens.
The defense of human rights knows no borders and is not a fight that can only be waged out there.
Today we give a good example of how to stop it even indoors.
The unjustified imprisonment of Aitane al Male has united us all here today.
She is a human rights defender.
Human rights defenders must be free people, and that is what we demand from the Syrian authorities.
We, also human rights defenders, will not leave you alone, thank you very much.

Mr President, the fact that there is a growing trend for the safety profile of new medicines to only become fully known after they enter the market necessitates a more effective pharmacovigilance system than has been in place up to now.
We are dealing with a typical risk management problem, but at a macro and supranational level, we have made it more relevant to citizens now.
New medications have played a crucial role in public health and advances in healthcare over the past few decades.
Adverse reactions caused by medications continue to be, however, the fifth cause of hospital death.
The proposals presented reinforce the contribution of medicines to modern public health through a community pharmacovigilance system, improving coordination and transparency.
Its objective is the monitoring, early detection, communication and evaluation of adverse reactions.
The new medications will have a graphic symbol indicating that they are still under scrutiny.

User participation in control is encouraged, national-level effectiveness studies are stimulated, a new sensitivity to environmental consequences is opened up, and community control institutions are improved.
That is why I welcome the proposals, Mr President.
I congratulate the rapporteur and also the Commission on their spirit of cooperation, as well as the Spanish Presidency.
That is why, with the proposals presented in this legislative package, I welcome the final document that will be voted on tomorrow.
Mr President, I would first of all like to thank and congratulate the rapporteur, as well as all the colleagues who were involved in this process.
We know that adverse drug effects are the fifth leading cause of hospital death, and it can never be repeated too often, and a strong and transparent drug surveillance system is essential.
We now have the opportunity to enhance the safety of medicines that are already available, going beyond laboratory tests, which do not always anticipate problems.

If concrete examples were needed to justify the importance of a new system, just look at what happened with the H1N1 flu vaccine: the speed with which the vaccine was placed on the market and the negligence in investigating the side effects that were detected, which still delay a complete investigation.
That is why it is necessary for us to continue to deepen this path.
This directive ensures the more active involvement of health professionals and patients in identifying difficulties.
In fact, cooperation between countries and the Union can be a positive-sum game.
Mr President, Commissioner, a Europe without economic, social and territorial cohesion is not a Union.
Mountainous regions, islands and areas with low population density have their own very difficult challenges that need to be overcome in the name of a Europe of the peoples.
But we must go beyond declarations of intent, otherwise we get the opposite effect, namely, we reinforce inequalities.
These regions are enormous reservoirs of important resources.
Biodiversity, forests, wetlands, and green areas provide an essential service to everyone, yet they suffer from the resulting limitations on their economy.
what to return.
The populations of these regions must be supported by all in a spirit of solidarity.
You give two proposals.
First, the potential contribution to science and development.
Many of these regions are authentic outdoor laboratories, given their wealth, but they do not have equal access to resources for research.
Why not, then, equip them with research centers of excellence, generating quality jobs and boosting their economies?
A second proposal is related to energy.
These regions can and should be the embryos of projects that demonstrate the potential of self-sufficiency and energy sustainability, particularly through the microgeneration of local sources.
It reduced that dependence, increased that equality and job creation.
Finally, I want to point out that using GDP as the sole or primary indicator for allocating aid funds can only result in more injustice.
That is why it is very important to use the supplementary data, particularly those that reflect the social and economic reality of these regions.
I cannot fail to make a special reference here to the people of the Azores, Madeira, the mountainous areas and the depopulated inland areas of Portugal.
Through their efforts, they greatly contribute to the development and quality of life of all Europeans.
These and all regions have their own context.
Social, economic and territorial cohesion should not be seen as a charitable service.
This is where it is decided whether or not we want a genuine European redistribution policy.
For all these reasons, I consider this resolution to be an important, but first step.

Mr President, Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the disparities between the various regions.
However, it is not enough to simply express the objectives to be achieved in the text of the treaties.
There are regions of the Union that have permanent constraints that strongly condition their economic and social development.

It is therefore necessary to implement specific programmes that effectively and genuinely overcome the backwardness of these regions, by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources, and contributing to the achievement of the objectives of the EU 2020 Strategy.
This incentive for these regions should result not only from regional policy measures, through its structural adjustment instruments, such as the Cohesion Fund and the four Structural Funds, but also
Also from a different use of the various sectoral policies, which have a relevant territorial impact in each region and can therefore have a stimulating effect on their economies.
For the determination of European assistance to these regions, it is certain that we should maintain GDP as the main indicator of eligibility.

However, taking into account their natural disadvantages, it becomes pertinent to resort to other measurable criteria, capable of providing a more realistic picture of their level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or education level.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

It recalls, for that matter, the case of the outermost regions, whose status is recognised by the new Treaty and which are a group of regions in the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The outermost regions, united by their particular characteristics, also differ in their levels of development.

Complementary GDP indicators should also be used for these regions, capable of providing a more complete description of their specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.
I welcome this motion for a resolution which calls for the need for a European strategy to make it possible to translate the principle of social cohesion and equal opportunities into reality.

The Territorial Treaty benefits from the Treaty of Lisbon, providing opportunities for the populations of territories that suffer from various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

I come from a region, the Azores, where these constraints accumulate and intensify, as in other regions designated as outermost regions of Europe, under Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union.
Following the Commission's communication, the outermost regions were a triumph for Europe in 2008, and after the extensive debate, in which the ORs themselves participated.
In turn, we are now also awaiting our version of this strategy, which will have to take into account not only our constraints, but above all our potential.
I therefore call on the Commission to be clear in its presentation, so that we can establish the best strategy before the debate on the new perspectives.

financial, because we must first define the content of the policies before allocating the necessary resources for their implementation, as, indeed, has been happening with the Community policies now under review.

Mr President, Mr President, Commissioners, dear colleagues, after four consecutive years of reducing the unemployment rate from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has nullified many of the progress made.
Unemployment rates in the European Union have seen a massive increase, for example in Portugal we have unfortunately reached a record unemployment rate of 11%.
Another negative phenomenon is youth unemployment in the European Union.
Europe is thus going through a period of transformation and is facing enormous challenges.
The crisis has nullified years of economic and social progress and exposed the weaknesses of the economies of its member states and, consequently, of the European Union itself.
The 2020 Strategy outlines the paths to follow.
The European Union must intensify all its efforts to promote employment and social inclusion as an integral part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
Thus, the motion for a resolution on the future of the Social Fund under debate today is to be welcomed, as this Fund plays a crucial role in achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy.

In fact, this fund is the main financial instrument that allows the European Union to achieve the strategic objectives of its employment policy, improving the education and qualification levels of its citizens.
The ESF must be strengthened as the main driver of the 2020 Strategy and must be used by the Member States to invest in job qualification, training and professional reconversion.

Finally, I would like to emphasize that the reform of the European Social Fund, to be carried out in conjunction with that of the other Structural Funds, should facilitate and simplify its management and implementation.
enhance transparency, as well as focus funds on achieving results and implementing objectives that are effectively felt by citizens in their daily lives.
The European Social Fund is probably the most structuring instrument of cohesion.
It must therefore have a strong partnership with the Regional Development Fund.
A global approach to the issues at hand is essential, in other words, a global vision for local action.

Local and regional authorities are the entities most knowledgeable about their realities, their investment needs and job creation, and which measures are most appropriate for promoting employment in their regions.
We must take into account the positive experiences of the regions.
In the Azores, an outermost region where unemployment usually reaches record levels, the unemployment rate is 6.5%, the lowest in Portugal.

This is largely due to the forward-looking planning strategy used for employment, focusing on factors that will drive action, such as achieving the desired goal, and also the use of the European Development Fund as an operational tool for this strategy, acting on education, training, and employment promotion.
The Eurozone wants to support cohesion; it is the only way to ensure strategic stability.
The cohesion policy is the great pillar of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and the harmonious development of the European Union as a whole is encouraged.
In the next period from 2014 to 2020, we must define a framework capable of enhancing the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance at various levels should be encouraged with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and as provided for in the new Lisbon Treaty.
The special situation of the outermost regions must not be forgotten.
This set of regions faces very important challenges and should continue to benefit, in the future, from specific provisions in the application of European policies.
GDP should remain the main eligibility criterion, but we must take into account other indicators that can provide a more complete picture of the regional reality.
aging and with very low birth rates.
These factors represent enormous challenges for the European Union, to which we must provide concrete answers.
This finding has been consensual during this debate among us, despite the different views that this discussion has been highlighting.
In Portugal, for example, the birth rate does not ensure the renewal of generations and reveals a reality that compromises the future.
This situation occurs in my country, as it does in most of the member states of the European Union.
I am confident that more flexible policies regarding maternity leave can help reverse these trends.
We must send families a consistent message of support for motherhood, with concrete measures for better reconciliation of professional, private, and family life.
Women should be protected so that they can choose to have children without having to leave the job market.
Meeting this challenge is essential if we are to achieve the economic and social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and combat demographic ageing.
In Portugal, for example, maternity leave is already paid at 100% for 120 days, in an attempt to counteract the low birth rate we are suffering from.
I therefore argue that women's wages should be guaranteed during maternity leave in the manner presented in the report under discussion.
Allowing each member state to create the conditions that guarantee the objective of full salary payment during maternity leave by 2020 seems like a sensible procedure.
Finally, I commend the rapporteur Edita Estrela for her persistence in advocating for measures aimed at protecting families, while also contributing to counteracting population investment.

Lisbon and the first Framework Agreement, which has a direct basis, an express basis in the treaties, more precisely in Article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

Parliament and the Commission and essentially represents a compromise, a balance between the vision of the two institutions on the new role that each of them has after the Treaty of Lisbon.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur for her work, as well as all those who collaborated with her on this report, which made it possible to reach this agreement at first reading.

This directive, which revises the previous directive that is more than ten years old, aims, as has been acknowledged here by all, to put an end to a widespread problem in the European Union of payment defaults.
These are, in some member states, unnecessarily long when they involve public administration.

The negative effects of this practice on economic life are enormous, both at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises and at the level of the internal market, and these negative effects cannot be tolerated any longer, especially since we are living through an economic and financial crisis like the one we are currently experiencing.
This legislative change provides coherence and gives meaning to the plan to relaunch the European economy and the implementation of the Small Business Act.
business act, surely this directive will improve the liquidity of companies.

Public administration bodies must set a good example and pay invoices for goods and services within the month.
It will now be up to the institutions involved, the Council and the Member States, to allow the transposition of this directive to be carried out as quickly as possible.
Mr President, there is currently a significant disparity in payment terms for companies in many Member States, particularly when the state, SMEs and large companies are involved.

We who come from companies know that, in this situation of economic crisis and acute financing difficulties, companies are increasingly struggling with liquidity problems, and in many Member States they are even exposed to a significant risk of bankruptcy.
It seems clear that the current directive, which attempted to regulate this matter, had limited effects, so the proposal we are now examining represents an important step forward in compliance.
of payment terms, not only in relations between companies and public entities, but also, and this is essential, in the relations that companies establish among themselves.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, allow me to speak of the unspoken.

I listened very carefully, Commissioner, and from what I heard, it seems to me that, up to a certain point, the most effective action, both by national authorities and European authorities, was the management of silence.
Industrial accidents can and should be avoided, and this is also the purpose of European legislation, and it seems obvious that the law was violated.
There was inefficiency, a delayed response, and abandonment of the affected people, particularly the most disadvantaged.
People have died and many are still today under threat of what may happen to their health.
It is impossible to calculate the total costs and it is immoral not to care for the victims.
How is it possible, I ask you, Commissioner, that we learn about news through reports from Hungarian citizens, and the authorities see nothing or tell us nothing?
That is why I would like to ask a few questions.
How can the banking sector pressure citizens with mortgaged homes in the affected area to pay what they owe, when their homes have lost value?
How is it allowed for telephone operators to cut off the only means of contact for those in the disaster zone?
How has the company responsible for this catastrophe already returned to business as usual?
And finally, Commissioner, you spoke about mitigating the effects of the mud spill.
I ask you what the reasons are for continuing to downplay the true extent of this human tragedy.
It's just that it seems like we're always starting from scratch.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all recognise that the control of short-term and long-term macroeconomic variables in the European Union has failed, particularly in terms of budgetary frameworks and accumulated national debt.
The crisis has highlighted the need to strengthen the single market, taking into account the Monte and GRECO proposals.

It is essential to develop electronic and cross-border trade, simplify online payment processes, standardize products and services, and harmonize fiscal instruments in order to build consumer confidence and stimulate the economy.
The Union must emerge from the crisis in a sustainable way, ensuring solid growth and responsible budgets, but also employment objectives.
Indicators such as the unemployment rate and the employment rate of the active population must be included in the monitoring system.
The indicators that will measure the progress of the 2020 Strategy cannot be forgotten either.
The reliability study on the issuance of common European bonds could provide an opportunity to deepen and implement financial instruments for defense against speculation.
We wish we could have gone beyond a simple study.
The creation of a European monetary fund deserves our support and we see it not only as a tool of discipline, but above all as a means of reducing speculative manipulation of sovereign debt markets.
Cooperation with rapporteur Feio was productive and a comprehensive, balanced and rich text was achieved.

We are at a time when trust depends on the Commission and the Council's ability to respond to citizens' real concerns and to manage unemployment, growth, and cohesion.

the granting of tax incentives and even subsidies to SMEs to maintain and create jobs.
the creation of a new Small Business Act with a stronger social dimension.

Mr President, I would like to start by congratulating Commissioner Barnier on presenting this important document.

As you have diagnosed, the impact of the crisis we are experiencing is being felt in all sectors of society and our economy, causing our citizens to feel discouraged and distrustful of the single market.
But it is precisely this single market that is one of the assets Europe has to combat the current crisis.
That is why we warmly welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for single market policies, allowing us to regain confidence in our social market economy model.
In the current situation, the European Union must pay particular attention to its 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises.
In this sense, one of the Union's priorities should be to create mechanisms that address the problem of access to credit for these companies.

We also highlight the Commission's proposal to evaluate the Small Business Act by the end of 2010 in order to facilitate the lives of these companies, particularly in terms of bureaucratic and tax simplification, as well as in the promotion of social responsibility.
We hope that these 50 measures now presented will contribute to deepening the internal market, taking full advantage of it, which could represent additional growth for the European economy.
Mr President, we are here today to discuss what has been presented as one of the European Commission's top priorities, which is innovation policy.
It is finally taking shape, particularly through the European partnerships for innovation and with this pilot project that we are discussing here today on active and healthy ageing.
However, there are many aspects that still need to be defined, particularly in terms of clarification, in terms of defining future projects, and in terms of priorities.
Who, in the end, will define the priorities and based on what criteria?
I think these answers are due to us.
But I would like to leave some notes, concrete and particular, regarding this first project on active and healthy aging, which was the one presented to us.

And these notes are, from the outset, a positive note, because it seems positive to me that the focus is on a sector of the population that is particularly vulnerable, in an increasingly aged and increasingly disadvantaged Europe.

However, I would like to add even more questions to these questions, because it seems contradictory to me that a project in this area is presented, when at the same time, we do not have the means to support this innovation.
How are we going to sustain it?
What is EVA?

Is there any viable innovation in a context like the one we are witnessing, where there is a persistent and systematic attack on the social state, a reduction in access to healthcare, systematic cuts in services provided, and continued disinvestment in this area?
The title of the presentation, "A union of innovation, more jobs, improved lives, better society," is ambitious.

I would even say that I would have no problem in subscribing to it personally, but let's face it, it is contradictory to what has been the practice in the member states, with the courts and with the austerity measures.

I think that only sustainable innovation, if there are rigorous, sustainable and demanding public policies, if it is not a match that goes out, little remains and we have little to respond to these populations. Thank you very much.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the Commission's efforts to place research and innovation at the top of the political agenda.
We are facing an integrated strategy to make the European innovation ecosystem more effective and productive in the service of a sustainable economy.
European partnerships for innovation emerge as an instrument, and the major challenges they address are broad enough not to be the subject of controversy.
However, it is not yet clear how the sub-thematic priorities will be defined and how the preponderance of each discipline within them will be determined.
What degree of transparency is to be expected for stakeholders to participate? How to arbitrate conflicting interests?
What is the relative role of the Commission, the Member States and the regions?
How to ensure accountability within a complex structure?
What financial dimension will these partnerships have?
The Commission and the Council, Mr President, must ensure excellence in implementation, which is not guaranteed with the few months of pilot testing planned for the first partnership.

The International Trade Commission is currently reviewing the global agreement on bananas reached within the World Trade Organization, and soon the plenary of this House will be called upon to decide on the reduction of customs duties due to the import of bananas from Latin American countries.

Let it be perfectly clear that none of the outermost regions, whether the wood from which they originate or any of the other eight, especially the Canary Islands, which are by far the most affected, are against the celebration of this type of agreement.
What these regions aim for, and only for, is that, on the one hand, the same phytosanitary hygiene conditions and respect for human rights be demanded of others.
workers that are required of them to access the market, which is a matter of elementary justice, and on the other hand that these are compensated to the exact extent of the harm caused to them.

Or, if that is not the case, at least have the decency to tell them outright that they will have to change their lives and seek another occupation, because it is certain that under the conditions that are expected in the future, they will not be able to survive and will have to abandon their activity.
It is certain that in these agreements there are winners and losers, so let us take care of the losers, because the winners do not need it.
We are here to discuss a very important program
concrete to help economic recovery and, in this case, in the central domain, which is the energy domain.
In the current context, given the crisis we are experiencing, it is essential that there are proposals like this one that help create jobs.
There is no possibility of economic recovery if we do not prioritize job creation.
And this report gives a very positive signal when it draws our attention to how to respond to this level in the local plan and domain, responding concretely to local needs.
We are in a period in which we have debated and will debate much more a set of legislative proposals in the field of energy and often we tend to
We focus too much on large projects, on large networks, and forget other areas of intervention where it is absolutely crucial to act.

That is why I think this report can help us invest not only in energy efficiency and renewable energy, which is very important, but also bring concrete benefits to local populations, which naturally translates into concrete benefits for the European population as a whole.
That is why I want to conclude, Mr President, with two final points. It is important not to forget that energy efficiency is also achieved through energy reduction and projects.

micro-generation, as presented here, and the final point that it was a major achievement of this Parliament to ensure that there was a concrete definition of the amount of funding to be applied to these projects.
It is not what we aspired to, we needed much more, and so I ask the Commissioner what he is trying to do and what he intends to do to ensure these needs are met.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Dalli, the patient must have the right to know as much as possible about their illness and which medicines are available to treat it.
But how to distinguish information from advertising?
Where and how to gather objective and unbiased information?
There are different interpretations of the texts in force, it is necessary to harmonize them, striving to reinforce the sovereignty of the citizen.
The information must be reliable, validated by authorities, independent, accessible, and targeted at an average, non-specialist audience.
The aim is to create a more informed and responsible citizenship on the part of the end user.
The deadline given to the European Agency for tacit approval should be extended from 60 to 120 days.
The requirement for substantiation of interference reinforces the adversarial nature and balances the final outcome.
EMEIA plays a crucial role as a privileged source of objective information

I would like to conclude by commending the rapporteur, Mr Fiedler, for the work he has done and expressing my satisfaction that he has taken up almost all the proposals I put forward in the Committee on the Internal Market as the partner rapporteur.

Commissioner, dear colleagues, bee mortality is increasing and the number of beekeepers is decreasing. This is a problematic situation for agriculture and biodiversity, as has been mentioned here, given the enormous implications for food production and plant species that depend on their pollination.
The life of a worker bee is very short, about six weeks, and it is very sensitive to the attractions of the outside world.

Therefore, honey production has also been affected, not only by the increasingly uncertain duration and stability of the seasons, but also by the increase in external aggressions that can result from the use of pesticides, mites, or other species.

nature and on which the highest level of investigation could contribute to obtaining better applied responses and more accurate reinforcement of measures in favor of biodiversity and the reduction of the effects of climate instability.
The current programmes, Commissioner, must undoubtedly be strengthened within the framework of the new CAP, so that we can also achieve a more effective level of response at this level.
Mr President, let us make it clear: the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt did not work and does not work. The price of Greek debt has not fallen, Ireland is in crisis.
