The economic meltdown and contagion were not contained. The process that was created was created too late, is intergovernmental, and should have existed in another format from the beginning of the euro's creation.
The President of the Commission is now proposing a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments proposed for use, there is a suggestion of private sector involvement.
We had already heard this proposal from Chancellor Merkel, and it was as a result of this premature and inopportune announcement that the markets went into overdrive.
Parliament will use its powers to the full, with the greatest responsibility and in a spirit of cooperation, in the codecision process that accompanies the package
legislative on economic governance, but it will not do so by sacrificing haste, speed, and putting quality in second place.

Therefore, let us be clear, Parliament will participate actively, but such a serious matter as the solution to sovereign debt cannot be decided on the margins and without the knowledge of European citizens and their representatives. The two elements go together.
Finally, we Europeans need a clear European vision at this time of crisis.
A European mechanism for consolidating sovereign debt is needed, eurobonds must be issued, and the eurozone must be sustainably protected through European systems, not intergovernmental ones.
We need to strengthen the European budget; we cannot continue with 1% of the European budget level, and we need to place growth and real convergence at the center of European political priorities.
And this agenda that the Commission and the new president must defend
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, I naturally wanted to say that the EPP's position is clear, it is a position to the effect that the Commission cannot do anything.
The resolution of this serious crisis that Europe and the European Union are experiencing can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the Community method.

For us, there is no doubt whatsoever that only with more Community method, only with economic governance, only with the appropriate instruments of a true single currency in the eurozone area, is it possible to confront and tackle this crisis.
But this means that each of the institutions, the Council, the Commission and Parliament, take responsibility before the Europeans.
And it must be said that it is clear here that at least the largest groups in the European Parliament are willing to cooperate in a clear way in order to increase
the Community method of introducing economic governance, of giving the single currency the necessary conditions for it to triumph in the face of the European crisis.

And it is also evident today that the same applies to the Commission and the President of the Commission, who, contrary to what the socialists and Elisa Ferreira say, have demonstrated that they are neither an emanation of the Council nor an emanation of Parliament, but an emanation of the European interest.
It now falls to the Council, in December, to assume its responsibilities.
That is what we are counting on, and on your clear commitment to the European ideal, President Van der Rohe.
Mr President, I would like to start by congratulating my colleagues Luan and Manescu on the remarkable work they have done on their respective reports.
both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion on the new cohesion policy for Horizon 2020
Today, more than ever, the achievement of economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for asserting the European Union's competitiveness on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by strengthening and developing the regional dimension can we have a cohesive Europe internally and competitive externally.

In this regard, I would highlight three points that I consider crucial: first, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, participate more and contribute to better implementation of cohesion policy.

calls on the Member States to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of the Structural Funds on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives, and finally to strengthen the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management and implementation of programmes.
Only in this way, with the greater involvement of these authorities throughout the process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect I consider crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of funds.
The underlying concern of the Lisbon Treaty was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us then not only do this, but also make your life easier by avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that deter your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to achieve the goal of true territorial cohesion.
Only in this way will we see the disparities within the European Union reduced, which are currently markedly contrasting and with a huge gap between rich and poor regions.
More participation also means more responsibility, and it is this responsibility that must be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better in order to have a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleagues Edith Bauer and Anne Heth on the excellent work they have done on this report.
Human trafficking dishonors our society and requires a strong and coordinated response from everyone.
The organized crime behind sex exploitation, forced labor, human organ harvesting trade and other ignoble practices must be effectively combated, but it must primarily be prevented.
What is at stake is the defense of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable people, particularly women and children.
Experience has shown that the legal framework in place was not sufficiently effective and that the European Union needs to make more of an effort.
Greater cross-border cooperation is essential, including effective sharing of information and best practices.
This proposal rightly highlights a victim-centered approach.
Policies in this area should cover aspects related to social issues and social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim. Thank you very much.
The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, and therefore allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country regarding this Summit.
At that time, the Portuguese authorities banned European citizens from entering the country, and the only reason those citizens were carrying critical texts about the alliance was...
In those days, the least we can say is that there was an arbitrary regime in Portugal, a genuine thought police.
Such a special regime that led the Portuguese Government to purchase anti-mutiny equipment worth 5 million euros, which did not even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are, after all, the priorities of a government facing a huge social crisis.
In the Europe we dream of, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not bow down to military organizations that write their history in blood.
From the NATO summit came the legitimization of its military intervention across the entire planet.
The European Union's subordination to the military strategy and interests of the United States also emerged.
Thirdly, the militarization of access to energy sources was consolidated.
Finally, military defense was established for a development model that generates environmental imbalances and exacerbates the social crisis.
So I want to say, Madam President, that in my view, with this summit we have lost in democracy, we have lost in freedom, and we have lost so that some can profit from the war.
Madam President, the first point I wanted to make clear and which is important to reinforce in this Parliament is that the Commission cannot simply be a speaker.
Contrary to what one sometimes reads in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been crucial in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in a difficult situation, with the currencies of the more fragile countries greatly devalued and with a possible German mark that would be overvalued, making it impossible to sustain the German economy and the European economy.

And that is why the euro has been a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries that are in the euro zone, but also for the currencies of the countries that did not want to join the euro zone.

And for that very reason, because we have to defend this community that has managed to respond to the crisis better than most, and as we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro actually has advantages.

We now have the responsibility in this Council to do everything to defend the euro, particularly to create a stabilization fund that follows the Community method and is capable of introducing responsibility into the

countries that are in a more fragile situation, solidarity with those who have fulfilled their obligations and who have not always shown themselves, at least in their external statements, to be willing to be supportive in the context of zone E.

I want to extend my sincere congratulations to my colleague Sorbou for the excellence of the report produced, and I strongly advise the Commission to take it into account, especially in those aspects where the complex dimension of agricultural issues, which far exceed the strict scope of agriculture, is very important.

agriculture, require the involvement of other areas, such as competition, internal market and financial regulation, as well as others that also require their treatment in other extra-Community forums, such as the G20 or the WTO.

The absolutely crucial issues for agriculture, for farmers, and for the availability of sufficient quantity and quality of food for the populations of Europe and the world can only be effectively addressed if they are tackled in all these dimensions.

The ambitious objectives of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform goes beyond the strict boundaries of agriculture and its objectives are also taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other bodies of a global nature.
This report leaves me perplexed and I mourn for that.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking everyone for their kind words regarding the report that Parliament is presenting on Alzheimer's and other dementias.
We all know that the situation we are experiencing is substantially dramatic and that it is still very underdiagnosed, as has been mentioned here.
And I just want to mention an issue that was common to all the speeches, but probably not as emphasized, which is the issue of patients' dignity and their rights.
and not only of the patients, but also of their families and those who care for them, whether formal or informal caregivers, and of the professionals who are associated with this type of disease.

I am pleased, genuinely pleased, with the Commissioner's words, when he says that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission views all the recommendations in the report presented by Parliament in a very positive light, and that it will do everything in its power to implement them.
We know that each passing day is later than the previous one in this matter, given the urgency of what we have on our hands.
And therefore, we also know that tomorrow Parliament will pronounce itself on this matter.
We will wait for the result of the vote, but we know, Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

We are expected to take concrete and appropriate action, and I hope, Commissioner, that you will implement it, and that the Commission, which has the initiative and which, unfortunately, this Parliament does not have, will implement it.

All this priority given to this domain and transforming it into legislative initiative so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with the equality and dignity they deserve.

First of all, I would like to say that this Parliament, on a day when we are discussing the Hungarian Presidency, should focus on the problems of the European Union, without prejudice to being able to deal with all the topics it wants to, which it is not doing here.
In order to focus on the problems of the European Union, you should carefully read and discuss whether or not you agree with the priorities of the Hungarian Presidency, rather than discussing points.

or aspects that are aspects of Hungary's internal life and that, at most, can be regulated in a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission and the Hungarian Government and Parliament.
I therefore wanted to say here that, beyond the priority that the Hungarian Presidency will naturally give to the economic and financial issues on the agenda, I am very pleased that it is
Hungary's agenda for this semester is very lucid and very ambitious, as it focuses and prioritizes three issues that will be essential for the future of Europe.

food, which is about to enter a serious global crisis, energy, which is essential for our security and for our economic sustainability, and water, which has been little discussed, but which will be the next challenge for Europeans, along with food.
I hope you achieve your goals.

Madam President, I think that these two countries, like others in this region, show us how, in recent years, European leaders have often been more on the side of business than of democracy, more on the side of dictators than of the poor.
I am frankly concerned about the current situation in Egypt and today's developments, which is why I believe that what we should have is not calm, but solidarity.
Solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens in Cairo and throughout the country, fed up with hunger, fed up with oppression, fed up with unemployment.

And that is why, after today, after Mubarak's speech, after the regime's dogs have been unleashed, after a clear and open path to violence has been created, we must say that we must stand by these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created so that they return home.
36 years ago, in Portugal, we would have gone back home if we had listened to that advice.
It's a good thing we didn't go back, because that's when we had a democratic revolution.
Mr President, Commissioner, I would also like to say that I think this issue is too important for us to continue living in the deception we have experienced in Europe.
The deception is a false promise, as you may call it, because we have been operating, above all, in terms of collecting terminal cells from umbilical cords, from databases that are misleading.
And we know, and it has already been mentioned, that in Europe the collection of stem cells through the umbilical cord is insufficient to meet the demand.

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for treating diseases can be inexhaustible. Diseases such as those already mentioned, such as cancer, Alzheimer's disease, rare diseases, have immense possibilities.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a set of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children's cells and, from then on, at the time of birth, and from then on, cure them in the future if necessary.
I think we should be more responsible than that, because the probability of ensuring that this happens is very low, as we know.
And this false promise, which is sold to parents, costs money.
In Portugal, for example, this false promise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly involves creating public banks, terminal seats, because only with public banks can we guarantee equal use, equal access.
effective medical treatment and more research that is equal for all and not just using stem cells as a commodity or a business that is growing, but that is only for a few.
That's why I think solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not, after all, things that can be classified as an additional requirement.
We do not have the power to impose, we have the power to promote.
This is within our powers, I think we should do it in the name of equality, thank you very much.
Mr. President, the price of food has reached an all-time high and is increasing for the seventh consecutive time.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, the first of which is a short-term factor.
It has to do with the coincidence of poor weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina.
But there are two factors that are structural, they are of a structuring nature, and that is why I am bringing up these two factors here.
The first has to do with the fact that some producers and consumers of food who were exporters have become importers, as is the case with China.
The second has to do with the fact that the weight of some large multinational companies can cause prices to be judged in their favor.
And the example of cereals is that this very clear level is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation therefore puts farmers in a state of great uncertainty about food prices.
Europe must therefore return to what it stopped doing some time ago, namely protecting its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone resorts to forms of protection and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
(SAMANTA) I will explain to fellow rapporteur Marisa Matias and I salute all those who collaborated with her.
Unfortunately, over the past few years, we have witnessed an increase in the falsification of medicines in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that poses a serious threat to European patients and the European industry.
The aim of this directive is to prevent the introduction of counterfeit medicines into the supply chain and thus protect public health.

I would like to highlight in the partnership that I have developed the following key points: the introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, clearly emphasizing consumer protection, the application of devices

Ensuring the security of prescription medicines, holding all parties involved in the distribution chain accountable, and finally, the application by member states of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
Mr President, I obviously want to thank all the comments that have been made by all my fellow Members.
I won't comment on zoom 1, that's not the intention.
I think that if there were any doubts about what the word commitment means, it has become very clear here what commitment means.

We don't all have the perfect proposal, but much more important than knowing if it's the perfect proposal is knowing that we have a tool in our hands that will allow us to no longer delay the protection of patients' health.
And we have the obligation not to delay its adaptation either, we have the obligation not to delay real action, and we can only do this together.
I must also say personally, and the Commissioner mentioned the issue of inspections, that in my initial proposal, I submitted an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
Compromise is just that, and yet, you gain in some things, you lose in others.
We were told by the Commission that this would be impossible to achieve.
I also want to leave another note regarding this commitment.
I think we all recognize the commitment, but I also think and am aware that we will all be demanding in order for it to be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

This agreement includes safeguards that allow us to monitor the process, evaluate it, and systematically obtain information that enables us to verify whether it is being implemented or not, properly or not, and whether changes are needed.

I therefore want to end by thanking the European Commission for its cooperation and, in particular, the Spanish Presidency and the Belgian Presidency, with whom we have worked together over the past six months.
There are no perfect proposals, there are no perfect interventions, there are flaws, but I think we have a strong and robust commitment that allows us to fight and defend patient health.
And since my speech was also full of flaws, I failed to thank my colleagues Regina Bastos and Amália Sartori, from the partners of the other committees.
Thank you very much for your support too.
Mr President, Commissioner, it is not worth repeating that the current moment is the most serious test of the euro's survival and, therefore, of Europe's.
The Polimata report opens up constructive solutions and, for that reason, I also want to congratulate our colleague on the ideas she presents.

The gravity of the moment does not stem from the fact that the eurozone as a whole has an excessive deficit or external debt, but rather from the fact that the economies that compose it diverge persistently and seriously under the impact of the common policy.
We lack instruments that would allow for convergence between these economies, that would allow Europe to regain balance, that would allow Europe to grow.

Let us be clear: the eurozone and the European Union cannot survive with the current degree of integration and the diversity of the economies that make it up, with a budget of 1% of the collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to build was the austerity recipe, and it is the workers and businesses who are paying for it today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, the rescue of which has committed 26% of the wealth of the European Union.
The financial transaction tax, levied at a very low rate, for example, 0.05% on highly speculative high-risk product transactions, is indeed to be paid by their consumers.
But why shouldn't they pay if ordinary citizens pay VAT on bread, on milk and on the most basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed in a way that harms workers and businesses less and is shared more evenly across the financial sectors, particularly speculative ones.
And, Commissioner, I think it is not up to the Commission, at this moment, to refuse or shy away from the clear message that this Parliament is politically giving you.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the tax on financial transactions; on the contrary, it must be analyzed with the highest priority.
(FELIPE) We know well what happened with the flu A and this should serve as a lesson to all.
I don't know if you remember well how all of this began, but the truth is that it started in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the size of the problem.
That is why the report that was voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that what was done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the whole story unfolded, and who decided that it should happen this way.
As we have the right to know which countries responded in a certain way, why did they respond without transparency and without allowing us to stay?
The least doubt, because we maintain all doubts whether there is a deal or not, we have to ensure that no trace remains whether there is a deal related to this flu or not.
That is why I understand, Madam President, that all threats to public health must be addressed, but it is not irrelevant how they are addressed, nor who pays for them.
Mr President, Commissioner, we are talking here about proposals on wages and proposals on retirement age and the least we can say about these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
They are unfair and they insist on recipes that have already been proven more than once to be failed recipes.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy and who knows how many other countries, because this is an endless cycle, are different situations in each of these countries, but there are some commonalities.
One of the things we have in common is an unprecedented transfer of value from labor to financial capital.
We could not accept that.
The other thing we have in common is that those paying for this crisis are the workers and the pensioners and retirees, and it is also being paid for by an entire generation of precarious workers.
You have no guarantees in this society we live in and that is why I would like to end by saying, Mr President and Commissioner, we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I sincerely hope
Thank you, Mr President, I would like to start by saying that I fully support what my colleague said.

The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of enormous importance and of growing importance, and the European Commission systematically presents a number of procedural intentions and a timetable.
But there is a very complicated problem, as has already been mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that typically responds to these situations, but it responds in a very, very long time - nine months to a year - and this is after the catastrophe.
As has also been mentioned, and as we will repeat until it is necessary, in the case of the wood, there was a huge catastrophe a year ago and it still has not received any support.
And I ask this, and I emphasize this question: is it not time for the Commission to review the procedure of the fund itself and the funding model itself?
How can we maintain a contingency fund to deal with situations that are becoming increasingly chronic?
We don't know where it will happen, but we know it will happen and climate change is here to prove it.
Therefore, the exception can never respond to a situation of regularity, thank you very much.
Mr President, the concerns raised here regarding disaster prevention and response are a matter of great sensitivity and utmost importance to our populations, which should not and cannot be exploited.

We are talking about very sensitive situations that affect people's safety and their property, which often touch everyone because of the loss of lives, the destroyed families, and the devastation of entire working lives.

But all our demonstrations are of little use in the face of the dramas that, in a media-driven way, impress and touch us all, if we then fall asleep on the job we must do to prevent those situations, minimize them, or, better yet, help them.
Commissioner, the subject matter here is very well covered by my colleagues.

It is an area where the European Union can better demonstrate its presence among its citizens, helping them in the prevention of catastrophes, especially when they occur, and being by their side at the moments when they are most in need and most vulnerable.
I would gladly respond, although I did not want to turn a debate in the European Parliament into a debate on Portuguese politics.

Incidentally, if Ms. Edita Estrela wants to debate Portuguese politics, she has a simple solution. We should have elections, candidates for the Portuguese Parliament, and the opportunity, in opposition, to debate with the PSD government the policies she wants for Portugal.
I will only say this: we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times over the years.
It is impossible, it is unsustainable, it is not credible for the markets, there are no more solutions for the socialist government.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by congratulating Mr Schwab on the commercial persistence that has led to this important compromise, and I also congratulate all those who have collaborated with him on this report.

We want not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also that European companies, regardless of their size, can provide goods and services to consumers in the 27 Member States without unnecessary legal obstacles.

This new directive will put an end to the legislative fragmentation that has been hindering our companies' participation in the cross-border market and will give an important boost to the internal market.
The new provisions regarding the information to be provided to the consumer stand out, requiring that this information be clear, understandable, and provided in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof regarding compliance with information requirements falls on the merchant.
As for contracts concluded at a distance, especially those concluded by telephone or internet, their rules should be defined and the consumer protected by simple and effective mechanisms.
We are certain that, at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as required in a global economy.

Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, first of all, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on the results of the Council meeting on 24-25 March, particularly on the consolidation of the European Semester.

but much more than that, whether through the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism, or the conclusion, let's say, of the Europolis pact, which already came from the eurozone summit on March 11.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe and it is a shame that this process was not fully completed on 24 March.
I believe that if we had given this signal, if the States had given this signal in the Council, by completely closing this package of Fund reform, we would be in a position today

stronger to face the three, four months and we would have partially mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and about which I also do not want to leave out a word.
to say that, in the case of BPSD fully integrated into the PPE, there is an absolute and total willingness to meet the requirements and obligations of integration into the European space.
This is what we have been doing, even now, at this moment, when there are difficulties regarding short-term financing.
Unlike what the socialist government has been doing, the Social Democratic Party has shown a total willingness to provide the guarantees to Europe that are necessary in the context of this crisis.

And with this, I want to give this signal, without bringing internal politics into the European Parliament, of commitment, commitment, of the Social Democratic Party's total guarantee of the rigorous agenda that the country will have to follow after its elections on June 5.
Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Füle, the historic moment we are living through calls for firm and determined action.
Like many of you, we are watching the events unfolding in the Mediterranean basin with a mix of hope, concern, and anticipation.

I am, however, pleased with the proactive position that Parliament is preparing to adopt with regard to the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy South, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this area, not only as a payer, but also as an engaged partner.
First and foremost, by affirming the absolute necessity of defending our founding values in our relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise in the defense of democracy, nor in the defense of human rights, and even less so in the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the greater interests of citizens and their uncompromising defense, of their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to women's rights.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighborhood policy.
It is imperative that this happens.
Only the greatest involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express a frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not want to take this opportunity to finally differentiate the Eastern neighborhood policy with countries that potentially could become our partners in the Union in the future, from the Southern neighborhood policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process on April 20, the ambition that the current moment demands for a neighborhood policy.
Tailored to each state, with clear benchmarks and careful evaluation that will lead to a future Mediterranean economic area with the new democracies of the south.

In conclusion, Commissioner, we trust that the good atmosphere and cooperation that have characterized the work on this subject will lead to the European Parliament's permanent involvement in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Mr President, the reports we have debated and on which I congratulate the rapporteurs today reinforce a set of initiatives that aim to relaunch the internal market.
I would like to highlight the commitment of the European Commission, in particular Commissioner Barnier, whom I greet, and the positive reception of this Parliament through its
Committee on Consumer Protection and the Internal Market, to give priority to market competitiveness and dynamism, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 Strategy.
Citizens and businesses expect effective measures to get Europe growing economically again, they expect an increase in employment, they aspire to the creation of more prosperity.

As the Commissioner pointed out, opening up markets to our companies, eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will provide a very special boost and an unparalleled opportunity that will allow them to continue their mission as the driving force of our economy.

Measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs and their access to credit and the service market, the European patent, and the recognition of qualifications are essential.
the relevance of developing e-commerce to strengthen consumer and business confidence in this type of commerce, the focus on innovation
important for strong and lasting growth. Social entrepreneurship is indispensable for creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening and making full use of the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, it is important to recommend that member states redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also want to add my voice to all those who have expressed concerns here about the low incomes of fishermen, exacerbated by the historic prices reached by fuel, particularly in recent months.
As has been well stated here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, particularly aggravating the already fragile incomes of fishermen.
This vestigial rise in prices is also bringing us profound negative effects: reduced access to the sea, miserable incomes for fishermen, exacerbated by the low prices paid at the first sale.

increases in imports of aquaculture and fishery products from third countries to the European market and a consequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties with further job losses.
In this context, to prevent the crisis from continuing to worsen, it is necessary to act, and to act quickly and thoroughly on the problems of fishing.

The Commission must therefore provide positive responses, with short- and long-term measures, to address the adversities facing the sector and the serious income losses being experienced by our fishermen.
First of all, I would like to particularly congratulate the work of our PPE colleague, Mário David, who is here today because he is absolutely committed.
I was not able to attend this plenary session and I wanted to say that we have always considered support for the victims of the floods in Pakistan an ethical and moral imperative.
And that is why we strongly support all the measures that have been taken towards traditional humanitarian aid.
We truly believe that work should continue to help stabilize the situation for so many millions of affected people.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy is now considered a suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this brings two disastrous consequences: one consequence within the European Union, especially for the southern countries and their textile and clothing industry, which is now highly weakened by an economic, social, and financial crisis unparalleled since the Second World War.

And secondly, at the global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this openness of the largest trading bloc in the world, which is the European Union, to these potential Pakistani negotiations could completely upset the negotiations.
and it is no coincidence that they find themselves at the impasse they are at.

It is therefore natural that, faced with a situation like this, we had to say something about the history of this regulation and the difficulties it encountered during these eight months of intense negotiations.

We have collaborated on the most constructive proposals, but unfortunately, we must now take a position that will support the amendment, which essentially calls for the end of this proposed regulation as we know it.
We have to do it at this point, not out of any less solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be given in the right place and in the right way.
President, Commissioner, I wanted to start by saying that, naturally, I believe that the agreement that was reached for Portugal is a balanced agreement.
It is a very tough agreement for the populations, but it places its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I swear that this is very positive.

I do not adopt here the attitude of others who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland and Portugal did everything right, made no mistakes, did not exaggerate, did everything right and it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No, our governments made mistakes and had wrong policies, but that does not mean that there is not now an opportunity, within the context of the Union, to have the possibility to get back on the right track and the correct path.

That is why it is important to remember here that, in fact, it is necessary to tell public opinion that is against supporting countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to these countries, they are only lending money to these countries.
But they are lending them at very high interest rates and therefore are making a deal that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.

But I also say here that perhaps it is time to have a comprehensive European response, with the admission of Eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of selling in the primary market, to respond to international markets.

Perhaps it is time for the European Commission, the Fund, and the IMF themselves to review the interest rates, so as to make it possible, by lowering these rates, to see sustained growth in these countries that are currently in difficulties.
Mr President, Commissioner and rapporteur, this strategy is important for all European countries, especially for those whose economy lacks more competitiveness.
It is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises
Today, the generation of new jobs is more active.
it is essential for universities and laboratories, whose survival depends in part on their relationship with the productive sectors.
It is essential for the financial system, which will find a new market in innovation, as the classic manufacturing model is running out.

Innovation is at the top of the European agenda and, being a pillar of the EU 2020 strategy, it will need to be supported by new financial instruments so that it does not succumb to the limitations of budgetary constraints.
Finally, I would like to salute Judith Merkies for her important contribution to a more innovative Europe with a more knowledge-based economy.
Mr President, Madam President and Commissioner, I would like to start by congratulating my colleague Mr Odi on his excellent report.

The mid-term evaluation, although belated, highlighted the critical aspects of the seventh program: its excessive bureaucracy, the lack of interest from industry, the number and complexity of the new instruments, and the slow pace of disbursements.
There is also a greater risk of substantial transfers of funds from the current framework programme to large-scale programmes with questionable added value.

But it also allowed to highlight positive aspects: greater international coordination and cooperation between scientific groups in joint projects, some success stories, including the European Research Council, and a greater gender balance.
There are priorities that must be developed: simplification in the first place, secondly promoting scientific excellence not in some countries, but throughout Europe, a greater connection of the

A framework programme with a focus on innovation, with instruments aimed at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar programme, which should be expanded. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, I am addressing the proposal that I am presenting to Parliament today, and I will say quite frankly that I think we have the right, some of us, to be disappointed with this proposal, because the proposal that is presented is not only weak, but it has numerous gaps.
I think this is a European issue, it is not an issue of the states that have a nuclear industry and those that do not, it is about the whole of Europe and Europe desperately needs good news.
I must say, sincerely, that one of those good pieces of news is to assure citizens that we are taking care of their safety.

Now, when these tests are carried out under the conditions presented by the Commissioner, that is, a first phase is carried out by the parties concerned, a second phase is carried out by the States that

These stakeholders argue in favor of it, and a third phase is carried out by the peers who are truly interested, and I wonder if the result will not ultimately be to say that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and recommend them.

We know that is not the case, and so I very much hope there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens that we are looking after their security and not just pretending that we are.
I expect a highly responsible decision from this European Council, especially given the climate we have been experiencing in recent weeks.
And what could be more irresponsible than what happened at the last Council, where they tried to postpone a problem for three months, just because of electoral calendars.

It is hoped that this decision of essential responsibility will essentially be perceived as showing that economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial issues are instrumental for what is Europe's main purpose, which is to maintain peace.
If one approaches the problems, it only leads to the states beginning to distrust one another, installing mistrust between the different states.

create and accentuate differences and rivalries between the Southern States and the Northern States, between the central States and the peripheral States. What we will have conducted is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of the technical solutions, regardless of the political drawbacks, is whether or not we believe that the European project remains a valid project for the strategy of peace in Europe.
I think that's what's at issue.
What I notice in many speeches by leaders, both from those in countries in difficulty and from those in countries that are paying countries, is that
of the taxpayers, it is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to some characteristics of the nationalities that are extremely negative.
I therefore appeal, and only to that, to the sense of responsibility of the leaders of European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to a way out and a solution.

Madam President, Commissioner, my first words are to praise the work carried out by the rapporteur, my colleague Giorgio Stravakakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness between the various structural fronts.

Your report also fits into this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that takes on greater importance not only because of the substance of the topic, but also, above all, because of the timing of its discussion.
In fact, we are currently in the process of getting to know the Commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives, but also regarding the future cohesion policy post-2013.
Cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its excellence instruments, the territorial funds, finances projects and programs in the member states, seeking to reduce the disparity between the development levels of the various regions.
Experience, however, has shown the inefficiencies and lack of results that result from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

A single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for more and better synergies between the various instruments and for enhancing their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination between the various sectoral policies and for greater efficiency in the application of resources.
We must take advantage of the danger of crisis to seek new alternatives.

It is clear that all these reports that we are discussing today will pose enormous challenges and that we know that, in order to respond to these challenges, we also need a good budget, but we must make a clear distinction between budgetary aspects and political objectives.
The political objectives are well known, and in fact, I am stating that these political objectives are what will enable us to offer a future to the regions.

And if that is the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Mr President, cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and its own currency, requires, in order to function, a certain level of convergence among its member states and regions.
The current divergences in competitiveness and development asymmetries have inevitably led to the weakening of the European area and the crisis affecting the eurozone.
This is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a powerful cohesion budget that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, in order to do more, must have more, and this is achieved by increasing its budget and not by abruptly reducing the cohesion budget.

I therefore ask the Commissioner whether the creation of the Infrastructure Fund and the new innovation policies, which will be linked to cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, could not turn into the Trojan horse introduced into the cohesion budget.
The modernization and renewal of the energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and smart growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for the energy security we need.
It is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

To this end, the incentives provided for in the regulatory systems must be improved, particularly those that apply to higher-risk projects and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores islands in the field of renewable energy.

The regions must be involved in the project approval and implementation phases, in setting priorities, in their development and execution, because this ensures better results and therefore better defence of the European interest.
The current economic moment further accentuates the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all economic, environmental, and social aspects.
It is essential not to lose sight of its medium and long-term effects, seeking to ensure that all European citizens have access to safe, sustainable and affordable energy.

Mr President, the report we are debating is of particular importance, given the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation and economic growth.

The collaboration with rapporteur Pronk was very useful and clarifying, as the rapporteur himself just said, allowing the adoption of several compromises in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.
For the result we have here today and which we have debated, I commend and congratulate the rapporteur.
In fact, from our point of view, the main concern was to make it clear that the competences in this matter fall to the Member States.
National authorities are responsible for defining, organising and financing social services of general interest.
Thus, it is unnecessary to create harmonizing legislation at the European level, given that the realities of these social services of general interest are very diverse across the 27 member states.

One need only look at the health, social security, employment, and social housing services, which are examples of how proximity and knowledge of the contexts are the cornerstone for the adequate and fairer provision of these services.

Mr President, as the draftsman of the REGI opinion on the future of international social services, I would like to congratulate my colleague Mr De Rossa, and to stress that we are dealing with an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we advocate for Europe, in which the SGEI plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the level of the European Union recommends not neglecting the existence of minimum protection levels in all member states, without prejudice to the respect for the competences of their national, regional and local authorities.

European regions play a very important role in providing these services to the population, and their opinion must be taken into account, given the specific nature of their constraints, to ensure that these services are provided to the population.

In a time of crisis like the one we are currently experiencing, international social services constitute a social safety net for the most disadvantaged or for those whose income does not allow them access to private services.

It is important to ensure that member states that decentralize powers are accompanied by the respective financial means, so that regional and local authorities can guarantee their good performance to the populations.
Madam President, Mrs Ashton, I will start by saying that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions that are taking place in these countries.
I don't have much time and, therefore, I just want to leave a few notes.
First of all, we must not forget that the conditions for negotiation, with a view to a democratic transition and not civil war, must be defined by the people in these countries.
The situation in Syria is serious, this applies to Syria, but it also applies to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we want to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to interfere in their internal affairs, and especially, and very particularly, through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say that, I say it because we must totally repudiate what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have bypassed all resolutions, even those voted on by the UN Security Council.
It is this silence regarding Libya, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it is not included in this resolution that I cannot endorse it.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr Prime Minister. First of all, I naturally wanted to congratulate the Polish Presidency on the ambitious programme it has brought here and, in particular, to congratulate it on the

neighborhood policy not only to the east, but also on the southern border, where I think there is currently a challenge, perhaps more demanding than the one we have to the east, which is more long-term and less short-term.

But having said that, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay special attention to economic integration policies, economic governance and the supervision of financial markets.
I believe that at this moment, no matter how ambitious our goals are in the areas of defense, energy, food security, environment, agriculture, and multiannual financial frameworks, if we do not

If we resolve the problem of the debt crisis in the European context in a clear and solid manner before the global markets, we will not have a Europe that is strong enough to deal with the challenges that the Polish Presidency has set out to address.
That is why I stressed the importance of convincing the remaining heads of state and heads of government that the European Union needs more economic integration and more economic governance.

Without this, what will happen is that we, instead of being the drivers or at least the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, Parliament, or the Commission of European Interest, instead of being that, will be just...
Mr President, as chairman of the Mashreq delegation, I would like to leave a sentence about each of my four countries, in quotation marks, of course.

Starting with Syria, and reiterating here what some colleagues have already expressed regret over, it is regrettable that the international community appears, in the eyes of public opinion, to have two sets of standards.

It is necessary to denounce, if necessary, the countries that, in the Security Council, and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, as well as Brazil, but with veto power, have prevented the international community from taking a position that is more consistent with what should be the values we share.
Regarding Egypt, I think there is a pressing need to raise awareness among the Egyptian authorities about postponing the elections, just as was done in Tunisia.
As for Lebanon, I believe that this debate must send a very clear message to the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their actions regarding the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.

Under Jordan, it is an example that a peaceful transition is possible and that perhaps all that is needed at this stage is to raise awareness and encourage the authorities to accelerate the reform process.
We cannot, of course, forget, in a debate of this nature, the peace process in the Middle East and reiterate our hope that the Quartet meeting next Monday will be able to
indeed be productive and reaffirm that this House would certainly like to see much greater involvement from the European Union in this whole process.

I have no doubt that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September, but I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and conducted in good faith.
Thank you, Mr President, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will constitute a reference in terms of recommendations and solid, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
If there is one conclusion that can be drawn, it is that the crisis we are experiencing can only be overcome by deepening European integration.

In a time of serious financial, economic and social difficulties and painful austerity measures in some member states, such as my country, Portugal, it is tempting to retreat into a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But, Gisele, I made a mistake.

The European response to the crisis involves a genuine European economic government that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation, and develops the social market economy, providing long-term solutions with defined objectives that the member states can identify with.
The exit strategy from the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious Community budget.
To prevent a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination on fiscal policies is needed, as well as the creation of a system for issuing public debt securities and eurobonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that, in this difficult period, it is also necessary to maintain levels of social protection, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, Presidency-in-Office, it is customary to say that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, that was the case, but today I am not so sure that this continues to be true.

The slow, improvised, reactive way the Union is reacting to the Greek crisis is aggravating the situation every day and spreading contagion and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening manner.
This, despite the problems of the eurozone resulting from obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, which today focus on its most fragile links.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed, as there was in the past, and unfortunately, neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to impart to the European program and project.
This report from Parliament, however, gives us this vision of more Europe, and not less; that is the solution.
Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency generate unbearable divergences between economies and that these must be countered by specific policies.

It recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a European budget reinforced by its own resources, and requires a European agency for the issuance of solidarity debt, capable of protecting the states from market speculation.

and provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
Parliament has come together to send clear messages, let's hope the Commission and the Council listen.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear fellow rapporteur, I would like, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteur on considering this report to be extremely useful and allowing us to indeed take new steps in the area of mediation.
The report presents an overview, a look, at the solutions adopted by the various member states in the implementation, in the application of the
Directive 2008/52/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008 on certain aspects of mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Now, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, it is a judicial body for resolving conflicts, which contributes to the decongestion of the courts, to the rationalization of the justice system, while at the same time providing
simultaneously providing the parties with the possibility of obtaining a friendly solution, which is faster and less costly than the litigation in which they were engaged.

It is therefore curious to reaffirm the objective of Article 1 of the directive, which calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution methods and, in particular, mediation.
Promoting access to and use of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution helps to improve, simplify, and make our justice system more accessible.

It is therefore a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security and justice, I would say, for the idea of the rule of law within the European Union.
And that is why, in this context of crisis as well, I consider it very important that, as stated in the report, public opinion and operators can be made aware.
on this issue and call here on the Commission and the Commissioner to quickly present a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution.
Mr President, Commissioner, I also want to mention the fundamental importance of this report in terms of transparency of the European energy market.
I just want to say that this is a central area of cooperation in European terms if we safeguard some of the dimensions that are fundamental, among them avoiding that
Liberalisation translates into increased energy prices for citizens, ensuring equal access and being careful about sanctions, as numerous colleagues have already mentioned.
Precisely because this is a central area of European cooperation, Mr President, Commissioner, I cannot help but mention it and question it, and ask you eye to eye, Commissioner.
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain yourself regarding the recent statements you made about Greece, Ireland and Portugal, because these are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures, such as flying the flags at half-mast, Commissioner, only serve to reinforce the shame of citizens who are dignified and who are fighting for a Europe.

Mr President, Commissioner Šefčovič, representatives of the Council, of the Polish Presidency, first of all, I would like to clarify that I am speaking here in a dual capacity, on the one hand, replacing the author of the opinion of the Committee on Social Affairs.

Constitutional, my colleague Nasser Schmidt, a Dane, who is absent because the election process is currently underway in Denmark, and therefore I am representing him as a member of AFCO, but also as a member of the jury, as shadow rapporteur on the jury for this report.
The first point I wanted to make is that, in the crisis we are experiencing, in the economic and financial crisis, the issue of smart regulation, better legislation, is a central issue.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms, which can boost the economic and financial takeoff of the European area, improvement in legislation and regulation is also absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe that aims to be, on the one hand, dynamic and competitive, must have regulations that are simple and accessible to businesses and, of course, to citizens, and therefore must be oriented towards their needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, first and foremost, the program for reducing administrative burdens is achieved, and that every effort is made towards
promoting consultations with market agents, representative associations of citizens and businesses, and conducting impact assessments of the legislation itself, is also extremely important, so that

The decision-making process can essentially be based, let's say, on the opinions of those who are the intended recipients of the legislation, and it can be done without administrative burdens and with fewer economic and financial costs.

It is important to say that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, this idea that European intervention should be an appropriate intervention and not an intervention that promotes the complication of the system.

and the regulatory system, and therefore, in our opinion, we pay special attention to the enhanced role that national parliaments now play in this dynamic, precisely because of the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that, in terms of smart regulation and improving legislation, we now involve the national parliaments, so that both legislation and regulation are at the European level and the national level.

Be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient and, therefore, this is a good time for us to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through more intelligent argumentation.
Mr President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has been steadily increasing in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial and social crisis and the increase in unemployment have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is the negation of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong austerity measure, the homeless concept, according to the national plan, encompasses people who go to ask for help to have a meal.
And the number of people seeking help to eat has increased by more than 20 since 2008.
A greater increase is observed in families and impoverished individuals whose living situation has been altered by unemployment and also by bank debt.
This is just one example that demonstrates the seriousness of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament adopted a written declaration on a European Union strategy for the homeless.

With this statement, this Parliament has highlighted the need for the European Union to develop a strategy supported by national and regional strategies, with the long-term goal of ending situations of people sleeping on the streets and long-term homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the member states.
We have taken good note of the Commissioner's words and recorded the state of affairs that he has presented to us.
I conclude by urging the European Commission to give a strong push to coordinate the action of the member states and regional authorities in order to combat this social injustice.
We debated the peace process in the Middle East, but there is some process underway that I have missed.
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union repeatedly states, like most of the international community, that there are two peoples and two states sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, who have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, stuck in a quagmire of hatred and misunderstandings that has lasted for 63 years, only extremism and frustration are fueled.

It is essential that Europe and the Arab League become much more involved in the search for a negotiated solution to the borders, based on those existing in 1967, with exchanges that allow the majority of Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

May the issue of Jerusalem, the holy city, future capital of the two states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that this is the land of milk and honey.

May all EU countries participate in resolving the issue of Palestinian refugees and may the international community, and in particular the Arab nation, participate in the necessary financial compensation.

It is also absolutely essential that a military force, under the auspices of the UN and with the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces, be deployed on the ground to guarantee the maintenance of peace.
So there is courage and political will.
Mr President, Commissioner, tourism needs a clear and coordinated European approach, with a keen eye on the potential and challenges that different forms of tourism have to offer us.
The tourist diversity that the European Union presents is so rich that it allows for exponential growth of this sector and of the European Union's own competitiveness.

A bet on this key sector, which represents 10% of the GDP and about 12% of employment in the European Union, will not only create European added value, but also help us face the economic crisis we are in.
It comes from an outermost region, Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

And, therefore, the creation of a specific heading for the sector in the 2014 financial framework is indispensable for cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially composed of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The implementation of a genuine European policy for sustainable and diversified tourism requires a concrete strategic plan, with a well-defined timeline, actions, and funding, capable of enhancing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.
Mr. President, the absence of an ongoing peace process is jeopardizing basic rights and leading to unilateral measures being taken by one side, which do not have to be taken together.

they have not contributed in any way to easing tensions in the region, much less to the effective pursuit of a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security, and with dignity.

The time has come for the international community to say enough is enough, the time has come for Europe and the Arab League to push for a lasting solution, with common sense, presenting viable solutions without delay and with deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let us start with Jerusalem: why not revive the original idea of a separatum corpus administered by the UN and functioning, of course, as the capital of both states?
Borders, we start with 67
Exchange land parcels as much as possible and consistently.
Take care of the defense of Israel, an issue obviously unavoidable for the Jewish people, for example, by placing blue helmets with American, European, and Islamic forces along the Jordan River.
There are approximately 4.8 million refugees who have the right to their dignity and a future tied to a land of their preference.

But they are not exclusively an Israeli or Palestinian problem, they are also ours, they are those of the neighboring Arab countries, of the Arab community in general, but also of Europe and the rest of the international community.
Colunatos must end its expansion, and this is non-negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and reflects hypocrisy and bad faith in a statement of readiness for immediate negotiations.
Above all, we want good-faith negotiations, with a deadline for their conclusion, after which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will have to take a different approach.

Madam President, Commissioner, since the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has been mentioned, we all share, and I share much of what has been said by my colleagues who have just spoken.
I am not going to refer to that in particular; I am referring to another situation that is more often omitted, which is that of the citizens who were received in the homes of families in Tunisia.

And this is one of the situations that should make us even more ashamed, because let's look at Tunisia, in a crisis situation, knows how to be supportive. Europe does not know how to be supportive and is not in a process of transition to democracy, does not know how to be supportive, does not know how to receive.
I think it is, in fact, shameful that we can count the number of refugees received in Europe in the hundreds.
Contrary to what has been said, many of these people cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications in terms of infrastructure, has implications in terms of what the reception is like in these countries.
That is why, Commissioner, I am very moved by what you do, and I do not say this in an ironic way, I say it seriously, but please, what about the Commission?
And Europe.
What can you do?
How does Europe live so well with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Commissioner.
It can't continue

Mr President, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on this supplement of hope that you have given to all European Members of Parliament and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union that we represent here.
And by saying that, I meant that we now expect the Commission to take very, very decisive action with the Council, so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it's a marathon, but we need immediate signs.

And so, without prejudice to the fact that we are already all thinking about amending the Treaties to give political substance to the entire project we have brought here today, without prejudice to that, something must be done immediately.

This set of measures and, possibly, an agreement between the states, what I have called a kind of parasocial agreement that goes beyond the Treaties and that can, from this moment on, put all these ideas into action.
Many congratulations on your courage and determination.
I believe we are on the right track and we will leave here today with another decision.

Mr President, the crisis that the European Union is going through has had serious consequences in all the member states, and thousands of workers have been affected by the layoffs caused by globalization and the crisis.
We must affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and state that Europe must help member states maintain an employment rate and combat unemployment.
A rapid reintegration of workers into the job market is a priority objective.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has drawn on it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalisation Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to help thousands of workers through vocational training measures, aid for setting up businesses and incentives for recruitment.
This proposal is positive because it will allow member states to request intervention from this fund to support workers who have been laid off as a direct result of the economic and financial crisis.

We support the extension of the deadline and understand that the member states most affected by the crisis should have greater and easier access to this fund in support of globalization and the crisis.
I greet the Polish Presidency and also Commissioner Wally Rehn, just to say that I believe that you
Today, following on from and building upon what was done in the State of the Union address, a very, very big step has been taken towards resolving the problems of the eurozone crisis.
Because the Commission has taken a stand here, committing to use its power of initiative and to use it with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and it is the only way we have at the moment to resolve the eurozone crisis.
There is no possibility of resolving it in the short term, only with an intergovernmental approach, and that is why it is necessary for the states, the governments of the states, to give the
The Commission has the instruments and the mandate for it to lead this resolution process, for it to implement, execute and develop this roadmap that it has presented here.
But I wanted to make it clear that this is not incompatible with doing so at the same time, with developing our ability to amend the treaties at the same time.
I am also convinced that, in the medium term, we need to amend the Treaties, but here too we will have to do so in order to strengthen the Commission, to give it more power and a better position.

It is through the reinforcement of the Community metric, now in the short term and then with a change in the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve more integration and a solution for the 17 countries of the eurozone and for the 27 countries of the European Union.

Mr. President, Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce that as one of the measures, banks that do not have capital requirements must submit plans to obtain them, and if they cannot submit them, they must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not help but agree with this presentation that was made by the president.
Just this week we saw what happened with Zexia Bank, and a few months ago, an administrator of this bank received a prize of 600 thousand euros for his wonderful administration, as we know.
But, to be serious, the President of the Commission has to call the governments and present the full package, and the full package is what has the essentials.
The essential thing is that taxpayers' money should be matched by a credit policy for growth.
The essential thing is that banks start paying taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, including my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather, in three years, it is the second time that we are asked to save the banks with the money of the taxpayers, of the unemployed.
(FEL) the banks that also save the economy, helping to create jobs. (SAM) Thank you very much.
"Madam High Representative, there are times when I think I need little and to take stock, and this seems to be one of those times."
And it seems to me that it is because we always go with the pace of events and the response from event to event and lose a bit of perspective on the whole.

It is true that each case is a case in itself and each country we are talking about here is a specific case, but, forgive me for saying so, Madam High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinise what criteria the European Union has used to act in relation to each of the cases.
I fear that we are often held hostage by the interests of the countries of the European Union, by some of these countries of the European Union, not all of them.
That is why we have used the expression "two weights and two measures" so many times in this house, and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it's sanctions yes, sometimes it's sanctions no, sometimes the interference goes as far as the bomb, as was the case in Libya, other times it's total silence, as was the case in the invasion of Bahrain by the forces

Now, Baroness, let me tell you that I have been studying all the ACERs carefully, and I have yet to see a single statement from European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by Saudi military forces.

There are death sentences, there is endless violence, there are doctors and nurses who are sentenced to up to 30 years in prison by a military court because they were allegedly against the regime and not helping the wounded who needed them.
Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain, regarding the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the Saleh regime, we have had much more silence than action.
