I am not in favour of management, never have been, but I fear we are putting ourselves in an uncomfortable position, the position seen from the outside, Baroness, which is instead of helping us with development, with aspirations,

democratic and revolutionary movements of the peoples in the Arab countries. Instead of helping the first Arab era, what we do is prevent it from extending, either by excess or by defect, and I don't think we should be burdened with this sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to an Yemeni activist may serve as a sign that our side is the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, this is a good report by our colleague Mr Casa.
First and foremost, one must ask why revise VAT in the European Union.
First, there is the need to be compatible with the single market.
The more regimes and VAT varieties, the less fluid the market will be.
A VAT reform favors e-commerce, centers competition on the value and base price of goods and services, and not on tax differences.
Combating fraud and ensuring trust, which is particularly necessary in cross-border transactions, improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other measures, as far as Joventut is concerned, are already in place in the single market that could be associated with VAT?
First and foremost, a simple, clear and transparent digital support mechanism, measure 7 of the single market.
Measure 5 on services, the need to review legislation on standardisation and the implementation of the Directive
The new measure aims to remove tax obstacles and explicitly review the VAT system and the VAT equation in online and face-to-face trade, which we all feel when we order books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two main reasons.
First of all, the economic crisis.
More revenue is needed, including, probably in some countries, reducing contributions on labor to promote economic development, shifting that burden to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressures is the aging population, demographic aging, and the trend of shifting from indirect to direct taxes, due to the reduction in the population base for taxation.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the range of variation in the standard VAT rate so that we can all understand it better.
Greater transparency is needed in defining the reduced VAT rate and its scope, a clear and widely publicized list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, knowing full well that each exemption brings with it a host of small or large-scale frauds.
Finally, welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Madam President, I thank my colleague Mrs Rübig for the excellent report she has prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly well known, but the obstacles are also evident: conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of the Member States undermine competitiveness.
The dichotomy in quality of prices and the complexity of laws and procedures are evident.
It is essential to look at existing best practices, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has worked well and has facilitated public procurement.
Effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling the public deficit and fostering growth.
To achieve this, it must have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs, and defend social and environmental values.

That is why I welcome the intentions that Commissioner Barnier has presented to us here for the revision of public procurement, later this year, as one of the twelve priorities of the Single Market Act.
to congratulate colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important in the field of public contracts is the issue of electronic public procurement.
Unfortunately, the objectives proposed by the European Union of 50% of awards through electronic procedures in 2010 failed, with average values of only 5.
Only a few countries, such as my own, Portugal, have succeeded in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are, indeed, evident and have been outlined here. It allows for the replacement of costly access processes with the simple consultation of the electronic platform, which means it reduces many costs for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.

Small and medium-sized enterprises, internet dissemination and the ease of receiving procedural documents increase the number of suppliers, increasing competition and allowing for better purchasing, making the public procurement process more efficient.

easier and more flexible, simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thereby facilitating their participation in the public procurement market, which is crucial for these important drivers of the economy.
In this sense, we welcome and encourage the European Commission for strengthening the mechanisms to make electronic public procurement an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living through decisive hours for the fate of Europe, and while the situation has quickly passed, before everyone's eyes, from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a major European problem, the truth is that the inadequacy of the proposed solutions and their delay have not produced any effectiveness in the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The search for solutions targeted at individual states, rather than truly European solutions, allowed the markets to continue speculating about sovereign debts and imposed deadlines and rhythms.
it is absolutely impossible that some states are trying to achieve with measures of an anti-inevitable brutality applied to people, companies and the public sector.

A common solution is absolutely essential, one that has already been found for the risk of European sovereign debt, which removes market pressure and speculation and buys time for the necessary adjustments to be made.
Without this, what we will end up with are countries that will continue to have nothing left to pay their creditors, with destroyed economies and a lot, a lot of suffering.

To the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I have had fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs of the partners from the four committees involved. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 compromises, all of which were approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest generated by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is, after all, about preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the job market in the next decade.
The key strategy for drafting the report was to reformulate common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the report's coherence.
I think that objective has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the weaknesses of the European economic and social model, and has also negated many of the advances made in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than five million jobs.
Today, there are nearly 23 million people without jobs.
Youth unemployment is even more frightening: the youth unemployment rate is close to 21% and represents more than double the general unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all member states, unemployment rates vary with qualification levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find jobs more easily.
We also know that, in the near future, the need for skills, competences and qualifications will increase in all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, job creation; second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Then there is the sustainability of social security systems and finally the difficulty in finding people with the right skills to fill job vacancies.
This report thus has a dual objective: first, to underline the need to act quickly to address skills gaps in Europe; second, to better anticipate the needs of the labor market in terms of skills.

To achieve this, several measures stand out. First, to ensure the availability of a skilled workforce, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I mentioned earlier, skill needs should be identified early, with a time frame of at least ten years.
Today, we are aware of the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications.
Then, participation in lifelong learning, professional requalification, and reducing school dropout rates must be increased.
Another important issue is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the link that must exist between educational establishments and the needs of the labour market.
Interns must be of quality and supervised by tutors, so that they can lead to a job and put an end to any abuses of the intern situation.
Particular emphasis is also placed on the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote job demand and creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we have to create jobs.
Small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role here for this objective.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers and, consequently, the need for the coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, especially the portability of pensions.

Lastly, the issue of labour market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labour market, flexicurity rules should be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you very much.
(FEL) Thank you, Madam President. I would like to begin by thanking all my colleagues who have contributed to this lively debate.
All colleagues made very useful contributions and contributed to a very constructive discussion on an agenda that is ambitious at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.

Incidentally, this discussion is taking place on the eve of a European Council meeting that will show whether or not there is the political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and whether there is a will

policy for a deepening of our coordination in economic terms and whether there is really a harmonized and unitary will to be able to carry forward the ambition that is in this agenda, that is, to have
new jobs in the next decade, new jobs that will give hope to young people who are currently unemployed and those who are graduating, hope in an inclusive job market that will meet their needs

ambition of dignification through work and who also have the opportunity to be in a permanent dynamic to keep up with the challenges of a globalized economy with a dynamic that has no parallel in recent generations.

That is why our ambition is truly to create jobs, to have economic growth, not only to respond to those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who will enter the labor market and also provide

response to the major challenges facing the green economy, health services, transport and accommodation services, which require all of us to have a different vision, an intelligent vision and an inclusive vision of the labor market.
Thank you very much to all.

Madam President, what we were told here today in the Council statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed in terms of the European semester, but what we are talking about is a political issue, and the question I pose is whether there can be political coordination without democracy.
Where, after all, is the scrutiny of the European Parliament?
Where is the scrutiny of national parliaments over their major budgetary choices?

But if the issue were technical, as was stated here, then we are talking about a variable technique, because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions for the four countries on France's waiting list, Italy, Hungary, Spain; it did not do the same for the countries under bailout.
So what kind of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to give opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to give opinions about Germany?
And, Mr. President, I ask you only to pay attention to this: no problem of democratic legitimacy is resolved by asking deputies to consult information on the Internet.
This is an issue of under-representation, not an issue of democratic exclusion. That's what we're talking about here. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, a word of congratulations first to the rapporteur, Mr Dardenne, for the quality and timeliness of this report, and also to Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem, requiring effective and rapid action to stem the rise of the phenomenon, which currently affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are already experiencing has exacerbated this situation and made the times we are living in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor said.
The number of unemployed people continues to rise, and we all know that a lack of employment is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This scenario requires resources, willingness and a great deal of effort from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not happen, the goal of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
That is why I warmly welcome the initiative of the Platform Against Poverty, which is a very important tool for ensuring social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
Access to the Internet should now be considered a new fundamental right of citizens and not just a mere object of commerce, because freedom of expression is at stake.
essential things depend on it, such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

That is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that block free choice and the possibility of easily changing providers, particularly in the mobile telecommunications world, as we also know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that complete and transparent information be provided.
Internet shutdowns are not just the exclusive domain of political regimes that are afraid of their own people.
It can also happen, as a result of economic choices, by offering privileges to special customers and by providing less equal treatment to customers who are not as profitable.
That is why I support Parliament in clearly standing up for net neutrality and defending its all-encompassing nature.
Let's speak the truth.
We have been taking the medication for three years to get out of the crisis and the situation is getting worse day by day.
Instead of healing, we have created two vicious and fatal circles.
The first between banks and states.
In Europe, it is now easier to discuss the bankruptcy of a state than that of a large bank, but it is still expected that banks will finance states and that states will save their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must push forward with European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
But it is also vital to protect the debt of the States from the attacks of speculators.

And to this end, it is urgent to prepare coordinated sovereign debt issues, whether called Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, and to guarantee them through robust instruments of a Community nature, not an intergovernmental one.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

It ignores the essential fact that a single market and a single currency, built by political choice and among unequals, necessarily exacerbate competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And that is what must be mapped out in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompoi, through sanctions that promote the crushing of wages and incomes through one country's control over another.
First, through a commitment, Mr. Commissioner, from both the countries with surpluses and those with deficits, to converge productivity through investment, education, and science.
(FEL) The sanctions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment and a wave of crisis from which we cannot escape.

Madam President, Commissioner, the integrated maritime policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas and coasts, in a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European policies related to the sea and requires better governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past few years through the various initiatives funded in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy must therefore continue to benefit from adequate funding during the remaining years of the current financial programming period.
In this sense, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, and I support the definition of a stable framework regarding the objectives of this program.
Issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics of particular interest to some regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The ORs are regions which, with the exception of French Guiana, are small in size, depend on a limited number of economic activities and where sea-related and fishing activities are of particular importance.
Furthermore, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the most extensive exclusive economic zone in the world.

The ORs represent more than half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 out of 25 million square kilometers, and, together with coastal regions, are crucial for the economic growth of the European Union and its member states.

A programme such as the one provided for in the integrated maritime policy should benefit these regions by giving priority to transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
It would be a missed opportunity in the context of integrated maritime policy not to emphasize the enormous potential that the Atlantic and insular dimensions hold for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and Africa, conferring a strategic dimension to Europe that is indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with an eye to the future.

And it is with the future in mind that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the coordination of maritime activities, should place the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension at the forefront of its priorities, based on science and technology.

The investigation of the Atlantic crisis, deep sea and seabeds constitutes a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of incalculable value to the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the Azores' privileged position and the location of its oceanographic department to establish a deep-sea observatory there.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is wrong, the remedies don't work.
And, in the case of the eurozone, its remedies have even brought it to the brink of death.
The successive miraculous solutions that have been proposed have also been equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stability Fund, the successive austerity measures of the Stability and Growth Pact, the troika's revenues in the countries under the program.
Blind discipline, without growth, generated a recessionary wave among fully interconnected economies, which therefore contaminated each other with bankruptcies and unemployment.
And, at the hands of the markets, that is, the rating agencies and the speculators, governments are falling one after another and solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

Changing the Treaties now is just another step in this disastrous trajectory, and by aggravating it, we risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty, putting countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, there is no need to amend the treaties.
In this emergency we are in, we need to make two decisions.
First and foremost, a genuine agenda for growth and sustained cohesion must be implemented.
Where is the 2020 Agenda?
Where is the relaunch budget?
Where are the project bonds for Europe's structural investments?
And, secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.
Of course, the eurobonds are necessary, but in this emergency we are in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defends the sovereign debt against the speculators.
Not in a timid way, but with a definitive, determined stance, as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that supports it.
For this, it is not necessary to change the Treaties, but rather political will and European conviction.
We will revise the Treaty when we have learned all the lessons from the current crisis, and there are many lessons to be learned, but this is certainly not the time.
Mr President, Commissioner Dalli, the first single market forum, an idea stemming from the GREEK report, took place in Krakow, in
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap, outlined in the Commission's communication of 12 April, with the 12 levers.
The law needs to be passed, as well as the strategy for the other 38 priorities identified in the Act for the single market.
For there to be a market, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be taken for granted; it needs to be stimulated, nurtured.
The single market is not just a buying and selling operation; it involves horizontal policies such as health, social and consumer protection, labor law, the environment, and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should therefore become a flagship event of the European Union, held annually and with a diverse and increasingly participatory audience.
Mr President, I think we are at a time of assessment regarding these crisis policies, austerity policies that have affected so many countries, and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I think we cannot help but see how they have generated so much social commotion.
And it has generated social unrest not only in the countries with the greatest difficulties, in the southern countries, not only in the so-called peaks and also in other contexts in Europe.
Just last week we had in Portugal the largest general strike ever, both in the public and private sectors, a strike that took to the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we witnessed the largest strike ever, especially if we consider that people took to the streets as well as they did in Portugal.
We expect a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes prove when people take to the streets, is that the causes and problems we have been facing are common, and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We have witnessed chaos in the financial markets and the growing inability to secure essential financing for the operations of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even when they are healthy, leading them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the urgent need for budget discipline, deep restructuring, and more economic governance, but these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if it is true that policies are needed to stimulate employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debt, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will collapse.
That is why, more than ever, more than a revision of the Treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention by the European Central Bank.
Madam President, Commissioner, we are all here today united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day and this review of the 2009 resolution and communication is crucial.
It is precisely the things that have already been mentioned that are crucial.
And we repeat ourselves, because unfortunately there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to be done.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and the European economic area. A 2010 report speaks of more than 25 new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about more than 100 new cases.
And if we think that things can't get worse, they can always get worse.

One of the issues I want to make very clear here has to do with the disinvestment that has been made in the health sector, as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
And this disinvestment has seriously affected areas that are crucial for the fight against HIV/AIDS.
That is why, Commissioner, I believe that the Commission has a crucial role to play here in asking Member States to fulfil their obligations in these areas.

A second issue is also related to the increase in discrimination, which has also been highlighted by the economic and social crisis, discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs because they are carriers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for everyone, regardless of gender, age, or the region where they live.
I hope we can implement these measures with the Commissioner's support. Thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr Draghi.
We are living through special and dramatic circumstances and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between state debt and bank debt must be broken, but at the moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the eurozone countries and the euro itself are not destroyed by the rating agencies and speculators.
In the report that we will approve, Tremosa and Baselt, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the eurozone, create eurobonds and a European treasury, but all of this takes time.
At the moment we are talking about an emergency and, in this context, the only solution is in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, you should not be inhibited in your intervention and action by limited interpretations of your mandate.
Its mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At this point, there is no doubt that saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck, brave and sincere ones, dear ones.
The European Neighbourhood Policy Committee has already taken very explicit note of the positions that the European Parliament has been adopting.

It was with great satisfaction that we saw a large part of the principles and proposals that we have been defending in this House included in the subsequent communications from the Commission and the Council.

I would also like to express my gratitude for the excellent and ongoing collaboration and coordination we have maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Ashton and Commissioner Stefano Fulla and their offices.
starting with the upgrade achieved in our relationship with our poor neighbors.

By prioritizing relations with the general population and with civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively founded on the universal values that we defend and share.
However, I emphasize that the European Union does not intend to impose a predefined model or formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when it comes to our taxpayers' money, we should give more to those who are doing more to approach the values we believe in.
This principle means that the faster a country progresses with its internal reforms, the more support it gets from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair and consistent.
What I mean, of course, is that we also anticipate the possibility of there being cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighbourhood policy is now based on the pursuit of common values and a commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.
But this pursuit implies greater accountability.

Our partners are called upon to take more responsibility in the process, which is why we advocate for the principles of greater differentiation, greater conditionality, and the concept of more for more.

By adopting a bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies towards our partners, which we call the Bottom Up Approach and Taylor made policies, we make development and institutional capacity more effective.

an institutional building that we so want to defend and that lies at the foundation of the rule of law and the democratic process, and that we want to see implemented as quickly as possible in the societies, economies, and communities of our neighbors.

The idea is to give a voice to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that identify with our values, supporting organized movements that strive for positive and democratic change in their countries.
countries, improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, whether of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.
etc., with fair elections, with the fight against corruption, with the rule of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection and resource efficiency.
The serious economic and social problems faced by our neighbors also require immediate action.
It is evident that, without our concrete help, the ongoing democratic processes may fail.
These are the ideas we have always advocated for the future European neighbourhood policy.
These are the proposals contained in the report that we are putting to the vote.
Now is the time to act.
For our part, we will continue to be vigilant and to exercise our powers of monetization and oversight, now enshrined in the European Parliament.

Finally, I would like to thank my colleague, co-rapporteur and friend Marek Siwicki, to whom I extend a very special word of appreciation for his remarkable work on the eastern dimension of the neighbourhood policy.
Also to the shadow rapporteurs and opinion rapporteurs, and to all of you for the countless suggestions proposed in the amendments you submitted, which I believe have enriched our work.
And a final word to the Secretariat of the Commission and to the political advisors for the excellent support work I have benefited from.

Regions such as the French outermost regions have an absolute need for greater integration into their geographical areas.
far from the Union's internal market, this integration is crucial for their development and represents a huge potential for deepening the neighbourhood policy with neighbouring third countries.

These regions can and should play a more active role in favor of the European Union within the framework of a new European neighborhood policy.

Since 2008, in fact, communications, reports, and recommendations have been produced by the Commission and Parliament, and high-level forums and groups have been established to address this serious problem, but in practice, nothing has changed beyond increased awareness.

We return to the subject and it must be said without hesitation that a significant part of the problems that farmers face stem from highly penalizing behaviors imposed, above all, by operators of modern distribution.
The problems have been more than identified.
What has been lacking from the Commission and the member states is an effective political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue to see losses for farmers and consumers.
I have to say that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, it is, above all, dangerous.
First, because it will reinforce, with more punishments and rigid rules, a recipe that does not work.
The downward spiral has begun.
Who can trust a doctor who cannot distinguish weight loss from anorexia?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more insists on the remedy, while openly discussing the probability of his death.
How many more countries have to go into recession before the Commission and the Council realise that the diagnosis is wrong?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million and 700 thousand are unemployed.

Does the Council and the Commission not realize that ignoring this fact, not giving an adequate response, reveals an autism and insensitivity that are politically exclusive?
Let us be clear.

Where are the project bonds to finance European investment?
Where is the reinforcement of the European budget with a tax on speculative financial products?
Where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates imposed on them by the markets, leading them to ruin?
Citizens demand options, not words, but competent options. Thank you very much.
Madam President, the Commission and governments are now promising to reprogram structural funds to support SMEs and create jobs.
However, it is worth remembering that at the end of last year, the Commission also decided to suspend the allocation of structural funds to countries that did not meet the deficit or debt targets.
You don't need to be a genius to realize that either the promise is fulfilled or the punishment is exacted, but you can't have both at the same time.
That is why, Commissioner, I wanted to ask you a very direct question: does the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds remain in place, has it been frozen, or has it been cancelled?
In other words, can Greece, Portugal, Ireland and other countries still access funds they are entitled to if they do not meet the targets being imposed by the Commission and by you?
Please answer, Commissioner, because in Portugal we are very tired of promises, okay?
Mr President, Commissioner, the proposal is made by President Barroso to redirect the available structural funds to support our SMEs.
But stimulating employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies that are being subjected to strong austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the agreement on external intervention and the major difficulties in financing the economy, and in particular our small and medium-sized enterprises by the banking system, this proposal takes on special importance for regions with high absorption and good use of funds, but which are in a recessionary context.

The TFA package, presented here as an instrument for sector organisation, contains positive and important elements, such as the strengthening of the role of producer organisations and inter-branch organisations in contractual matters, which in some Member States may, for example, cease to be important.

However, there is much that the sector needs in terms of instruments to thrive in the coming years within the framework of an agriculture that we want to have in Europe, with access to a fair distribution of value in the food chain, and that does not transform into an agriculture of large intensive farms concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving the self-regulation condition in the relationship between industry players is desirable, thinking that this alone is sufficient is a serious mistake that could drive thousands of dairy farmers, dozens of regions, and even some countries away from dairy production.
The debate on the regulation of the veal sector from the perspective of a sustainable sector, economically, socially, environmentally and territorially, is still ongoing.
And we cannot abandon the milk quota system without having ensured genuine supply management instruments.
Mr President, Commissioner, from May 2010 to the present day, we have seen how a problem that seemed manageable has escalated uncontrollably.
It is true that the fight against the crisis triggered by the financial markets has worsened the debt of the Eurozone countries and that the most vulnerable have become particularly susceptible.

However, is it possible that countries sharing the same currency are left to the mercy of attacks by financial operators and speculators, betting on the probability of eurozone countries going bankrupt?
The dire consequences of the Council and Commission's failure to respond have generated problems that are now undeniable.
The speculative interest rates applied to individual countries have made any strategy for exiting the crisis unfeasible.
The consequent worsening of the country's economic problem justifies a new interest rate hike, until the total cut of credit kills a country's economy and contagion does the rest.
And this Parliament has long been advocating for a common management of sovereign debt, subject to demanding but clear rules.
We welcome the fact that the Commission has finally produced a Green Paper on the subject, which has been referred to as the

Today it is clear that, without some kind of obligations of this type, properly articulated with the European Stabilization Mechanism, the so-called protection barriers, these firewalls for sovereign debt, do not exist and, as long as they do not exist, the euro is in danger and Europe is also in danger.

In the resolution that this Parliament overwhelmingly approved regarding the new Treaty, it became absolutely clear that it is not acceptable to continue imposing more fiscal stability rules, budgetary discipline, and sanctions on the euro countries without taking concrete and urgent steps towards the solidarity-based management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will have to evolve in parallel.
That is what we expect from the Commission, and it is too late now.

insist on dialogue, without a doubt.

We continue to disapprove of the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in their unbelievable support for the Syrian regime.

Mr President, welcome, Commissioner, to discuss this topic of such importance.
In fact, we are talking about central issues related to data protection, especially in a context where there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

Data protection is, in fact, one of the sensitive areas that has generated so much controversy and, in my view, will continue to do so, because we are talking about what could be the clash between the

the rights and guarantees, the safeguarding of European citizens who are protected by European legislation and then find themselves overridden when the legislation of other countries supersedes European legislation.
It is sensitive for several reasons.
Is it sensitive because there is a break and there is doubt in what is a contract that, for all intents and purposes, exists between European citizens and European institutions?
When they provide their personal data, they understand that it will be protected by European entities and institutions and that it will not be distributed for other purposes.

Therefore, there is a breach of trust here, and this is a fact that is complicated to manage, and on the other hand, it is also a serious and perilous situation, because the European Union ends up transferring personal data to third countries, thus breaking the trust cell that is generated.

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different areas, from health issues to other issues, as mentioned, such as business ones,

If I speak specifically, for example, of the case of the United States, which systematically request data from the European Union, what are we doing when citizens start from the assumption that they are ceding, and, as I said, for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, what is done is a breach of trust.
Therefore, I also want to say, Commissioner, that these issues have often been problematic for different reasons, but I will always be on the side of the citizens' demonstrations.

They want to safeguard the protection of their personal data and, if there are demonstrations that aim to be made because the European institutions do not comply, I think we should be on the side of the citizens and not on the opposite side.

It is almost a kind of betrayal that is being carried out, and that is why we are asking you this question, these questions we are putting to you, Commissioner, so that you can clarify this for us once and for all, because no community is built on destruction as its basis or foundation.

weakening of the bonds of trust that exist between its citizens and its institutions. And in this regard, Commissioner, please answer us, to what extent can we ensure that European legislation overrides the legislation of third countries?
Because, while it is true that European legislation supersedes the legislation of the 27 member countries of the European Union, citizens abdicate.
This sovereign space, in many respects, why should we accept that other countries, such as the United States, can then override European legislation and override national legislation?
This needs to be clarified because it is a very sensitive fact and it is serious and it is an issue that we must take into consideration.

And finally, Commissioner, I would like to ask you, please, to tell us what the Commission is doing to prevent this from happening, to ensure it does not recur, and to protect the personal data of all citizens.

from companies and various sectors that are referenced in these issues, are in fact data that people can trust, that remain protected from what we protect. And by this I mean that I don't even share the view that all the information that is stored should be stored, but that is another debate.

Regarding this, as it is a serious issue and a preliminary one in terms of citizens' rights, I would like you to provide us with these clarifications so that we can all feel more at ease. Thank you very much.

President, I would essentially like to say that from the next Council we expect a major decision at an economic level for the countries that are on aid very closely linked to the issue of the Structural Funds.

they must be geared towards competitiveness, towards small and medium-sized enterprises, towards relaunching the economy.

Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner, I understand the rapporteurs, but I would like to say that enough is enough of pious speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the first results on macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil is beginning to lift on why, in the European Union and particularly in the eurozone, some countries are growing while others are inevitably struggling.
Europe is losing competitiveness in foreign markets, and this agenda needs to be revised because much of the insufficient internal growth, concentrated in the domestic market, depends on this.
Four countries, including Germany, have been accumulating surpluses year after year, while twenty other countries, I repeat, twenty, have been accumulating deficits year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases in an unsustainable manner.
Of course this process has to be controlled.
Of course, discipline is necessary.
But it is important to ask today whether, in this context, the solution of crushing the most fragile with recessionary policies is the only possible solution?
Is the tax competition of some winners within the internal market still tolerated?

Can the best European economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, while being right for its economy, capture in its favor most of the gains from the internal market?
Can the Commission and the Council continue to impose recessionary policies that tighten the economy of the most fragile, discussing
openly the possibility of bankruptcy of sovereign states in the eurozone, when they know that the firewalls never left the dossier of intentions
Are the Commission and the Council fully aware of the explosive political and economic risk that this discourse brings to Europe?
Yes, it is necessary to radically revise the recipes.
But for that to happen, there needs to be political will.
Until this will exists, out of respect for the citizens, let us stop saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
And citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you very much, Mr President, I begin by welcoming the rapporteurs.
It is now a commonplace to say that we are experiencing the most serious financial, economic, and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model.
It cannot be stressed enough that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historic records, making the fight against unemployment the top priority.
Youth unemployment is dramatic in my country, Portugal, with more than one in three young people looking for a job and having no prospects of finding one.
Our citizens are suspicious.
It is urgent to restore their confidence.
After years of reckless management of public finances, it is time to adopt fiscal consolidation reforms and put the accounts in order.
But let us not delude ourselves: austerity without economic growth is only a partial solution.
The creation of more jobs and better jobs is the great European goal.
Measures to ensure that young people do not go more than four months without receiving a job or training offer, as well as reducing the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must become a reality.
Mr. President, one year ago we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami, and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today, we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
Honoring the victims is a way of telling them that we have learned the lesson we must learn about dealing with natural and nuclear catastrophes, and that we have a duty to prevent them.
But unfortunately, that doesn't seem to be the truth.
A year after Fukushima and new nuclear power plants continue to be built.
A year after Fukushima and new nuclear power plants continue to be planned.
Japan unfortunately has the memory of the lasting tragedies of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and we Europeans also have the memory of the lasting tragedy of Chernobyl.
Fukushima forces us, for all these reasons, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed: the debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two-thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know it costs lives and they know that this cost is priceless, on the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear power is the policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe too, we have a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and despite this, nothing seems to change.
There are currently 320 refugees in Japan, of whom 100 will never be able to return home.
What was once familiar is now dangerous, what was once comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation, it is the ruin of contaminated soil or water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited like other ruins, for example, a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin, but nevertheless, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization, and the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
the one that chose to include a deadly technology in its development model.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.
In Japan, as in Europe, many citizens have decided to create movements to say goodbye to nuclear power.
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear energy is a myth. They know better than anyone that there are no stress tests that
they can simulate what happened in Fukushima and that's why we know that energy policies are national, but in the sky
As previously mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
And these are, in fact, the numbers of an epidemic.
That is why I believe it is also justified to make a specific resolution regarding diabetes, especially since this is the first time this Parliament has addressed this issue.
It is the result of collective work and it is a work that does not nullify the work done so far on chronic diseases; on the contrary, it reinforces our ability to intervene together.
We have about 325 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the leading cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, kidney failure, and vital organs.
In light of these data, we have two options, in my view.
The first is to say that it is not so serious, that we can live well with it and that each government takes care of itself.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that, on our side, we have a lot to do.
And we have a lot to do in early diagnosis, in coordination, in investment in research.
And that is why this Resolution has the value of a beginning and of joint work in this direction. Thank you very much.
What I wanted to draw attention to, basically, was to congratulate myself on the Council's results.
Not because the measures are ideal, but because they are the possible measures.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many states have been making a huge effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has only been made in some states, by induction of the European Union.
It is essential for them to recover their credibility in international markets and it is essential for them to be able to grow in the long term.
With these guarantees that the states have to offer, among which the Portuguese state stands out, in terms of fiscal consolidation and budgetary consolidation, I am
I am also convinced, with the new treaty signed between the 25, that we will be able to seriously relaunch growth in the next steps of the European Council.
But it is only with this confidence that is being generated little by little that this growth must be made.
And that is why I say: solidarity from the richest with the poorest is important, but from the poorest with the richest is also important, providing these guarantees.
Mr President, I basically wanted to say that we are very pleased to see that steps have been taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, like Spain, or like Greece, which were countries that lived under dictatorships and had a set of very serious problems, is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And that is why Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
I would, in any case, like to give a slightly different note here than the one that has been given by my colleagues.

I know and appreciate the great concern for minorities, but we must not forget the Serbian majority. It is essential that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a full right to be there.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia, and therefore, no matter how much we emphasize the rights of minorities and they must be respected, we cannot forget the Serbian majority, their identity and their full right to be European citizens equal to all others, with their own state and national pride.
Mr President, Portugal voted last week on the Treaty, or rather, the budgetary ultimatum, which is not, incidentally, a European Treaty, it is worth noting.
The government parties' vote in favor reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good student, racist, who doesn't think and obeys the bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to move from a very dangerous violent abstention to a creeping vote in favor.

This alliance makes our Portuguese Assembly of the Republic the first Parliament to accept the humiliation of amputating itself from one of its most important functions, for which the people it elected decide annually on the country's budget.
This is yet another blow from the European Union, yet another one. It is a blow in which the power of money becomes increasingly out of reach of the citizens' vote.
And I ask, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that one can no longer vote? Thank you.
Mr President, fiscal consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, each day there are fewer people who have to bear a greater burden.
The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, yet we are witnessing completely disproportionate tax evasion and avoidance.
The Group of the European Socialists wanted to know how much this tax evasion and avoidance is worth in the twenty-seven countries, and it amounts to one trillion euros.
This is more than the European Union countries spend on health.

This means such a volume that, if we were to spend just a fifth of this amount on investment, investment in Europe would rise from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore talking about an exceptionally high value.

The purpose of the resolution we are going to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to accelerate concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for tax cooperation within the European Union, tax cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country in a bilateral manner.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating tax fraud and evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a major partner in the international context.
Within the G20 framework, Europe has an obligation to clearly advocate for a common fight against tax fraud and evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens, and therefore, my final words in this debate are a call for the Commission and the Council to begin an effective fight against tax fraud and evasion.

Mr President, I would like to start by congratulating my colleague Mrs Nybler on her excellent work and to note the coincidence that, on the Day of Europe which we are celebrating today, we are debating and will approve measures tomorrow that meet the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.

What is at stake in this regulation is to impose limits on mobile phone tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with the ultimate goal of ending roaming within the European area as of 2016.
Our citizens will now benefit from a sharp drop in prices for calls, texts, and data.
If nowadays there are operators that charge 3 euros per mega, from July onwards the maximum price they will be able to charge is 70 cents per mega, with this value dropping to 20 cents in 2014.
As for incoming calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be eight cents this year and five cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner said, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: higher quality of information for consumers.
Starting in the summer, operators will be required to inform consumers of the prices charged when they travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation was only within the European space.
Third advantage: the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition, which will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able, if they so choose, to have two contracts, one for services within the national territory and another for services abroad, while keeping the same mobile number and having only one bill.
The consumer, our citizen, will also be given the option to contract with any European operator that offers the best price.
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
Mr President, in February 2009 this Parliament approved a report supporting the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy.
There were projects on clean energy, transport, new technologies, innovation, and even then, the role of the European Investment Bank and the Structural Funds was being considered.
More than three years later, we have been able to produce the Six Pack, the Euro Plus Pact, the Fiscal Compact, the Two Pack, all of which are full of reinforced discipline and sanctions.

But meanwhile, as unemployment, especially among the young, reaches frightening levels, the European economy is entering a recession and more than seven of its member countries are experiencing negative growth.
And yet, while Greece is no more than a first stone threatening to bring down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At the moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters now is no longer to attribute a sense of urgency to it, but a sense of emergency, in a situation that threatens to explode.
A set of pillars urgently needs intervention.
First and foremost, the European Marshall Plan must be composed of investments that promote growth, employment, and convergence.
Project bonds are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us at least prepare to coordinate sovereign debt issuance and jointly manage the accumulated debt.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to actually function as true firewalls in defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that has been massively transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks has to reach companies.
A billion euros is held back in the banking system, while thousands of viable companies die every day due to lack of financing.
Fifth point: investment makes no sense without a quest.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that need to stimulate internal demand.

The fact is that nearly 80% of the exchanges are based within Europe, and it is up to the Commission, Commissioner Olesen, to make recommendations aimed not only at the most fragile economies, but also at the most dynamic ones.
And finally, I will conclude now, Madam President, there must be a limit to the revenues imposed by the troikas.

This brings us to the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which high-ranking officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member countries. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioner, what I wanted to say is very clear: of course the Portuguese MEPs from the EPP fully support all measures that can contribute to growth. There is no possibility of

We cannot emerge from this crisis without promoting growth, especially in those states that are most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I listen to some of my colleagues here, I get the feeling that they think we can continue to have growth with excessive deficits and more public debt.

Now, we must continue to insist on reducing spending and on structural reforms. We can do everything on the growth side, but we cannot abandon the path of containment and reduction of public spending and
more growth cannot be more relaxation, more rest; more growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigor in public accounts and with great rigor in structural reforms
If we only start talking about growth and think that there are magical solutions to growth, we will end up again with an unsustainable public debt and we will continue without structural reforms.

That said, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, at tomorrow's summit, it will not only be a matter of this long-term or medium-term issue of growth, but also the urgent issue of Greece, and I believe it is crucial that European states somehow stand by Greece.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem and I would like to refute here the statement made by the British MP who spoke of the Portugalisation of Europe, perhaps
The Portugalization of Europe, at least on the level of values, is not a negative thing, and therefore I reject this idea of trying, in the end, to humiliate or try to diminish any people.
We are all Europe and we all have a place in it.
Mr President, Commissioner, you have come here to tell us that every extra euro spent on debt is a euro less for job creation. So explain to us why we should continue with this obsession.

You come here to tell us that one of the summit's priorities is to keep Greece in the eurozone, and I ask you, Commissioner, do we believe you or do we believe Dr. Doron Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who were saying exactly the opposite a few days ago?
He spoke about maintaining the eurozone, and I ask myself, which euro?

in the euro we are currently living in, in this zone we are currently living in, or in the euro that was announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study in which it referred to a second-category euro if the left wins those June elections in Greece.
This is a trap, Commissioner, the trap of a Europe held hostage by governments and the trap of a Europe held hostage by financial interests.
Let us not let people live in fear, because that is not a way to live. Europe can be different, Mr. wise man, there is no lack of money, there is a lack of shame.

Mr President, Minister Lehmann, the first thing I would like to state is that it is regrettable that the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative, Mrs Ashton, is not present at a debate of this importance.

I would like, first of all, to offer a word of comfort and solidarity to the Guinean people, who have basically been the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability, and great insecurity.
It is no longer just the poverty that is widespread, it has been systematically affected by these evils.

I wanted to say, on the other hand, that the EPP, under its Presidency, has been following this issue from the beginning and that it is also regrettable that the European Parliament can only hold a debate on this matter after a month.
This has to do with the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean issue.

And this invisibility is due solely to the fact that, unlike other very serious matters, there are no large economic interests at stake here that would motivate the European, American, and world powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say that if an external reason is needed, if misery and political instability are not enough for us to have a global humanitarian and political response, then there is
Not least the situation of drug trafficking that is spreading in Guinea and that directly affects European and American peoples is a reason for us to strive for this.
And that is why I am calling on the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that Resolution 2048 and the decisions of the European Union, the Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries, the African Union, but perhaps no longer of the Community of West African States, are moving in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, we need actions.
We need to be firmer, we need to be more effective with the states that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
This is our obligation.

I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well in terms of principles, but it is not responding as it should in terms of the practical instruments of the operation on the ground, and that is what I ask of the Council and I ask of the Commission.

Mr President, Mr President-in-Office, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, globalisation has brought with it a disproportionate growth in the financial sector, whose transactions are now, as we know, 70 times greater than global wealth.

Opacity, very frequent transactions, high compensation, and very high risk have not only come to characterize the world we live in today, but are also fundamental reasons for the crisis we are going through.
However, this crisis came to demand accountability and much more effort from ordinary citizens than from the sector that had caused it.
So today and this moment is important.

It is important and I would personally like to see a situation where the tax is generalized in all European Union countries and subsequently extended to the rest of the world, through active participation of the Commission and the European Union in general in the context of the G20.
I would like it to be covered or to cover all products, without exception.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary reinforcement of the European Union's own resources.
In the short term, compromises have to be accepted, but we must not lose sight of the direction in which we need to move.
This can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission, and with a great spirit of compromise on the part of the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today, and I can only thank, here today, not only the Annapolis Mattei, who was tireless in this process, but also all those who managed to overcome their differences to reach a common position.

Mr President, thank you, fellow Member Podimata, today we are discussing here for the first time the tax on financial transactions and if it is approved it is the first sign that speculation will not go completely unpunished in this crisis we are living through.
This House and the European institutions must answer to the people and not to the financial markets.
For decades, the financial market lobbies have managed to govern the world without opposition and without any problems.
It is obvious to us that, during 2008 and 2012, the speculative financial market crisis was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.
And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to prevent any action being taken, but also to facilitate a direct transfer from the citizens' pockets to these same speculative markets.

We have been fighting for this for many years, Mr President, but it was only when the people all over Europe began to say enough is enough that there was finally some initiative from the institutions that govern the European Union.
And so, this is the answer we have to give to the citizens, it is a first sign that we have to give.
The citizens of Europe, who have everything to pay for, do not deserve that we disrespect them.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, it will not solve the entire problem of financial speculation, but it is an important signal.
We have been walking, not us, European leaders have been apologizing to the financial markets.
they should apologize to the people they have affected.
And, to conclude, Mr President, quoting a now famous politician, it is these markets we are talking about, these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments will give a sign of trust to the people and I sincerely hope that, with this approval and with the positive vote of my colleagues, we will start to talk about justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, gather your courage, let's get this project passed.
Mr President, the financial transaction tax should serve as a means of controlling and discouraging high-risk speculative activities in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and increase healthy competition, the foundation of the single market, and also generate revenue.

The Podimata report attempted to bring the European Commission's initial proposal closer to the UK's well-known Stamp Tax. In this way, we made this proposal more attractive to reluctant member states.
The Council is also expected to understand the message.

If, in the Commission's proposal, the tax applied to transactions of financial institutions located within the territory of the European Union, it is now intended that transactions in European assets, even if carried out by non-Europeans, should also be taxed.
This measure will broaden the revenue base and reduce evasion.
It is expected that tax revenues will be considered as a source of own resources of the Union or the States, reducing the taxes of the member States, a matter still to be decided.
I conclude, Mr President, by congratulating the rapporteur on the quality of her work and I hope that this symbolic text
Madam President, this weekend we had another request to save the private banking sector.

They keep saying the same argument, which is to prevent contagion in the eurozone, and what I ask is whether we have learned nothing from Greece, Portugal, Ireland and now Spain, and yet the contagion continues.
But what kind of containment of contagion is this that is destroying us?

This policy doesn't work, we should have known it already. It's the same rulers who say there's no money for culture, education, health, public goods, who, when banks ask the markets, make it appear right away, almost by miracle.
This economic policy is not a remedy, it is a deadly poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for social Europe.
The markets dictate and the governments obey and blackmail the peoples and that is what the governments are doing with Greece at the moment, during an election period.
I sincerely hope that we, the Greek people, will not be blackmailed next Sunday and that we will teach them a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, the proposals we are discussing here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the eurozone and also implement the logic of the Fiscal Treaty.

Some declarations of intent, but they are very timid. I refer, for example, to the roadmap for a day when we can start thinking about ways to define possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of Eurobonds.
The problem is that this day will only come when all the problems in the eurozone have been resolved, and it will take a very long time to get there.
We support some aspects of this proposal, but at this pace, everything will be too little and too late.

Member states that honor their debt, but withdraw from them all the instruments that could allow them to grow and find the resources to do so.
