As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and now Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment and insolvency. And end, Mr President, by saying that the worsening of these situations and their spread to other economies are bringing us to a point of no return.

Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German government are proposing the same policy, but in a more subdued form, and the neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
Given the extremely limited time we have, I simply want to tell the Commission at this moment that it can count on this support, as it has always been able to count on it.
Parliament works effectively in favor of the solidity of the eurozone and Europe, but this is only achieved when initiatives focus on discipline, on the

We have managed to add the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices between the different member states and between the different citizens, and a hope that we will emerge from the crisis we are currently experiencing.
For this hope to exist, other initiatives are needed, and it is these that this Parliament is trying to fill with an initiative focused on investment, growth, and control.
the sovereign debt that has been the Achilles' heel, evident, reflecting the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Commissioner, you can count on us, the Council and the President can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda, it cannot be an agenda that does
discipline, the condition for everything else to follow, even if it makes discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this of us, they can count on Parliament, and I want to thank my colleagues once again, the rapporteurs, Mr Gozelski and another rapporteur, and all the colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active participants in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.
for a more balanced, more solid Parliament project, which I hope will deserve the respect, the capacity for dialogue and the spirit of construction and compromise that it has had so far.
Thank you very much, Mr President, thank you very much, Madam President, thank you very much, Commissioner.

Madam President, in addition to thanking all those who contributed to this result, I would like to request that the final vote be postponed so that we can negotiate immediately at the trialogue level.
The EU is currently facing three agendas: the growth agenda, the agenda concerning bank management, and the agenda concerning sovereign debt management.
And dealing with the European semester involves including these three dimensions.
on the issue of growth and I think that, at this point, it is important to emphasize that the Commission's recommendations cannot only focus on
countries with deficits must also impose burdens on countries with surpluses, and if some must suppress their domestic demand, others must unleash it.

I also think that, in terms of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called troika, because when a country enters a recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public spending, as if nothing had happened.
The troikas must have their recipe reviewed and adjusted based on the results. And I want to tell you, Commissioner, that we approve this here in Parliament today
Parliament needs to launch a tool for growth and counter-cyclical activity of the order of 1% of the European Union's GDP over ten years.

A second dimension, which is fundamental, is the dimension of what is now called banking union. We asked in Parliament for this to be done two years ago, in the June 2010 report, and so far it has not been implemented.

A third dimension is the sovereign debt dimension, without it there is no stability in Europe and I also want to say that today we approve the TUPEC here, but we introduced in the TUPEC, in addition to austerity.
something else has been missing, and that is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, using German terminology, so that sovereign debt exceeding 60% can be managed collectively.

This is a legislative text and we expect the Commission's full support for this Parliament initiative, so that we can control the completely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, now that we are seeking to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget citizenship and consumers, in other words, the human and social dimension that our society has.

which gives it substance and which was the subject of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001, because any growth pact must take into account the sacrifices and social benefits associated with it.

Just as important as a test of the internal market will be a test of the social impact of all measures taken to achieve the single market, a test, a review that allows us to measure the progress made for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost more than 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is experiencing an unprecedented contraction and unemployment among men, women, and young people is reaching historic records.
According to forecasts by the Bank of Portugal, the situation will worsen in the next two years.
It is in this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
Now and always insisting on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, the member states will really have to focus their efforts on job creation.

The means to achieve this should involve subsidies for hiring that create new jobs, reducing the tax burden on labor, and support for the creation of new businesses and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises that maintain jobs.
National employment policies must bear in mind that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are health, information and communication technologies, and the green economy.
It is urgent, as stated in the communication, to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the skills demanded by the job market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment involves worker mobility.
It is also crucial to use structural funds for job creation and the practical importance of the EUROS portal as the primary instrument for recruitment and job offers in Europe.
Finally, social governance has to be on the agenda, because our citizens are eagerly waiting for concrete results. Thank you very much.

Mr President, Commissioner, it is true that six months have passed since this scandal involving GDP came to light, and the most unbelievable thing is that a private company could have managed to do this for ten years.
operated in the market and introduced silicone implants that were intended for the construction and manufacturing of collections and were used in women in 71 countries.
This affected a large number of women, as mentioned, it is estimated that around 500,000.

We are now talking about estimates because there were failures and serious failures in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, it is a fraud, it is a judicial case, but we also know

that there is fraud here that must be controlled by the courts and the courts will deal with it, but there is a legal failure, there is a legal vacuum and that is what we must deal with. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For ten years, we were unable to identify what the criminals were able to identify, and therefore there was a void in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of files, in terms of records, everything failed, but these gentlemen from this company were able to put into practice what we were unable to control and that is why

And in this process there is not only the issue of lack of information, which is very important, in fact, of lack of information on all issues related to breast implants, but also the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation, in particular, of those women who had to undergo tests to find out if they had been fitted with the correct implants or not.

We are talking about a public health issue and we cannot be lax on public health. We control so many unnecessary things, we even control the authenticity of car parts and just recently we approved a directive on this.

We have to control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the medical device directive is good news, it was the best news that we would not have to do it, but now that we are going to do it, we apply it with

It has conditions, with traceability, transparency, sanctions, because, unfortunately, the sanctions, even if applied, will no longer be applied to the women who have suffered from this problem, and the States must assume full responsibility.
Mr President, I would like to state very clearly here that the Council meeting at the end of June is crucial for us, and that what is essential is that a European solution to this crisis is sought.
From our point of view, the problem so far is that we have been dealing with each of the issues that arise in isolation and individually.

The time has come for us to have a global solution for Europe, a solution that involves, as President Doulou has very clearly stated here, more integration, more cooperation, greater alignment of European policies, and the strengthening of the Community method.
It is essential that alongside stability there is growth, but that we do not abandon concerns about stability.
We therefore count on a global European response, not a response divided for each state or for each region in difficulty.
The productive and increased production possibilities led to considerable increases in milk production, creating critical situations of surpluses and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these surpluses were sold at bargain prices in the market of other countries, generating even greater downward pressure on the prices paid to producers in those countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk, sold in France at double the price it was sold in Galicia, and the producers, with the high increase in the cost of raw materials and production factors, now see their ability to withstand low prices extremely reduced.

This is bad news for many farms and productive territories in Europe and also seems to be a clear indication of what a future without quotas and without adequate supply regulation instruments could look like.

There is, therefore, a need for a detailed audit of the territorial impacts on thousands of farms across the European Union of the abolition of these instruments that we currently have to regulate supply.
Mr President, I should like to start by congratulating the rapporteur on this report.
This is a matter of utmost importance for Europe.
At a time when we are experiencing a serious economic, financial and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by combating counterfeit products is crucial for the European economy.
This protection should enhance research performance and promote innovation, ensuring scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All of this with the aim of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years, we have witnessed a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, which represents annual losses, as mentioned here, of 250 million euros for companies and the destruction of 185 jobs in the European area.

But, beyond these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, medicines, etc., are dangerous.
etc., are produced in unregulated environments.
That is why the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing counterfeit products from entering the internal market.
The revision of this regulation aims to strengthen the control of the application of the legislation in question, reinforce the legitimacy of its intervention, increase the
legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the regulation to new realities and new developments, thereby contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are thus a crucial priority for achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in order to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, indeed, the election of the new Egyptian president, Mr. Mubarak, is good news, but we cannot delude ourselves, and these presidential elections do not in any way close what is the transition process that is taking place in Egypt.

It was well noted that the dissolution of Parliament, days before the presidential elections, puts several risks on the table and, in this case, the power that is concentrated in the United Nations Supreme Council.

The Armed Forces were the least exaggerated, they have legislative power, they reduced the power of the President and, in addition, they still have in their hands the definition of changes in the Constitution.

Now, all of this raises some concerns for us, and should raise some concerns for us, because the Egyptians risk becoming hostages to military power and a return to the past, lacking a fundamental element, which is a democratically elected parliament.
It is not up to us to bring about change in Egypt, it is up to the Egyptians
But I think that we Europeans will have to stand by all the changes that propose the restoration of what is democratic legitimacy and of a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, I begin by congratulating my colleague, the rapporteur, Lara Comi, for the excellent work she has done on this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a world and a society undergoing rapid transformation, Europe needs a comprehensive, integrative, effective and up-to-date standardization system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, improves consumer protection and their quality of life, but also protects the environment, is essential.

It is also very important to have more innovation and social inclusion, as well as interaction and communication between networks and systems, especially in the field, as has already been emphasized here, of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti stated in his report "A New Strategy for the Single Market", European standardisation is essential for the governance of the internal market, as highlighted in the
The need for a review of the European standardisation process, which maintains the advantages of the current system and finds the right balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report we are now discussing follows and defends these objectives, which are correct and appropriate, to end the slowness and fragmentation that exist and that cause companies to incur costs.

transaction costs and higher unit costs, strengthen the participation of SMEs in standardisation activities, particularly at national level, and facilitate their access to these standards, also strengthen

On the other hand, the participation of parties representing societal interests, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, and people with disabilities, while maintaining financial support for European organizations created to represent public interests.
I conclude by saying that the approval of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, and to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies.
Mr President, Commissioner, the future common fisheries policy must give priority to its environmental, economic and social sectors, and the fisheries policy must be given priority.
in a synergistic and non-hierarchical manner, in the interests of sustainable development and in line with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 Strategy.
As rapporteur for the third system, I would like to highlight the particularity of some regions, such as the outermost regions, whose economies are heavily dependent on the sector.

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thereby safeguarding and defending the employment that depends on them.

I agree with the European Commission's position on the need for an adjustment of this policy and specific measures that must take into account the disparate realities of the fishing and aquaculture sector in various coastal regions.

I argue that this policy should focus on regionalization as a form of governance, through an enhancement of the participation of various stakeholders, so that in the future, a more adequate response to the demands and sensitivities of each maritime basin can be achieved.
We are reaching the decisive moments when we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe and we cannot fail.

The need and urgency to achieve sustainable rebalancing in our allotical resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and the promotion of their socio-economic level, in the modernization of the sector and in the supply of quality food, require more than ever arrogance and courageous measures.
We must therefore make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, suggesting that the exploitation of its resources be carried out taking into account scientific data, giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploitation, and restricting external access, beyond 100 miles, to the fishing banks there.
It proposed to safeguard the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting proposals for transferable quotas.

He proposed that our communities have better intervention in the management of their fishing affairs with the creation of a regional advisory council of their own, more suitable for interperipheral regions. I hope that in this way we can have a better future.

18 Member States have been notified, but this information is probably already outdated due to lack of transposition. My question to you is how you are addressing the possibility that the legislation being prepared, particularly regarding networks, might be affected.
trans-European networks, if it includes a device, an incentive, that conditions a conditionality for the submission of PICs, of projects of common interest or that

conditions the fulfillment by the Member States of the obligations arising from the third package or, on the contrary, believes that this is an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left only to the regular competition mechanisms, Article 101.
201 and his successors all the intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
The question is whether, with legislation in preparation that could be approved, we will be able to do our part.
Introducing an additional and much stronger conditionality means that this conditionality is an abusive instrument or do you think this conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share much of the concern that was initially presented here, regarding democratic legitimacy and democratic control, which are related to this proposal.

of the Banking Union and Banking Supervision, because an essential issue remains to be clarified and resolved, which is the role of Parliament, the only institution directly democratically elected by citizens.

But there is another concern that also has, which is a fundamental concern and has to do with the following: monetary policy instruments are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union, and yet, if everything goes wrong, if banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying that bankruptcy continues to fall on the taxpayers of the national states, it remains a national responsibility.

This is not a minor issue, it is a fundamental problem that remains unresolved, and finally, I just want to point out that it also does not resolve the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context in which we live, which is inflation, and not to job creation and growth, as it should be.

Mr President, European leaders keep harping on about fiscal discipline, and I say fiscal discipline, then let's have it, because what exactly are we talking about when we talk about fiscal discipline?

In my understanding, budgetary discipline means respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the state's commitments halfway through. In my understanding, budgetary discipline means respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts in subsidies.

The budgetary goal is to respect commitments in health, education, and culture, and not to close services or cancel projects halfway through. Discipline means getting the banks in order and not taking money from taxpayers to hand it over to speculators to save their banks.
This is the fiscal discipline I would like to see implemented in the European Union, rather than continuing with this market party.

Mr President, you need an example: the budget being discussed in Portugal under the troika's guidance is a perfect example; it violates all the commitments that any state must have with its citizens, not to mention the agreements made behind closed doors that are ruining Europe and its countries.

Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, first of all, I naturally wish to congratulate you on the results of the Council, although it seems to me that it is somewhat delayed in time, the final decision is coming a little late.
The truth is that there is progress

Now, precisely because I see myself reflected in everything that my colleague Lida Caçula said, I would like to ask just one question to the President of the Council: the countries that are under assistance,
Countries in difficulty have fought hard to ensure that there can be a retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from state debt.
And, apparently, that was not the site.
But we heard statements yesterday from the highest German authorities and the highest French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland as a special situation.
What I am asking is whether the Council has approved any decision to apply discriminatory treatment to Ireland, different from that reserved for countries like Portugal, Greece, Spain, and others.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses in
regarding the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, in which the twentieth anniversary of this market was marked.

A word of thanks first of all to my fellow Members from all the political groups, and in particular to the draftsmen of opinions and the shadow rapporteurs, for their very constructive contributions and their very positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with everyone and the report greatly benefited from our combined effort.

We are well aware and proud of the fact that, over the past 20 years, the single market has been the driving force behind major economic and employment opportunities in Europe, which have transformed the lives of European citizens and European businesses.
Traveling, residing, and working in the spaces of the Union are freedoms that are within reach of all citizens of the 27 member states.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the single market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the beginning of the crisis,
In 2008, just look at the 2.7 million jobs that were created and the 2.13 additional GDP growth.
Today, taking a TOEFL or receiving a TOEFL while traveling in Europe is 13% cheaper than in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people is most eloquently expressed in the Erasmus program.
More than 2.5 million students have benefited from this European education exchange and mobility program.
Over the past five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% cut in administrative posts due to single market legislation.
But one question arises: is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.
Our citizens, in some countries, are living with the drama of unemployment and facing austerity measures, and have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative view of the internal market.
People still do not know or sufficiently understand their rights, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many member states are unduly delaying the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thereby undermining its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, such simple things as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another EU country, opening a bank account for a student in the Program

Erasmus, changing energy supplier, transferring retirement pensions, having qualifications recognised and registering a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult or costly procedures.
it is important to address these problems.
That was my concern, as rapporteur.
That is why the message written in the report is very clear: more political will is needed, much more political will from the member states and the European institutions.

Council, especially the Council and the Commission, to govern better and together, it is necessary to regain the trust of people and companies and it is necessary to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to commend the European Commission, represented by Commissioner Barnier, for presenting the Act for the Market II, 12 priority actions for new growth, which I am sure marks a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier and dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your efforts, which have already been so successful.
When Jacques Delors presided over the European Commission, the Union's single market was created in 1992.
Delors then summarized the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years on, the economic and financial crisis has revived the threat of national protectionism, and it has become clear that the internal market is not a finished work.

And the celebration of these twenty years must be used to relaunch the single market, with the concern of putting the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To achieve this, we need to set priorities, and I would like to talk about one priority in particular.
A common policy is essential to produce and distribute energy at affordable prices for consumers, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through a European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructure, with the possibility of leveraging Community investment that represents added European value.
In energy too, Madam President, it will dominate the common market.
The greatest achievements of the European Union certainly represent one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its member states and its regions.
However, in order to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize its policies towards equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve the greatest development of our most remote regions, such as the outermost regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue to increase their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions, but we will never achieve this if we do not better address our accessibility problems in the area of transportation.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that better address the problems raised by our separation.
We therefore argue that the Commission should consider a specific programme, similar to POSEI transport, as an essential instrument for integrating these types of regions into the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President, I would like to start by saying thank you for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate that demonstrated that the single market is truly a great achievement of the European project.

I welcome Minister Mavroyiannis's presence and his participation in this debate, and I thank all my fellow Members for their constructive approach, and some for their sceptical approach, which is understandable.
And to say a big thank you to Commissioner Barnier for the effort and enthusiasm he puts into discussing these issues, these problems of the internal market and the political will to solve them.
We still have a lot to answer to the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, disillusioned and expect more from us, expect more from the Council, expect more from the Commission, expect more from the Member States.
This balance sheet is very useful, this 20-year balance sheet is important, but, as many have said here, it is important to open the door to the gaze of the future.
And the future outlook addresses many of the issues that have been raised here and many of the measures that have already been announced by the European Commission.
The digital single market, citizen mobility, the reform of the EURES portal, and the European energy market are examples.
eloquent proof that we still have an important path to follow in the future and that this path is very important and vital to respond to this era of crisis that we are living through.
Citizens are suffering, citizens expect a lot from politicians and the answers that politicians can give to the adverse conditions they are experiencing.
That is why it is important that the single market is one of the answers to the major challenge of competitiveness, employment and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, after this 20th anniversary celebration, are more prepared to provide the answers our citizens need.

Mr President, the Gozez report, together with the report we will be drafting on the Union's annual growth prospects at the end of this year, which will precede the Spring Council, are two essential components of the so-called European Semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council on a proposal from the Commission, and these recommendations, as was just mentioned, are in line with
six pack and the future two pack, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policy of member countries.

The balance and anticipation of control and autonomy and legitimacy at the national level is not easy to find and it has fallen to a level of imposition, especially of discipline, and ultimately, it may even result in a serious package of sanctions.

Regarding the TUPEC, I would like to briefly comment that it is important for the Council, which is absent today, to give its negotiators a negotiating mandate that is compatible with the ambition to quickly conclude this package, this TUPEC.

But more European coordination, to return to the topic, means less control of countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure consistency between medium- and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment, and real convergence, and short-term recommendations, which are primarily focused on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be consistency

with the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular the asymmetric impact of common policies and the negative externalities of the spillover effects of some national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, we need to agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic and labour rights that cannot be exceeded by these recommendations. Lastly, it is important that the quality of the recommendations is measured by the results achieved, which is far from being the case so far.

I have finished, Madam President, and I would just like to thank Mr Gozez for his spirit of collaboration and hope that he will take another step in this spirit, in order to broaden the consensus around his report and that this spirit will also remain in place for next year.
It is true, as it has been mentioned many times, that there are many things we do not know about shale gas extraction.
But there are also many that we already know and it is important not to forget them.
We know, for example, that each shale gas extraction operation uses more than 19 million litres of drinking water, which is enough to supply 1 European citizen for a year in terms of their needs.

We also know that for every shale gas extraction that is done, in each of the operations, 300 pieces of cotton balls are pumped into the sun, up to 300 tons of chemicals can go into the sun, and about 80 of which remain in the sun and do not come out.

We also know that, in each extraction of gas X, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released underground, which, together with the evaporation of toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute an effective threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of drinking water resources and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also a response that is apparently easy, that only thinks about the immediate, the industry and profit, ignoring the populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, in this house, that water is an essential, vital and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental standards and health standards.
Therefore, when you don't know everything, being in the know is the minimum.
And they may even want to do so, but do not do it in our name, nor in the name of the citizens who are here to represent us.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in fact, recent years have shown us that the Economic and Monetary Union did not withstand the crisis.
We also showed that we had a European institutional architecture full of holes, particularly the institutional architecture of the euro.
That is why the report presented here and the proposal put forward are so far ahead in terms of vision compared to what is proposed by the governments.

But also, as the rapporteur said, we are in a position of making political choices and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and will not be able to support this report.
The first has to do with issues related to conditionalities.

What we see and continue to experience is a narrative in which solidarity between different countries can only occur when everything is fulfilled in terms of the stability and growth plan, in terms of the intergovernmental agreement, pact for
more and a set of measures that impose nothing but massive doses of austerity in the peripheries and also a set of recessionary measures that, as we have already seen, are not working.
A second reason has to do with the banking union.

The rapporteur presents the banking supervision mechanism very well, but it is so necessary that we cannot shy away from the essential, and the essential here is slipping away as we continue to add up.

We are clustered in national systems, which means we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong and therefore taxpayers will continue to pay.
And a third point concerns the issue of common debt and the issuance of Eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of the emission of ordinary water is considered, but only when it is already too late.

Because we need the common debt and now it is not just when the deficits of excessive debts have been corrected, because with these policies we are following, they will never be corrected, on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire set of populations.

That is why, Mr President, I want to conclude by saying that, despite all the efforts, I think we have here a very clear example that together we could still stand up, but divided, we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to have gone even further.
Madam President, Mrs. Ferreira, please, there is always room for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union in recent years has been crucial.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country with highly trained, highly sophisticated labor.
But when a country exports, it must have conditions for where.
That is why it is important that some countries with surpluses open their doors to the requalified exports of countries that started with a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

One final note to say that it is not possible for immigration to be the solution, that the requalified workforce, where support from the European Union was used, is now lost through a massive export of the most qualified individuals to countries that have the capacity to welcome them.
This is dramatic and completely jeopardizes our future.

Mr President, small-scale fishing should be given special protection under the Common Fisheries Policy, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and ensures the livelihood of many families, but also because it is a factor in retaining these communities along the coastal areas.
Their economic and social sustainability must be an objective, ensuring them a differentiated fishing regime that gives priority of access to resources.
It allows for proximity management and protects the fishing rights that benefit the fishing professionals of these communities against transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important, for their sustainability, to take into account the water access regime, especially in waters or regions with biogeographical basins.
marine areas with a reduced continental shelf and scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that must have protected access.
In the context of liberalisation and crisis that weighs on fragile regions, it must also be ensured that products from international trade meet the same requirements as those that the Union imports.
Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, I shall be very brief because I swear that what is at issue here is essentially a political point, it is not a political point.
The financial point and the question that arises is this: do we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or do we want to exacerbate the crisis?

Most European countries are currently making a huge effort, from the point of view of their public finances, in order to overcome the crisis in a competitive way, in a way that can put their countries
The European Union, on a global level, has a great capacity for competition and rivalry, but it is obvious that without investment there can be no growth and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a huge
This effort will not allow them to grow and will cause the plan we have accepted in all countries for the European Union to fail: sound accounts with prospects for growth and competitiveness.

The only and great instrument for this is precisely this multiannual financial framework and, therefore, if we want the European Union to succeed and for this policy to be an exemplary policy for other countries, we must bet on the budget for the financial perspectives.
